questions.text: According to the Sample registration system (SRS) 2021 statistical data, the crude birth rate and crude death rate in India (per 1000 mid-year population) are
questions.solution:
According to the SRS 2021 update, the crude birth rate and death rate in India are 19.7 and 6 respectively. 

The birth rate is the number of live births per thousand population in a given region and year. It is a crude measure of the fertility of a population. It is a crucial determinant of population growth. The birth rate of India has considerably declined over the past 4 decades.

The death rate is the number of deaths per thousand population in a given region and time period. It is a simple measure of the mortality of a population. The death rate of India has considerably declined over the past 4 decades.

Note: This SRS report published in 2021 corresponds to the reference year 2019.

questions.text: A 28-year-old, 16-week pregnant woman comes to your clinic for a routine check-up. On examination, her BP is 144/92, pulse rate is 94 bpm. Urine examination is normal. USG shows normal expected fetal development. A subsequent repeat BP measurement also reveals a similar value. So,  you decide to treat her hypertension with a drug. Which of the following antihypertensives is not to be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy because of an increased risk of fetal renal damage. Therefore ACE inhibitors should be avoided in this patient who has chronic hypertension in pregnancy.

Chronic hypertension in pregnancy is defined by the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology (ACOG) as blood pressure ≥140 mm Hg systolic and/or 90 mm Hg diastolic before pregnancy or, in recognition that many women seek medical care only once pregnant, before 20 weeks of gestation, use of antihypertensive medications before pregnancy, or persistence of hypertension for >12 weeks after delivery.

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBS
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside

Antihypertensives found safer in pregnancy :

  • Labetalol
  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardioselective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: may be used as a last choice.
Conditions associated with hypertension
First choice drugs for hypertension
Diabetes
Chronic kidney disease with proteinuria
Inhibitors of renin-angiotensin system.
Angina
Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers
Heart failure
ACE inhibitors and alpha+beta blockers such as carvedilol
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
α1 Blockers
Pregnancy
Labetalol
Atrial fibrillation
Diltiazem and verapamil

Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy:

Gestational Hypertension

Pre-Eclampsia

Chronic Hypertension in pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Previously known hypertensive or BP  >140/90mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation

No Proteinuria

Proteinuria present(>300 mg in 24 hrs urine or >30 mg/dl in the random urine sample or urine dipstick 1+)

No proteinuria

BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

BP does not come to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

Other options:

  • Hydralazine: one of the safer drugs in pregnancy. Hydralazine causes preferential dilatation of arteries over veins. It causes a selective decrease in vascular resistance in coronary, cerebral, and renal circulation, with a smaller effect in skin and muscle. Because of preferential dilatation of arterioles over veins, postural hypotension is not a common problem. Hydralazine-induced vasodilation causes reflex activation of the sympathetic system through baroreceptor-mediated reflexes resulting in increased plasma renin activity.
  • Alpha methyldopa: Methyldopa is preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy based on its safety and efficacy data for both mother and fetus. Alpha-methyldopa is converted to methyl norepinephrine centrally to decrease the adrenergic outflow by alpha-2 agonistic action from the central nervous system, leading to reduced total peripheral resistance and decreased systemic blood pressure.
  • Labetalol: Labetalol acts by blocking both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular resistance without significant alteration of heart rate or cardiac output. Labetalol is now commonly used as a first-line treatment choice in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with complains of bilateral progressive hearing loss since 3 years. It was associated with intermittent tinnitus. Her mother had similar complaints and underwent surgery for the same. Rinne's test revealed bone conduction (BC) > air conduction (AC) bilaterally. Otoscopy was normal.  The audiogram showed a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz and the following type of graph is obtained on tympanometry. What is the most common site of lesion in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common site of origin in otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestram lying in front of the oval window.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis Any site but asymptomatic

 

Otosclerosis is bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy, menopause.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).

Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicates that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz knows as Carhart's notch (see image below).

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: The brain CT scan of a 42-year-old man shows multiple punctate calcifications and two cystic lesions in the brain parenchyma with surrounding edema. A fecal examination reveals round eggs as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely mode of infection in this condition?

choices.text: Ingestion of fruit contaminated with cow manure

questions.solution:
The CT scan with multiple punctate calcifications and cystic lesions in brain tissue suggests neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium, and autoinfection in a human is the most likely mode of infection among the given options. Autoinfection in T. solium may occur if eggs derived from his or her own feces are ingested.

T. solium mainly causes two forms of infection in humans:

  • Intestinal taeniasis- Adult tapeworms in the intestine. It results when raw or undercooked meats containing the cysticerci are ingested. Intestinal taeniasis may be asymptomatic with the passage of proglottids in the feces.
  • Cysticercosis- Larval forms in the tissues. It results from ingestion of T.solium eggs- either by auto-infection or by ingestion of human feces contaminated food or water. In cysticercosis, the cysticerci are most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or eye.

Neurocysticercosis is the most common form of cysticercosis, presenting with seizures, symptoms of increased intracranial pressure including headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, dizziness, ataxia, or confusion. Papilledema may develop secondary to hydrocephalus. Cysticerci may even cause chronic meningitis or arachnoiditis, hemorrhages, or strokes.

Diagnosis:

  • Fecal examination shows eggs of Taenia, but species identification requires examination of proglottids.
  • Histologic demonstration of the parasite from a biopsy of a brain or spinal cord lesion
  • Fundoscopic visualization of subretinal cysticercus
  • Demonstration of a scolex within a cystic lesion on CT or MRI. Findings include cystic lesions with or without enhancement (e.g., ring enhancement), nodular calcifications, focal enhancing lesions, or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Treatment:

  • Intestinal T. solium infection - single dose of praziquantel.
  • Neurocysticercosis - anti-epileptic drugs, antiparasitic drugs like albendazole or praziquantel, high-dose glucocorticoids.
  • For hydrocephalus, removal of cysticercus by endoscopic surgery may be done.

Other options-

Option B- Exposure to dogs can lead to Hydatid cyst caused by echinococcosis granulosus.

Option D- Ingestion of fruit contaminated with cow manure would lead to intestinal taeniasis due to Taenia saginata.

MRI of a patient with neurocysticercosis demonstrating multiple cysticerci within the brain is shown below.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Cestode
Diphyllobothrium latum Plerocercoid larva Eggs or segments of the tapeworm
Taenia saginata Cysticercus bovis Egg
Taenia solium Cysticercus cellulosae Egg (for intestinal taeniasis ) / cysticercus cellulosae larva (for cysticercosis)
Echinococcus granulosus Egg Protoscolices and brood capsules
Hymenolepsis nana Egg Egg
Trematode

Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
Nematode

Ancylostoma duodenale

Dracunculus medinensis Third stage filariform larva (L3) Adult worm
Hint: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing autoinfection.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, breathlessness, and cramping pain in the right leg. He reports to have had deep vein thrombosis in the right leg 1 year ago. His BP was 128/88 mmHg and his pulse was 110 bpm. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE). The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition is CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA).

PE and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are part of the same spectrum of venous thromboembolism. PE occurs due to obstruction of the pulmonary arterial circulation by deep venous thrombi that detach from their site of formation and embolize to the vena cava, right atrium, and right ventricle.

Virchow’s triad of venous stasis, hypercoagulability, and endothelial injury, leading to recruitment of activated platelets, provides the ideal environment for thrombus formation.

PE can be classified as:

  • High-risk massive PE (extensive thrombosis affecting at least half of the pulmonary vasculature): Characterised by dyspnea, syncope, hypotension, cyanosis, cardiogenic shock, multisystem organ failure
  • Intermediate-risk submassive PE: Characterised by right ventricular (RV) dysfunction with normal systemic arterial pressure.
  • Low-risk PE: Shows excellent prognosis

Symptoms of PE are nonspecific, the most common among them being unexplained breathlessness.

Well's criteria is used to assess the likelihood of PE in a patient. For a patient with low-to-moderate likelihood of PE, the initial investigation is measurement of D-dimer levels. Whereas, for a patient with high likelihood of PE, the choice of investigation is CTPA. 

In the given patient, clinical signs of DVT, past history of DVT, heart rate >100 bpm, and a diagnosis other than PE being less likely contribute to the high likelihood of PE according to Well's criteria.

A normal D-dimer test helps to rule out PE. However, increased D-dimer levels are nonspecific as they can be seen in patients with other systemic illnesses including myocardial infarction (MI), pneumonia, sepsis, and cancer.

CTPA, also known as CT chest angiogram with contrast, is performed in patients with high probability of PE or those with low-to-moderate probability but elevated D-dimer levels. It is highly specific and sensitive, and a positive CTPA showing a filling defect confirms the diagnosis of PE.

The arrows in the image below show a large pulmonary embolism at the bifurcation of the pulmonary artery (saddle embolism):

Other options:

Option A: Echocardiography is not reliable because most patients with PE have normal echocardiograms. However, it can be used for detecting conditions that mimic PE like acute MI, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection. The best indirect sign of PE on transthoracic echo is McConnell’s sign (hypokinesis of the RV free wall with normal or hyperkinetic motion of the RV apex).

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning is a second-line diagnostic test that detects absent or decreased blood flow due to PE. It is performed when CTPA is contraindicated or inconclusive and additional testing is required.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. 

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents to the emergency room with chest pain and is found to have suffered a myocardial infarction. The medical evaluation suggested the need for a triple bypass procedure. This is performed on the fifth day of his hospital stay. During recovery, he develops septic shock with fever and pneumonia. Gram-positive cocci in clusters were isolated from his sputum and the surgical incision. It formed beta-hemolytic colonies on sheep blood agar. Kirby-Bauer testing demonstrates that the organism is resistant to oxacillin, penicillin, erythromycin, and gentamicin. Which of the following statements is correct about the patient’s infection in the post-op phase?

1. The isolate is Staphylococcus aureus.
2. The isolate is resistant to third and fourth-generation cephalosporins.
3. Resistance to oxacillin is encoded on the chromosome.
4. Patient should be treated with imipenem.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 3 are correct. The isolate from the sputum and wound infection is Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) which is resistant to most beta-lactams including imipenem.

Gram positive cocci in clusters that form beta-hemolytic colonies on sheep blood agar indicate that the organism is staphylococcus aureus. Resistance to oxacillin on carrying out Kirby-Bauer testing indicates the strain is MRSA.

Methicillin resistance occurs due to changes in bacterial cell surface receptors and alterations in the penicillin-binding protein (PB2a). This protein is synthesized by the mecA gene, which is part of a larger chromosomal mobile genetic element called SCCmec. There are 12 different SCCmec types. Types I, II, III, VI, and VIII are associated with hospital-acquired methicillin-resistant S. aureus (HA- MRSA) infections. SCCmec type IV has been found mainly in community-acquired MRSA strains that tend to be less resistant and more transmissible.

Resistance to methicillin indicates resistance to all semisynthetic penicillinase-resistant penicillins (SPRPs), such as oxacillin or nafcillin, and to all cephalosporins (except ceftaroline, ceftobiprole and razupenem)

Vancomycin or daptomycin are the drugs of choice for the treatment of MRSA bacteremia, endocarditis, and complicated skin infections.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes hip arthroplasty. The consultant advises starting the patient on anticoagulation to prevent venous thromboembolism.  He specifically asks to administer an anticoagulant that acts by directly inhibiting the thrombin enzyme. Which of the following drugs is the most likely anticoagulant given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI). They represent a new class of anticoagulant drugs.

Direct thrombin inhibitor – Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTIs) prevent thrombin from cleaving fibrinogen to fibrin. They bind to thrombin directly, rather than by enhancing the activity of antithrombin, as is done by heparin.

  • Parenteral DTIs include bivalirudin, argatroban, and desirudin. 
  • The only oral DTI available for clinical use is dabigatran.

Indications:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

Dabigatran is the only oral DTI available for clinical use and is generally given at a fixed dose without monitoring. Maximum anticoagulant effects are achieved within two to three hours of ingestion. Excretion of the unchanged drug by the kidney is the predominant elimination pathway. 

The major adverse effect of dabigatran is bleeding. There is an additional risk for bleeding in renal impairment and concurrent use of antiplatelet agents or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Dabigatran is contraindicated for stroke prevention in patients with mechanical heart valves.

Other options:

Option A- Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits the enzyme (vitamin K reductase) that catalyzes the conversion of oxidized vitamin K to the reduced form of vitamin K. The reduced vitamin K is involved in the carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S.

Options B and D- Rivaroxaban and apixaban are direct oral factor Xa inhibitors that inhibit the free and clot-associated factor Xa resulting in reduced thrombin generation.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: A young girl is brought with a deformity of the upper limbs. She has a history of multiple fractures and her father has a similar history since his childhood. The image of the patient's eye and the radiographs of the upper limb are shown below. Which of the following is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing the blue sclera and bowing of the upper limbs are suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It occurs due to the defect in the formation of type 1 collagen.

Osteogenesis imperfecta, also called brittle bone disease, is an autosomal dominant disorder. There are 8 types of osteogenesis imperfecta. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

Since type 1 collagen is mainly present in the bone, ligament, dentin, and sclera, patients will present with repeated fractures, deformities of bone, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities.

The image given below shows different metabolic disorders of the bone.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Arjun (32/M) comes to your clinic for a regular health check-up with his mother (65/F) and wife (28/F). He read about adequate calorie requirements online and requests your advice regarding the same. He weighs 65 Kgs, is a software engineer and his lifestyle is predominantly sedentary. His wife weighs 55 Kg, is pregnant, and is in her second trimester. Her lifestyle is sedentary too.  According to the latest NIN RDA guideline, how many calories should Arjun, his wife, and his mother respectively consume?
questions.solution:
According to the RDA 2020 guideline, Arjun who is a sedentary worker must consume 2110 Kcal.

His pregnant wife with a sedentary lifestyle must consume 2010 Kcal.

His mother, whose age is 65 must consume 1500 Kcal.

Dietary Reference Intakes

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group
  • Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the individuals in a group

The EAR for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years) is 1500 Kcal/D.

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

questions.text:
A 24-year-old female patient comes with complaints of swelling under both her eyes, both lower limbs along with abdominal distension. On examination, her BP is 140/90, pulse rate is 82 bpm, respiratory rate is 12/min and temperature is 98.6 deg F. Pitting edema is seen in both lower limbs. Urine analysis also shows proteinuria prompting the doctor provisionally diagnoses the condition as a glomerular pathology. If the provisional diagnosis is indeed correct, which of the following additional findings can be seen in this patient's urine?
  1. RBC casts
  2. Muddy brown casts
  3. Dysmorphic RBCs
  4. Isomorphic RBCs
questions.solution:
Dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts would be seen in a patient with glomerular disease.

Glomerulonephritis (GN) generally presents as a constellation of findings that include hematuria, proteinuria, edema, and often hypertension. GN is caused by a number of disorders that are all characterized by glomerular injury accompanied by inflammation. In some cases, GN may progress to kidney failure.

This patient's generalized edema and hypertension point towards a diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Further, proteinuria strengthens the possibility of the diagnosis of glomerulonephritis.

For the diagnosis of glomerular diseases from urine 40/5/1 rule is followed which includes:

  • 40% dysmorphic RBCs.
  • 5% acanthocytes (a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs).
  • Even a single RBC cast.

Hematuria can be either due to systemic or renal causes. Renal causes can be further subdivided into glomerular and non-glomerular causes as given below:

Glomerular Non-glomerular

Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size)

Isomorphic RBCs seen (normal shape and size)

RBC casts may be present

RBC casts always absent

MCV  is small (<72 fl)

MCV is normal

Protein leakage is more (>1g/day)

Protein leakage is less (<1g/day)

The cause is usually medical

The cause is usually surgical

Other options:

  • Muddy brown casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis which is a type of intrinsic renal failure.  Epithelial casts and granular casts can also be seen in acute tubular necrosis.
  • Isomorphic RBCs (normal shape and size) are seen in non-glomerular pathologies generally.
  • Broad casts are seen in advanced chronic kidney disease and indicates poor prognosis.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the clinic with significant fatigue and weakness. He also complains of difficulty in controlling bleeding, even from minor wounds. On examination, his BP is found to be 110/70, pulse rate is 102 bpm, respiratory rate is 16/min and the temperature is 98.6 deg F. Pallor of the conjunctivae of the eyes is seen. Flow cytometry shows the absence of glycol-phosphatidyl inositol (GPI)-linked protein expression on blood cells. Which of the following best represents laboratory abnormalities seen in this patient?

choices.text: high MCV, low haptoglobin, low LDH, low urinary urobilinogen
high MCV, low haptoglobin, high LDH, high urinary urobilinogen
low MCV, high haptoglobin, low LDH, low urinary urobilinogen
low MCV, high haptoglobin, high LDH, high urinary urobilinogen

questions.solution:
Laboratory abnormalities seen in Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH) i.e Intravascular hemolysis are high MCV, low haptoglobin, high LDH, and high urinary urobilinogen.

This patient's fatigue, weakness, and pallor of the conjunctivae of the eyes point towards anemia while difficulty controlling bleeding suggests decreased platelets. Further, flow cytometry shows the absence of glycol-phosphatidyl inositol (GPI)-linked protein expression i.e deficiency of CD55 and CD59 on blood cells which suggests that the most likely diagnosis is Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH).

PNH is an acquired chronic hemolytic anemia with persistent intravascular hemolysis.

It is due to an acquired mutation in the X-linked phosphatidylinositol class A PIG-A gene causing deficiency of GPI. GPI is a glycolipid that anchors membrane protective factors such as CD59 and CD55 to the membrane. The deficiency of CD55 and CD59 makes the RBC sensitive to complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis.

PNH is characterized by hemolytic anemia, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis involving cerebral, hepatic, renal, portal, and abdominal veins.

Patients with PNH usually also tend to have bone marrow dysfunction resulting in pancytopenia. They may present with anemia, increased susceptibility to bacterial and fungal infections, and bleeding manifestations. This bone marrow dysfunction may rarely transform into aplastic anemia or acute myeloid leukemia (AML). 

PNH is also associated with venous thrombosis. Symptoms depend on the veins involved and may include abdominal pain due to abdominal vein thrombosis, acute hepatomegaly due to hepatic vein thrombosis (Budd Chiari syndrome), headaches and confusion due to cerebral vein thrombosis, acute kidney injury due to renal vein thrombosis. Venous thrombosis is the most common cause of death in PNH. 

The gold standard for the diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is flow cytometry. When carried out on granulocytes and RBCs, it shows the absence of glycol-phosphatidyl inositol (GPI)-linked protein i.e CD59 and CD55 negative blood cells which is diagnostic of PNH. 

Note-

The tendency of red cells to lyse at night is explained by a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep. This increases the activity of complement.

Laboratory findings show-

Lab parameters Derangement  Explanation
MCV High Due to compensatory reticulocytosis
S. LDH High Released from RBCs
S. Unconjugated bilirubin High Hemoglobin released from RBC is converted to bilirubin
Urinary urobilinogen High Hemoglobin released from RBC is converted to bilirubin which in turn causes urobilinogen to increase
S. Haptoglobin Low Free hemoglobin in circulation binds to haptoglobin causing decline in free haptoglobin levels

Additionally, hemoglobinuria and hemosiderinemia may be seen on urine examination.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother because she has not started menstruating. Her mother and older sister started menstruating at the age of 16 yrs. She is a healthy girl and lies along the 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. She has scant axillary and pubic hair and breasts are Tanner stage 3. Pelvic examination is normal and she says she is not sexually active. She has an old sonographic report of abdomen and pelvis that was normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
All women with amenorrhoea,whether primary or secondary, should undergo beta-HCG testing to rule out pregnancy. Only after this, other investigations, if needed, should be done.

Note: All reproductive-aged women with amenorrhea are assumed pregnant until proven otherwise. Thus, a urinary or serum β -hCG level is always obtained

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below. Which of the following structures is not cut during the procedure most commonly carried out by this instrument?

choices.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal  nerves

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is an episiotomy scissors. The obturator muscle is not cut during mediolateral episiotomy which is the most commonly done procedure using this instrument.

A surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour is called an episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J shaped episiotomy.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with hypertension. After initial workup and investigations, he is started on captopril. Which of the following changes in renal function will reduce the blood pressure in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule

questions.solution:
Among the given options, decreased sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule is one of the changes seen due to captopril.

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor. It decreases the levels of angiotensin II thereby decreasing all its physiological effects leading to:

  • Vasodilatation
  • Decreased salt and water reabsorption in the proximal tubules
  • Decreased stimulation of aldosterone which reduces sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules
  • Increased renin secretion due to reduced negative feedback.

Other options:

Option B: Angiotensin II receptors are blocked by ARBs like losartan.

Option C: ACE inhibitors increase renin secretion because the decrease in the levels of angiotensin II reduces the negative feedback on renin release.

Option D: Decreased angiotensin II improves renal blood flow.

questions.text: A young man presented to the casualty with a suspected abdominal injury following a road traffic accident. On examination, his vitals are found to be stable and there is some tenderness in the epigastric and umbilical areas. He was sent for a contrast-enhanced CT scan. Which of the following can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium in him?
questions.solution:
Iodinated contrast can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium in contrast-enhanced CT scan for this patient.

Contrast agents for CT can be divided into:

  • Water-soluble compounds (iodine-containing)
  • Non-water-soluble compounds (barium)

Iodine is the only element that can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium for radiography including angiography and CT. The iodine provides radiopacity. The other elements of the contrast medium act as carriers of iodine which increases the solubility and reduces toxicity. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media include iothalamate, iohexol respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Gadolinium (Gd) is used as a contrast medium for MRI. It contains paramagnetic metal ions that affect the MR signal properties of surrounding tissues. Since gadolinium ion is toxic, it is chelated with DTPA. Hence, Gd-DTPA is the agent used.

Option B: Barium sulphate (BaSO4) is a poorly soluble compound that is used to study the gastrointestinal tract. It is administered orally or rectally, in a finely divided aqueous suspension. It is avoided when there is a suspicion of aspiration, a fistula between the oesophagus and lungs, or perforation of the gastrointestinal tract due to the risk of leakage causing fatal mediastinitis or peritonitis.

Option C: Perflutren, as a microscopic gas bubble is a contrast media used in ultrasound imaging. It is administered intravenously. There are three agents available:

  • Air with galactose and palmitic acid as a surfactant
  • Octa fluoro propane (perflutren) with an albumin shell or a lipid shell
  • Sulphur hexafluoride with a phospholipid shell.

Related Pearl: Classification of iodinated contrast medias:

Types Ionic  Non-ionic
Subtypes  Monomer Dimer Monomer Dimer

Iodine: particle ratio 3:2 6:2 or 3:1 3:1 6:1
Examples

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with vomiting. He was prescribed metoclopramide, following which he developed spasms of facial muscles, difficulty in speech, and torticollis. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the treatment of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has developed symptoms of dystonia due to metoclopramide. Diphenhydramine is used in drug-induced dystonia.

Metoclopramide has dopamine receptor antagonist, 5HT4 agonist, and 5HT3 antagonist properties. It is indicated in patients with gastroparesis and is also used in reducing nausea and vomiting that often accompany GI dysmotility syndromes.

Dopamine receptor antagonist property is responsible for extrapyramidal symptoms. The dystonic reaction is one of the extrapyramidal symptoms. Features include spasms of muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back. It can be treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine.

Other extrapyramidal symptoms include parkinsonian-like symptoms that may occur several weeks after initiation of therapy. It responds to treatment with anticholinergic or antihistaminic drugs and reverses on discontinuation of metoclopramide. Tardive dyskinesia can develop in patients treated for a prolonged period with metoclopramide.

Other options:

Option A: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. It inhibits MAOA and MAOB to prevent the breakdown of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin. It is used in the treatment of major depression. The major adverse effects include weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and hypertensive crisis if taken along with tyramine-containing foods/ beverages.

Option C: Chlorpromazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist and is classified under typical antipsychotics. They are noted to improve the positive symptoms of schizophrenia and acute mania. The major adverse effects are extrapyramidal side effects, sedation, weight gain, hypotension, metabolic adverse effects, and photosensitivity.

Option D: Prochlorperazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist which is used as an anti-emetic. It is mainly used in motion sickness. The main adverse events are extrapyramidal symptoms including dystonia, cardiac effects, and hypotension.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presents with heat intolerance and fine tremors in both her hands for 6 months. She also complains of palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities. Examination revealed a BP of 136/86 mm Hg, tachycardia, and exophthalmos. Which of the statements is true in this patient?

RAIU - Radioactive Iodine Uptake

choices.text: RAIU at 24 hours is below normal

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms point toward hyperthyroidism, and eye findings like exophthalmos are highly suggestive of Graves' disease. In this condition, the serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high, and T3 is high. 

Graves disease: 

It is an autoimmune disease with a strong familial predisposition (50%) and females are at a higher risk with a peak incidence between the ages of 40-60 years. The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is due to stimulatory autoantibodies i.e Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) to TSH-R. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) binds to and activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor resulting in diffuse toxic goiter and therefore, increased T4 and T3 levels. The clinical features include:

Symptoms:

  • Hyperactivity,  irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea,  loss of libido

Signs:

  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goiter
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia
  • Extra thyroidal conditions include ophthalmopathy, dermopathy (pretibial myxedema), thyroid acropachy, gynecomastia, and other manifestations.

Diagnosis:

  • Lab Investigations:
    • T4 and T3 increased due to the stimulating effect of TSI on the TSH receptors.
    • TSH is reduced as increased T4 levels in the blood lead to negative feedback on TRH in the hypothalamus.
    • Elevated TSH-R antibodies- diagnostic
    • Anti-Tg and anti-TPO are seen but nonspecific
  • Radiological investigations:
    • RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal due to increased thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: A patient is posted for esophagectomy for the presence of esophageal carcinoma in the middle third of the esophagus. During the operation, the surgeon performs laparotomy and constructs a gastric tube. After this, he performs a right thoracotomy and removes the tumor. He then anastomoses the remaining part of the esophagus with the stomach in the upper part of the thorax. What is the type of esophagectomy done by the surgeon?
questions.solution:
The resection of a tumor in the middle third of the esophagus by laparotomy and right thoracotomy is called the Ivor Lewis approach. 

In the Ivor Lewis approach, partial esophagectomy and esophagogastric anastomosis are done in the thorax. 

Other approaches in esophagectomy:

  • Orringer approach (option B) is used for tumors in the lower part of the esophagus. The stomach is mobilized through a midline abdominal incision or by laparotomy, and the tumor is removed. The cervical esophagus is mobilized through an incision in the neck, and anastomosis of the remaining part of the esophagus and the stomach is performed. This is a palliative procedure. 
  • McKeown approach (option C) is used for the tumors in the upper part of the esophagus. In this technique, the surgeon performs laparotomy and thoracotomy to remove the tumor. A right-side neck approach is done for the anastomosis between the pharynx and stomach. 

McEvedy approach (option A) is used in the repair of the femoral hernia. The surgeon reaches the site of the hernia via a horizontal incision in the lower part of the abdomen, centered at the lateral edge of the rectus muscle.

Related Pearl: Replacement conduits after esophagectomy

  • Best conduit after esophagectomy – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after carcinoma esophagus resection – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after benign disorders – Colon
  • Best conduit of choice after short segment replacement – Jejunum
  • Gastric conduit is based on right gastric and gastroepiploic arteries
  • Left colon conduit is based on left colic artery
  • The posterior mediastinal route is preferred for placement of conduit as it is the shortest route.

questions.text: You are performing an emergency appendicectomy in a COVID-19 positive patient. After surgery, in which bin would you dispose of the N95 mask?
questions.solution:
The N95 masks used by healthcare workers, while treating COVID-19 positive patients, must be disposed of in the yellow bin.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used
COLOUR OF THE BIN PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT(PPE) OTHER WASTE

  • Goggles
  • Face shield 
  • Splash-proof apron
  • Plastic coverall
  • Hazmat suit
  • Nitrile gloves
  • Used gloves

Laboratory waste

  • Pre-treated viral transport media
  • Plastic vials and cryovials
  • Vacutainers
  • Eppendorf tubes
  • Pipette tips
Yellow Bin
  • Used mask(triple layer mask, N95 mask)
  • Head cover/Cap, Shoe cover
  • Disposable linen gown 
  • Non-plastic/Semi-plastic coverall

 

  • Diapers with feces of immobile COVID 19 patients

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has chronic hypertension since 10 years. He has tried three different drugs A, B, and C to control his hypertension over the years. The graph below shows the relationship between the log[Dose] and the response of three drugs A, B, and C. Which of the following options is true in regards to the drugs' efficacy?
questions.solution:
In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Therefore, Drug C has the least efficacy. Both Drug A and Drug B have the highest efficacy that is the maximum effect produced by the drug. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Thus, in the above image, Drug A is more potent. The potency is Drug A >Drug B> Drug C.(option B)

questions.text: A middle-aged man is posted for an open cholecystectomy. He has a medical history of hypercholesterolemia. The pre-anesthetic evaluation revealed abnormal liver function tests and mild hepatomegaly. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be safely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium can be safely used in this patient with liver disease because of non-hepatic metabolism.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous, non-enzymatic, chemical degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

The metabolites of atracurium and cis-atracurium are monoquaternary acrylate and laudanosine.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

Pancuronium, rocuronium, and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological picture showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), for which CD 117 is the specific marker. 

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach. The tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumor peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anemia (due to blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumor is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumor is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells, along with DOG1.

The prognosis depends on tumor size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used. 

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

Most common Structure/Conditions
Congenital intestinal atresia Imperforate anus
True diverticulum Meckel's diverticulum
Site of ischemia Colon
Site of fistulization Esophagus
Site of GI polyp Colorectum
Malignancy of GI tract Adenocarcinoma colon
Cause of esophagitis Acid reflux
Benign tumor of the esophagus Leiomyoma
Esophageal cancer in India and worldwide Squamous cell carcinoma
Esophageal cancer in Western countries Adenocarcinoma
Type of chronic gastritis Type B gastritis (Helicobacter pylori gastritis)
Malignancy of the stomach Adenocarcinoma
Site of extranodal lymphoma Stomach
Mesenchymal tumor of the stomach Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)
Tumor of small intestine/appendix Carcinoid

 

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy and congested pharynx. Two days later, he develops a maculopapular rash and changes in the tongue and hands as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features given is Kawasaki disease. The image shows strawberry tongue and erythema and edema of the hands. 

Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that predominantly affects coronary arteries. It is commonly seen in childhood. Symptoms include cervical lymphadenopathy, pharyngeal congestion, and maculopapular rash.

For the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease, the patient should have a fever for at least 5 days with any four of the following clinical features:

  • Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival injection
  • Erythema of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa 
  • Edema and erythema of the hands and feet
  • Rash
  • Nonsuppurative cervical lymphadenopathy

Early diagnosis of the disease is important to prevent coronary artery abnormalities.

Intravenous immunoglobulins are the mainstay of treatment. High-dose aspirin can also be given till the fever subsides. 

Other options

Option A- Erythema infectiosum is caused due to the infection of parvovirus B19. It presents with bright red erythema over the cheeks which gives it a slapped cheek appearance. The patients might also develop a maculopapular rash over the extremities.

Option B- Scarlet fever is caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus and presents with fever, exudative pharyngitis, and a bright red rash. The rash appears 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms. It starts on the neck and then extends to the trunk and extremities. The tongue is usually coated and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

Option C- Measles is caused by a paramyxovirus. It presents with fever, rash, exudative conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots. The rash begins on the face and neck and then spreads to the extremities.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vasculitis based on Pathogenesis

Direct infection

Bacterial

Rickettsial

Viral

Spirochetes
Immunologic

Immune complex-mediated

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE); Rheumatoid arthritis, serum sickness

Drugs (penicillin)

Cryoglobulin vasculitis

Polyarteritis nodosa

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) mediated

Wegner’s granulomatosis

Churg–Strauss syndrome

Microscopic polyangiitis°

Directed antibody mediated

Goodpasture-syndrome (anti-GBMAb°

Kawasaki’s disease (anti-endothelial antibodies°)

Cell-mediated

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these two variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a country is best given as __________
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.

Maternal death is defined as:

  • Death of a woman while pregnant.
  • During delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

MMR = (No. of maternal deaths in a given year/ Total no. of live births in the same year) x 100,000

In a developing country like India, maternal mortality is a huge public health issue. The most common causes being postpartum hemorrhage and infections. This mainly occurs because women do not give birth in hospitals or health centres. The main contributor to a decline in maternal mortality has been attributed to a rise in institutional deliveries.

Other important statistics of India:

  • The infant mortality rate in India is 32 per 1000 live births.
  • The crude birth rate is 20.0
  • The crude death rate is 6.2
  • The growth rate is 1.2%
  • According to the latest bulletin, India's MMR declined by 7.3% from 122 in 2015-17 to 113 per 1,00,000 live births in 2018-20

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-year-old child to the pediatrician after the baby developed a high fever and rashes over the body. She says that the baby initially had a very high fever, running nose, and redness of eyes. After 3 days, the fever came down, but the baby started to develop rashes. It initially started on the trunk and then spread to the face, neck, and other parts of the body. On examination, you notice multiple erythematous and maculopapular rashes over the body of the baby. Oral examination reveals lesions at the uvulopalatoglossal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is roseola infantum. The pattern of fever, the timing and pattern of spread of the rashes, and the presence of lesions at the uvulopalatoglossal junction favor the diagnosis.

Roseola infantum (also called sixth disease and exanthem subitum) is an infection caused by the human herpesvirus 6 (HHV- 6)and human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The majority of the cases are caused by HHV-6. 

It is characterized by the abrupt onset of high fever, which may be accompanied by a runny nose, redness of eyes, etc. The fever usually comes down after 3 days followed by the appearance of faint pink or rose-colored nonpruritic morbilliform rash. The rashes first appear in the trunk and then spread to the rest of the body. In a few people, there might also be ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction, which are called Nagayama spots.

Hydration and antipyretics are recommended for the management.

Other options 

Option A: Measles is characterized by prodromal symptoms like fever, running nose conjunctival congestion, etc. On the second day, gray white-colored sand-like lesions appear over the mucosa opposite to the lower second molars. These are called Koplik spots. The rash appears on the 4th day. It first appears behind the ears, along the hairline, and then spreads to the face, neck, and other parts of the body.

Option C: Chickenpox also presents with fever and rash. The rash appears within 24 to 48 hours after the appearance of the fever. It first starts on the trunk and then spreads to the face and other parts of the body. It evolves into clear fluid-filled vesicles, clouded vesicles, and then crusted vesicles. Several skin lesions with different sizes and different stages of evolution can be seen simultaneously.

Option D: Rubella presents with fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy. The pink maculopapular rash first appears on the face and then spreads to trunk and extremities within 24 hours. Enanthem on the soft palate can be observed which are called Forchheimer spots.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with jaundice and pruritus. He has been on treatment for ulcerative colitis for many years. Investigations showed elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. MRCP showed beading in the bile ducts. Biopsy finding reveals the following appearance of the bile duct. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows onion-skin fibrosis surrounding the bile duct which is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis. Beading of the bile ducts seen on MRCP is also suggestive of the diagnosis.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments.

Morphology:

  • Large intrahepatic bile ducts show epithelial injury and chronic inflammation, which is superimposed by neutrophilic infiltrates. The edema and inflammation lead to fibrosis and the development of strictures. The inflammatory injury causes circumferential onion-skin fibrosis. The development of fibrosis around the atrophic lumen eventually leads to obliteration of the duct by a tombstone scar.
  • Small intrahepatic bile ducts are not directly involved by inflammation. However, they exhibit mild injury and prominent ductular reaction due to cholestasis.

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There is diffuse stricturing of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between. 

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency after he injured his arm in a road traffic accident. He was bleeding profusely from his brachial artery. Which of the following suture materials would you use for the repair of the artery?
questions.solution:
Nonabsorbable monofilament suture material like Polypropylene is ideal to repair the brachial artery. 

The vascular anastomosis requires an accurate and watertight closure. Hence it requires a non-absorbable material that can provide tensile strength for a longer period. In addition to this, the material should also be non-braided to avoid platelet adherence to the suture material. Hence, polypropylene which is a non-absorbable monofilament is used for vascular anastomoses.

Important suture materials used in the clinical practice are:

  • Polyglactin (Vicryl)- This is an absorbable suture material and is commonly used in gut anastomoses, biliary anastomoses, and kidney and ureter surgeries.
  • Polygylcaprone (Monocryl)- This is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin
  • Silk- It is a naturally available, non-absorbable suture material. It is used in skin, two-layer bowel anastomosis, and in securing the external drains.
  • Nylon- It is a non-absorbable suture material. It is used in abdominal wall mass closure, hernia repair, and neurosurgery.
  • Polydioxanone - Absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period. 

Silk, a non-absorbable material of biological origin, will fragment with time and lose its strength, and hence should never be used in vascular anastomoses for fear of late fistula formation.
