questions.text: A 24-year-old nulligravid woman is to undergo a hysterosalpingogram to look for uterine anomalies. The gynaecologist chooses Leech-Wilkinson cannula for the procedure. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Instrument 2 is Leech Wilkinson cannula. It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e 9th or 10th day of the cycle).

The patient is pre-medicated with atropine and analgesia to prevent tubal spasm, especially in an apprehensive woman. Then, 10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal block.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility to tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

Contraindications for HSG:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding.
  • Genital tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy.
  • Allergy to the dye.
  • Premenstrual phase
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Other options

Instrument 1 - Rubins cannula - used to introduce dye into the uterine cavity during hysterosalpingography or diagnostic laparoscopy.

Instrument 3 - Karman's cannula. It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.

Instrument 4 - Simpson's uterine sound. It is used to measure the length of uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A primigravida with an adequate pelvis and good contractions goes into active labor. You notice the hand alongside the fetal head as shown below. What should be the immediate next step of management?

choices.text: Gently reposition the hand inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT

questions.solution:
The given scenario of the presentation of the hand alongside the fetal head is suggestive of a compound presentation. Expectant management with observation alone is sufficient.

Contracted pelvis, fetal prematurity, polyhydramnios, and multifetal gestations predispose to this presentation. The most common compound presentation is a hand prolapsing alongside the head.

In most cases, expectant management is enough. With the progression of labour, the prolapsed hand retracts with the descent of the fetal head. If retraction fails and the hand seems to be blocking the head, the prolapsed arm is gently pushed upward and fundal pressure is applied to promote the descent of the head.

If cord prolapse is present or the pelvis is contracted, a caesarean section should be done.

questions.text: Who among the following would require the least amount of inhaled anaesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Among the options, a pregnant woman would require the least amount of anaesthetic agent as pregnancy decreases minimum alveolar concentration (MAC).

MAC of an inhaled anaesthetic agent is the alveolar concentration that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a standardized stimulus (eg. a surgical incision). It is the highest at 6 months of age, after which it declines. After the age of 40, MAC reduces by ~6% per decade.

Higher the MAC, more the anaesthetic that is required. Chronic alcoholics, infants, and cocaine abusers would require a higher amount of anaesthetic agent as MAC would be more compared to normal.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC)

Factors increasing MAC Factors decreasing MAC No change in MAC
Hyperthermia >42°C Acute alcohol intoxication  Hyperthyroidism
Chronic alcohol abuse Hypothermia and hyperthermia up to 42°C Hypothyroidism
Acute amphetamine use  Older age (>6 months MAC decreases 6% per decade)  
Drugs: Cocaine, Ephedrine Chronic amphetamine abuse  
Hypernatremia  Drugs: Opioids, Ketamine, Barbiturates, Benzodiazepines, Sympatholytics   
Young age (<6 months; MAC is maximum at 6 months) Hyponatremia, Hypercalcemia  
  Hypotension  
  Hypercarbia, Hypoxia, Metabolic acidosis  
  Pregnancy

questions.text:
A concerned mother brings her child with the complaints that she gets up at night and walks around the room for around 15-20 minutes. During the episode, she does not respond when spoken to, even though her eyes are open and eventually goes back to bed. Identify the correct statements about this condition.

1. It occurs in the rapid eye movement (REM) phase of sleep
2. It can be secondary to other sleep disorders
3. The patient does not have full consciousness
4. The person is responsible for any criminal actions performed in this state
5. The patient may ingest food during such episodes
questions.solution:
The condition described above is known as somnambulism (sleepwalking), and the correct statements about it are 2, 3, and 5.

Somnambulism (sleepwalking) is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities while unconscious. It occurs in the non-rapid eye movement (NREM) phase of sleep(Stage N3 sleep). 

It is more commonly seen in children between the ages of 4-8 years. It usually resolves after adolescence and is rarely seen in adults. It has a familial pattern and may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk or perform semi-purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty. During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road). Legally, the person is not criminally responsible for his acts carried out during an episode.

Forms of somnambulism include:

  • Sleep-related eating: The individual may ingest food during the episode.
  • Sleep-related sexual behavior (sexsomnia): The individual may engage in sexual activities during the episode

Management includes reassurance, maintenance of safety, and avoiding sleep deprivation. Antidepressants, relaxation techniques, and hypnosis may also be used.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A 24-year-old nulliparous woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) seeks advice for contraception. She expresses a desire to conceive at some point in the future. The medications that she takes regularly are hydroxychloroquine and corticosteroids. Which among the following contraceptives would be ideal for her?
questions.solution:
IUCDs are the ideal mode of contraception for this particular woman.

IUCDS are safe in a woman with SLE with or without antiphospholipid antibodies. They come under the first-tier contraceptive methods, which are the most effective in terms of failure rate and ease of use.

These methods require only minimal user motivation or intervention and have an unintended pregnancy rate less than 2 per 100 women during the first year of use and provide the longest duration of contraception after initiation and require the fewest number of return visits. Although the ideal candidate for an IUCD is a multiparous woman, they are not contraindicated in nulliparous women.

Other Options:

  • Oral pills are usually combined preparations. The contraindication to their use is dependant on the patient factors like severity of heart disease, age of the patient and other comorbidities. Since the patient is a known case of SLE, oral pills should be excluded to minimise the risk of thrombosis.
  • Norplants are first-tier, levonorgestrel-releasing devices, contraindications to which include thrombosis or thromboembolic disorders. Although SLE is not a contraindication, IUCD is preferred over implants, especially if the patient has positive antiphospholipid antibodies to minimise the risk of thrombosis.
  • Condoms are not contraindicated in this woman. But they are third-tier methods and their expected failure rate is 10 to 20 per cent per 100 users in the first year. Hence very less effective than an IUCD.

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: Which among the following antimicrobial agents is B. cepacia resistant to?
questions.solution:
Burkholderia cepacia (B. cepacia) is resistant to cefotetan, a second-generation cephalosporin .

B. cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to :

  • First and second-generation cephalosporins
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Polymyxin
  • Carboxypenicillins

Effective antimicrobials agents against B. cepacia include: 

  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Co-trimoxazole)
  • Meropenem
  • Doxycycline, minocycline
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Ceftazidime

Patients with cystic fibrosis and chronic granulomatous disease are vulnerable to infection with B. cepacia. Cepacia syndrome is a rapidly fatal syndrome of respiratory distress and septicemia in cystic fibrosis patients. It is also a cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-associated infections, and wound infections.

B. cepacia secretes elastase and possesses components of an injectable toxin-secretion system like that of P. aeruginosa. Its lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is more potent than LPS from P. aeruginosa.

Selective media containing colistin are recommended when culturing the sputum of patients with cystic fibrosis. B. cepacia may take 3 days before colonies are visible. It is oxidase-positive, like all members of the Pseudomonadaceae family. 

Related Pearl: List of intrinsic drug resistance in bacteria

 

Organism Intrinsic Drug Resistance

Ampicillin,Amoxicillin,Ertapenem,Trimethoprim,Chloramphenicol
Pseudomonas aeruginosa Ampicillin,Amoxicillin-Clavulanate,Ceftriaxone,Ertapenem,Tetracyclines/Tigecyclines, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole,Chloramphenicol
Bacteroides fragilis Aminoglycosides,Ampicillin

Gram negative bacteria Vancomycin
Klebsiella pneumoniae Ampicillin
Enterobacter Ampicillin
Aerobic bacteria Metronidazole
Lactobacillus & Leuconostoc Vancomycin
Burkholderia Polymyxins and aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and decreased vision over his right eye. He gives a history of accidental exposure with a cleaning agent that contains ammonia. Ocular examination finding is given below. According to the Roper-Hall system, what is the grade of chemical injury?
questions.solution:
The image shows a grade II chemical injury. There is limbal ischaemia in the lower left quadrant involving <1/3 of the limbus and a hazy cornea with visible iris details.

The Roper–Hall system is used for the classification of chemical injuries to the eye.

Grade Limbal ischemia Cornea Iris Prognosis
I Absent Clear Visible Excellent
II <1/3 of limbus Hazy Visible Good
III 1/3 - 1/2 of limbus  Hazy Obscured Guarded
IV >1/2 limbus Opaque Obscured Poor

Chemical injuries to the eye:

  • Alkali burns are twice as common as acid burns.
  • Alkalis tend to penetrate more deeply than acids, as the latter coagulate surface proteins, forming a protective barrier.
  • Most commonly involved alkalis are ammonia, sodium hydroxide, and lime.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman complains of frequent headaches. On ophthalmic examination, she was found to have an  intra ocular pressure of 20 mm Hg. Her previous recorded values of intra ocular pressure were 18 mm Hg and 20 mm Hg. The patient is found to have cup disc ratio of more than 0.6, gonioscopy showed open angle, visual field testing showed Siedel scotoma. What is this condition is known as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the all the features of primary open angle glaucoma with an intra ocular pressure of less than 21 mm Hg. This condition is known as normal tension glaucoma.

Other options:

Option A- Primary open angle glaucoma (POAG)- The following features are needed to diagnose POAG:

  • An intraocular pressure of more than 21 mm Hg on more than one occasion.
  • The presence of optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucoma:
    • A cup:disc ratio of more than 0.5
    • An asymmetry between the cup:disc ratio of two eyes of more than 0.2
    • Narrowing, notching or pallor of the neuroretinal rim
    • Disc haemorrhages and abnormalities of the blood vessels suggesting enlargement of the optic cup
  • Visual field changes consistent with glaucoma
  • Defects in the retinal nerve fibre layer

Option B- Primary open angle glaucoma suspect- Patients with changes of optic nerve head suggestive of glaucoma but with

  • IOP leass than 21 mm Hg
  • No visual field changes

Option C- Ocular hypertension- Individuals with IOP more than 21 mm Hg physiologically but with

  • No optic nerve head abnormalities
  • No visual field changes

questions.text: Identify the technique of tubal sterilization depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
The sterilization procedure which is shown in the above image is the Pomeroy technique.

It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation. 

The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. The middle portion is formed into a loop and tied at the base with catgut and excised. If desired, a reversal of sterilization is possible.

 

Other options

Option A- Kroener's method refers to fimbriectomy. It is done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by resection.

Option B- In Irving's procedure the mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion excised. The distal end is buried in the broad ligament and the proximal end is buried in the myometrium. It is a reliable method but irreversible, and requires a laparotomy incision.

Option D- In Uchida's method, the tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, and then excised. The proximal end of the fallopian tube is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The potential for tuboplasty is preserved due to minimal excision of the tube.

questions.text: A newborn baby was brought to the NICU because he was lethargic and unable to take feeds. A bruit is heard over the anterior fontanelle.  The baby was admitted and further investigations revealed high output cardiac failure. The baby’s MR angiography is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and MR angiograph point to a diagnosis of Vein of Galen malformation. The MR angiograph shows an enlarged midline venous structure, with multiple arteriovenous communications leading to aneurysmal dilatation.

The vein of Galen malformation is the most common antenatally-diagnosed intracranial vascular malformation. Although named the vein of Galen malformation, the malformation is actually from an embryonic precursor- the median vein of the prosencephalon and is also known as the median prosencephalic arteriovenous fistula.

In AV shunts, blood flows directly from artery to vein, leading to an increased venous return to the heart and high-output heart failure. On examination, a typical asymmetric systolic-diastolic bruit can be auscultated over the anterior fontanel or eyeballs.

Infants and children will have less shunting and may present with hydrocephalus. Older children may have headaches and seizures and are more likely to develop intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Complications:

  • Worsening of the vascular steal phenomenon
  • Thrombosis of the vein of Galen
  • Rupture of the vein
  • Worsening of cardiac failure with multiorgan involvement.

Management includes early neurosurgical involvement, with embolization of the feeder vessels.

Other options:

Option B: Dandy walker syndrome- Foramen Magendie fails to open resulting in the ballooning of the posterior wall of the fourth ventricle and cyst formation in the posterior fossa

Option C: Arnold Chiari malformation- Displacement of the brainstem and cerebellum in the spinal canal 

Option D: Sturge weber syndrome- Triad of a port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angioma, and glaucoma

The formation of the Vein of Galen:

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presented with abdominal pain and hematemesis. He has been taking antacids for heartburn for the last three years. He was stabilized. Endoscopy revealed a bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum near the pylorus. Which of the following vessels is most likely to be the source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of upper gastrointestinal bleeding probably due to peptic ulcer disease. The vessel most likely to be the source of bleeding is the gastroduodenal artery.

Peptic ulcers include duodenal and gastric ulcers of which duodenal ulcers are more common. 

The common sites are the first part of the duodenum and the lesser curvature of the stomach especially incisura angularis respectively.

Risk factors include H.pylori infection, NSAID intake, and cigarette smoking.

Features of a duodenal ulcer include bleeding and perforation. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, leading to hematemesis and melena. Perforation is common with anterior duodenal ulcers.

Gastric ulcer also tends to bleed and perforate. They are much larger than duodenal ulcers.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient on ART with zidovudine, lamivudine, and indinavir develops pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs should be avoided in him?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin should be avoided as it is a potent inducer of CYP enzymes including CYPs 1A2, 3A4, 2C9, and 2C19, which in turn can induce the metabolism of indinavir and results in therapeutic failure of ART.

Rifabutin causes the least induction of cytochrome enzymes and is therefore preferred in HIV patients who are on protease inhibitors/NNRTIs.

Cytochrome enzyme-inducing potency of rifamycins is: rifampicin > rifapentine > rifabutin.

Note: 

Cytochrome p-450 inducers Cytochrome p-450 inhibitors
  • Barbiturates
  • Carbamazepine
  • Rifampin
  • Phenytoin
  • Aminoglutethimide
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Chronic alcoholism
  • Macrolide antibiotics
  • Azole antifungals
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Omeprazole
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
  • HIV protease inhibitors
  • Cimetidine
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Metronidazole

Related Pearl: Cytochrome enzyme inducing potency of Rifamycins

  • Rifampicin: Highest
  • Rifapentine: Intermediate
  • Rifabutin: Least

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with nausea and vomiting. She says that she has generalized weakness and fatigability for 2 months. She also complains of frequent episodes of giddiness. Her blood pressure was 90/70 mm Hg. Clinical examination revealed hyperpigmentation of her arms, face, knuckles, and knees. Investigations revealed hyperkalemia and hyponatremia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of long-standing weakness, fatigability, nausea, vomiting, hyperpigmentation, and hypotension, along with hyperkalemia and hyponatremia, are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency, as seen in Addison's disease.

Addison's disease is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis. It may also result from the destruction of the adrenal cortex due to hemorrhage, infection, or infiltration.

The symptoms of adrenal insufficiency are as follows:

  • Glucocorticoid deficiency leads to:
    • Fatigue, lack of energy
    • Weight loss, anorexia
    • Myalgia
    • Hypoglycemia 
    • Low blood pressure, postural hypotension
  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to:
    • Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
    • Dizziness, postural hypotension
    • Low blood pressure, postural hypotension
    • Hyponatremia
    • Hyperkalemia
  • Adrenal androgen deficiency leads to dry and itchy skin, loss of libido 
  • The hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas results from excess ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) secretion, which occurs in response to decreased adrenal cortical hormones.

Other options:

Option A: Cushing syndrome results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It presents with weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Other clinical features include thin brittle skin with easy bruisability, purple stretch marks, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and osteopenia.

Option C: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is caused by mutations affecting glucocorticoid synthesis. It presents with glucocorticoid deficiency. It is present in the neonatal period or early childhood.

Option D: Conn syndrome refers to primary hyperaldosteronism. It usually results from an aldosterone-secreting adenoma. Excess aldosterone leads to increased sodium and water retention and potassium excretion, resulting in hypokalemia, volume expansion, and hypertension.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: A 30 year old woman has high BMI. She tries to lose weight by intermittent fasting. She has fasted for the past 12 hours and is now feeling very hungry. Which of the following is true about the levels of appetite regulating hormones at this stage?

choices.text: High levels of leptin that continue increasing

questions.solution:
This patient will have high levels of ghrelin at this given stage.

Ghrelin, the hunger hormone is produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic glands of the stomach. It increases food intake. Its levels increase during fasting, peaks just before the beginning of food intake or when the person is expecting a meal. The levels fall within 1 hour of the start of feeding.

Other options:

Option A- Neuropeptide Y stimulates appetite, hence this patient, who is now very hungry, will have high levels of NPY at this time.

Option B- Leptin levels are high in patients with obesity. This can decrease by 60 to 70% by 48 hours of fasting. So, it will not be increasing

Option C- Cholecystokinin is a short-acting hormone that is released in response to feeding. It inhibits appetite and decreases food intake to prevent overeating. Its levels are low during fasting and rise immediately after food intake.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins constitutes a part of the acyl carrier protein?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that constitutes a part of the acyl carrier protein is pantothenic acid.

Fatty acids are synthesized by the fatty acid synthase enzyme complex. The individual enzymes required for fatty acid synthesis are linked in this multienzyme polypeptide complex that consists of an acyl carrier protein (ACP). ACP contains vitamin B5/pantothenic acid.

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol. It involves the formation of palmitate from acetyl-CoA. This process occurs in the liver, kidney, brain, lung, breast, and adipose tissue. Acetyl-CoA and CO2 act as the substrate and palmitate is the end product.

The image given below shows the steps involved in fatty acid synthesis.

Pantothenic acid/vitamin B5 constitutes a part of the coenzyme A, which functions in the transfer of acyl groups.

Pantothenic acid as coenzyme A is involved in:

  • Fatty acid oxidation
  • TCA cycle (succinyl CoA and acetyl CoA)
  • Cholesterol synthesis (HMG CoA)
  • Acetylation reactions

The intestinal gut flora synthesizes vitamin B5 and hence deficiency is rare. Gopalan's burning foot syndrome is a rare disorder that occurs due to deficiency in pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) and the clinical features include paresthesia (burning type of pain as the name suggests) in lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbance.

Elongating fatty acids 12-carbons and longer.

Utilizes fatty acids derived from de novo lipogenesis, as well as fatty acids derived from the diet.

questions.text: A group of scientists are studying gastric cancer.  They extract DNA from the cell and cleave it using a restriction enzyme. They separate the DNA fragments by running them on an electrophoresis gel. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose paper and the gene of interest is isolated by exposing it to labeled DNA probe. Which of the following laboratory techniques does this describe?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes the Southern blot. This technique is used to detect mutations in DNA.

Procedure:

DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe (DNA, RNA, or oligonucleotides).

Variants of Southern blot are:

  • Northern blot- It is similar to Southern blot except that the sample is a mixture of mRNA molecules that are separated by electrophoresis. It is then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with a radiolabeled probe.
  • Western blot (also called immunoblots)- It is also similar to southern blots, except that the proteins are taken as samples and the probe is labeled antibody.

A polymerase chain reaction is a technique to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It uses DNA polymerases to amplify the targeted portions of the DNA.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with complaints of redness and irritation of both eyes since 1 week. On examination, the following findings were observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image and the history suggest angular conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis characterized by mild inflammation limited to the conjunctiva and the lid margins near the angles. It is often accompanied by maceration of the surrounding skin.

The most common causative organism is Moraxella Axenfeld, which is responsible for the characteristic appearance of bacilli placed end to end, leading to the alternative name of diplobacillary conjunctivitis.

The source of infection is typically the nasal tract of healthy individuals or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs.

Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation, discomfort, a history of dirty-white foamy discharge collection at the angles, and redness in the corner of the eyes.

Clinical signs of angular conjunctivitis include hyperemia (redness) of the bulbar conjunctiva near the canthi (corners of the eyes), hyperemia of the lid margins near the angles, skin irritation around the angles, and the presence of foamy mucopurulent discharge at the angles.

Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide inhibits proteolytic enzymes.

Other options: Small, obligate intracellular, Gram-negative bacteria.

Option B: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornavirus namely enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus. It is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis. Patients present with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling. On examination conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid edema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy.

Option C: Chlamydia are obligate intracellular organisms that do not grow on standard culture media such as blood agar. These organisms have two distinct forms: the extracellular elementary body, which is the infectious form, and the intracellular reticulate body, which forms inclusion bodies that can be visualized using iodine or Giemsa stain. Trachoma is caused by serovars A, B, and C of Chlamydia. In newborns born to infected mothers, Chlamydia can cause neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis.

Option D: Gonococcal conjunctivitis presents in the first week of life. The baby would have severe eyelid edema and purulent discharge. If allowed to progress, can rapidly cause corneal ulceration. It should be treated using third-generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: A 4-years-old child is brought to the primary health center with a history of 4 episodes of loose stools for the past 1 day. The mother says that the stool is watery and does not contain blood. On examination, you see that the child is irritable. His eyes, tongue, and mouth are moist. On offering water he drinks normally and does not appear thirsty. On pinching the skin, the skin goes back very quickly. What will you advise the mother regarding the treatment of her child?

choices.text: Give 25-50 mL of ORS after each loose stool
Give 50-100 mL of ORS after each loose stool
Give 100-200 mL of ORS after each loose stool
Give 250-300 mL of ORS after each loose stool

questions.solution:
The child has loose stools and is irritable. His eyes, tongue, and mouth are moist, he does not appear thirsty and the skin pinch is normal. This indicates that there is no dehydration in the child. Since the age of the child is 4 years, the child should be given 100-200 mL of ORS after each loose stool.

Management of no dehydration in the child

After each loose stool, the child should be provided ORS according to the age 

Age amount of ORS to be given after each loose stool
<24 months 50-100mL
2-10 years 100-200 mL
>10 years As much as the child asks for

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of nose-bleeds. She also complains of frequent episodes of headache and fever. The following test is positive in this patient. Which of the given findings is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Cottle’s test which is positive in patients with deviated nasal septum. Septal perforation is not associated with DNS. Septal perforation usually occurs as a consequence of septal abscess.

Cottle's test- In this test, the cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.

DNS is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction- Deviated nasal septum may lead to obstruction of the nasal cavity at different levels based on the type of deviation:
    • Vestibular- due to caudal septal dislocation, synechiae or stenosis
    • At the nasal valve- due to synechiae, usually post rhinoplasty
    • Attic (along the upper part of nasal septum)- due to high septal deviation
    • Turbinal- due to hypertrophic turbinates or concha bullosa
    • Choanal- due to choanal atresia or a choanal polyp
  • Chronic sinusitis- Deviated septum causes obstruction to the ostia of the sinuses. This causes poor ventilation of the sinuses leading to sinusitis.
  • Headache- Deviated septum or the spur may press on the lateral wall of the nose leading to pressure headache. Headache can also be due to sinusitis.
  • Turbinate hypertrophy- Because of chronic sinusitis
  • Middle ear infection
  • Epistaxis- There is drying of the mucosa over the deviated septum due to air currents. This leads to the formation of crusts which, on removal, cause epistaxis.
  • Anosmia- reduced airflow may lead to anosmia
  • External deformity- External deformities of the septum may be seen due to deviation of the cartilaginous or the bony part of the nasal septum. Deformity of the tip or columella may also be seen.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man, with no known medical illness, came for a routine medical check-up. His chest radiograph is presented to you. Identify the incorrect statement with respect to the X-ray shown below.

choices.text: The structure marked number 2 is the right ventricular border
The structure marked 1 is the trachea
The structure marked 3 is the left ventricular border
The structure marked 4 is the aortic arch

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option A because the structure marked as 2 is the right atrial border (not the right ventricular border). The given image is posteroanterior (PA) view of a normal chest x-ray. Structures marked in the X-Ray are as follows:

  1. Trachea
  2. Right atrial border
  3. Left ventricular border
  4. Aortic arch

Chest x-rays can be described as posteroanterior (PA) or anteroposterior (AP) views. This indicates the direction in which the x-ray beam traverses from the patient to the detector.

PA view means that the x-ray beam enters from the posterior aspect of the patient and exits anteriorly to reach the film.

AP view means that the x-ray beam enters the patient from the anterior aspect and exits from the posterior aspect, reaching the film.

A left lateral decubitus view is one taken with the patient’s left side down.

questions.text: Image of insulin regimen with different preparations of insulin is given below. The yellow curve in the image indicates
questions.solution:
The yellow curve in the image has a duration of action of around 11- 12 hours. Therefore, it indicates NPH insulin.

The image shows an insulin regimen consisting of a twice-daily injection of NPH insulin (yellow line) providing basal insulin coverage and regular insulin (blue dashed line) or an insulin analog (glulisine, apart, and lispro in red) providing mealtime insulin coverage.

Duration of NPH insulin is around 10-16 hours, insulin degludec is 24-42 hours, regular insulin is 4-6 hours and insulin glulisine is around 3-4 hours.

Other commonly used insulin regimens are shown in the following image. The letter B indicates breakfast, L indicates lunch, S indicates supper and HS indicates bedtime.

The above image shows multiple-component insulin regimen consisting of long-acting insulin (degludec, determir, or glargine), which are denoted by green color to provide basal insulin coverage and three shots of short-acting insulin (glulisine, lispro, or insulin aspart), indicated in red color, to provide glycemic coverage for each meal.

The above image shows the insulin level attained following subcutaneous insulin (short-acting insulin analogue) by an insulin pump programmed to deliver different basal rates. At each meal, an insulin bolus is delivered.

questions.text: During the final hectic weeks of her clinical internship, a 24-year-old medical student, in good health, frequently found herself feeling unreal and detached from her own body like she is in a dream.   The episodes last a few minutes, resolving spontaneously. Her medical and surgical history are unremarkable and her toxicology screen comes back negative, prompting suspicion of a derealisation disorder. The presence of which of the following would make a diagnosis of Depersonalization/ Derealization Disorder unviable?
questions.solution:
One of the DSM-V diagnostic criterion for the diagnosis of depersonalization/derealisation disorder is that the disturbance is not better explained by/attributable to another mental disorder, such as posttraumatic stress disorder. History of recent near-death experience indicates a possible post-traumatic stress disorder, making the diagnosis of depersonalization disorder unviable.

Depersonalization is an experience of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer with respect to one’s thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions. Derealization refers to the experiences of unreality or detachment with respect to the surroundings (Eg - objects appear unreal, people seem lifeless).

Depersonalization/derealisation experiences commonly occur after a life-threatening trauma (It is not a diagnostic criterion for the disorder). 

It is also experienced by seizure and migraine patients, use of psychedelic drugs, or experienced as a symptom of mood, psychotic, or anxiety disorders. It occurs in the normal population as well. These experiences remit after the removal from the trauma, drug, or following the treatment of the underlying condition.

To diagnose it as depersonalization/derealization disorder, DSM-V lists the following criteria:

  • The presence of persistent or recurrent experiences of depersonalization, derealization, or both.
  • Intact reality testing, during the episodes.
  • The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  • The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, medication) or another medical condition(e.g., seizures). 
  • The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as schizophrenia, panic disorder, major depressive disorder, acute stress disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, or another dissociative disorder.

Depersonalization disorder may have an episodic, relapsing and remitting, or chronic course. Many patients have severe impairment in occupational, social, and personal func­tioning.

Management:

  • SSRIs like fluoxetine may be helpful
  • Psychotherapy
  • Stress management and distraction techniques, relax­ation training, and physical exercise may also be helpful.

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

 

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A young boy consumed the fruits of this plant and chewed its seeds. All of the following symptoms will be seen in this boy except?
questions.solution:
The plant shown in the image is Ricinus communis. Ingestion of seeds of this plant leads to all the above mentioned symptoms but does not cause blisters on the skin. 

The given image shows rose-red softly spiny fruits which are suggestive of Ricinus communis. The entire plant is poisonous but the seeds are the most poisonous. The poisonous component is the toxalbumin ricin. It is a glycoprotein that blocks protein synthesis. 

The seeds contain the highest level of ricin. The fatal dose is 5 to 10 seeds or 50-100µ ricin.

Ricinous poisoning causes the following symptoms:

  • Burning of oral mucosa, salivation
  • Nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain
  • Bloody diarrhoea 
  • Muscle cramps
  • Drowsiness, convulsions
  • Delirium
  • Dehydration, collapse, and death

Treatment includes gastric lavage, activated charcoal, and symptomatic management.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing. He has had such symptoms on and off since childhood and his symptoms worsen in the spring and when he goes out of the house. He is given a drug that has the action of leukotriene receptor antagonism for his condition. Which among the following drugs is the drug given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. 

The leukotrienes are proinflammatory mediators produced from arachidonic acid via the 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO) pathway. These drugs are competitive antagonists of the cys LT1 receptor and hence decrease bronchoconstriction, airway mucus secretion, increased vascular permeability, and recruitment of eosinophil.

This patient with symptoms of runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing along with worsening of his symptoms in spring and outside environment strongly suggests allergic rhinitis as the diagnosis.

Uses: 

Montelukast and Zafirlukast are indicated for the treatment of allergic rhinitis. Antileukotrienes are useful in preventing exercise-induced asthma. They act mainly by inhibiting bronchoconstriction.

In some patients, anti leukotriene agents are effective as monotherapy in the treatment of mild to moderate persistent asthma, although the mean efficacy of anti leukotriene agents is lower than that of inhaled glucocorticoids (IGCs). Thus, IGCs are preferred first-line controller agents, and anti leukotriene agents are considered alternatives, particularly in patients who have difficulty with adherence or inhaler technique.

Adverse effects:

  • Zileuton, montelukast, and zafirlukast are all associated with rare cases of hepatic dysfunction. Hence, liver function tests should be monitored during the course of their therapy.
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome consisting of vasculitis with eosinophilia is associated with the use of montelukast and zafirlukast. 

Other options:

Option A- Ketotifen is a mast cell stabilizer used for the management of bronchial asthma and allergic disorders such as atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis/conjunctivitis, and chronic urticaria. Oral ketotifen possesses both anti-mediator and mast cell-stabilizing properties.

Option B- Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer. It inhibits the release of mediators of inflammation, including histamine and leukotrienes, from the mast cells that are induced by reactive antigens that result in allergic symptoms and bronchoconstriction.

Option D- Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor and helps to reduce inflammation, edema, mucus secretion, and bronchoconstriction in the airways.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has moderate hypertension for the past few years. The given image shows a section of a small blood vessel of this patient. What is the finding seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyaline arteriolosclerosis. Homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with narrowing of the lumen is seen in the above slide.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis, which is the thickening of the vessel wall with loss of its elasticity. It has two variants:

  • Hyaline arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in chronic hypertension. Chronic changes in blood pressure damage the vessel wall leading to the deposition of plasma proteins and matrix. On microscopy, it appears as a homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with the narrowing of the lumen. It is also seen in elderly patients (normotensive or hypertensive) and diabetes mellitus.
  • Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in severe hypertension. Microscopy shows a characteristic concentric, laminated (onion peel appearance) thickening of the vessel wall with luminal narrowing. It is the characteristic vascular lesion of severe hypertension.

In medium and large vessels it can lead to degenerative changes and can cause aortic dissection and cerebrovascular hemorrhage.

The image below shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

Monckeberg medial sclerosis is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically involving the internal elastic lamina. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is usually an incidental finding. 

The following image shows Monckeberg medial sclerosis of an artery.

Atherosclerotic plaque is yellow-tan that is raised above the vessel wall. It occurs due to intimal thickening and lipid accumulation. The lumen appears irregular. The given image shows atherosclerosis:

Related Pearl: Onion Skin Appearance in Pathology

Onion skin appearance:

A pattern characterised by concentric laminations of differing radiologic or histologic densities. It is seen in:

  1. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: Onion skin fibrosis
  2. Castleman disease: Onion skin appearance of Mantle zone lymphocytes
  3. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Onion skin lesions in spleen
  4. Thrombotic thrombocytopenia purpura (TTP): Onion skinning of renal arteries and arterioles
  5. Ewing sarcoma: Laminated periosteal reaction (onion skin)
  6. Malignant hypertension: Onion skin lesion/ Hyperplastic arteriolitis
  7. Tay–Sach's disease: Whorled arrangement (onion skin) of cytoplasmic inclusions within lysosomes of ganglion cells under electron microscopy
  8. Lyme arthritis: Onion skin thickening of the arterial wall
  9. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) and Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease: Onion bulb formation of proliferated Schwann cells around the axon due to recurrent demyelination and remyelination

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought in by her mother. On examination, the child appears emaciated and her feet and ankles show an extensive, pruritic maculopapular rash. Blood examination reveals a hemoglobin of 6 g/dL and the peripheral blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. Identify the egg belonging to the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of chronic hookworm infection (caused by A. duodenale or N. americanus) and image 4 shows the hookworm egg.

Features of the hookworm egg:

  • Oval/ elliptical with a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.
  • Not bile stained.
  • Floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • Contains a segmented ovum, usually with 4-8 blastomeres when passed in the faeces.
  • A clear space lies between the segmented ovum and the shell.

Filariform larvae penetrate the skin when a person walks barefoot on soil containing larvae, causing a pruritic maculopapular rash at the site of entry (Ground itch). Common sites of entry include the skin between the toes, the dorsum of the foot and the medial part of the sole. It can occasionally lead to a creeping eruption along the path traversed by the larvae, similar to cutaneous larva migrans.

The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 

A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss. 

Diagnosis:

  • Demonstration of characteristic hookworm eggs in feces by direct wet microscopy. The modified Kato-Katz smear technique is useful for the quantitative estimation of eggs in the stool. 20 eggs or more are associated with anemia.
  • Stool culture: Harada-Mori method of stool culture demonstrates filariform larvae which differentiate A. duodenale and N. americanus.
  • Lab investigations characteristically show hypochromic microcytic anaemia, occasionally with eosinophilia or hypoalbuminemia.

Treatment:

  • Anthelmintic drugs- albendazole and mebendazole.
  • Iron replacement.
  • Nutritional support.

Other options:

Option A: Eggs of Ascaris can be fertilized or unfertilized. Unfertilized eggs have a thinner shell, containing a small atrophied ovum with a mass of disorganized granules. Fertilized eggs are always bile-stained, are usually surrounded by a 3 layer membrane, and contain a large unsegmented ovum. Infection is by swallowing fertilized eggs that contain the larvae.

Option B: Eggs of Strongyloides hatch out to rhabditiform larva as soon as they are laid, and are therefore not seen in the stool. Infection occurs when larvae penetrate the skin while walking, or by autoinfection.

Option C: Eggs of Enterobius are colourless, but have a characteristic plano-convex shape, with a double-layered membrane, and contain a tadpole-shaped embryo. Swallowing eggs by autoinfection or contaminated fingers is the mode of infection.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and bruising around the eyes.  A biopsy image of the adrenal gland tumor picked up on an abdominal CT scan is shown below. Amplification of which of the following oncogenes is associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the biopsy are diagnostic of neuroblastoma, in which amplification of the N-MYC gene is seen. 

Neuroblastoma is a tumor arising from the neural crest cells. It is the most common intraabdominal tumor in children. It is associated with the amplification of the N-MYC protooncogene and tumor cell DNA content. These genetic characteristics have prognostic importance. The most common site of occurrence is the adrenal gland. 

Most cases are diagnosed before the age of five. Clinical features of the disease, vary depending on the site of the location of the tumor. It can present as an abdominal mass, periorbital ecchymoses, hypertension, and Horner syndrome. It is also associated with central hypoventilation syndrome, Hirschsprung disease, and neurofibromatosis type 1. 

CT scan will show the presence of tumor calcifications. A biopsy reveals the presence of small round blue cells with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. 

 

Other examples of small, round blue cell tumours include: 

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

The treatment modality is chosen based on the patient age and tumor stage. Cytogenetic and molecular features are used to determine the treatment risk group and prognosis for each case. 

Other options:

Option B: C-MYC translocation is associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

Option C: H-RAS point mutations can cause bladder and kidney tumors.

Option D: Point mutations in K-RAS oncogene can result in colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.solution:
The toxin responsible for the abnormal posturing shown in the image is tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani. It acts by causing presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release. 

Tetanospasmin, after secretion by the bacterium is cleaved into two peptides linked by a disulphide bond. The larger peptide diffuses to terminals of neurons and migrates by the retrograde axonal transport system to the spinal cord and brainstem. It diffuses to the glycinergic interneurons and GABA secreting neurons there. The smaller peptide degrades synaptobrevin and blocks the release of the inhibitory glycine and GABA. This results in hyperreflexia, muscle spasms, and spastic paralysis. Even small amounts of the toxin can be lethal.

The incubation period of C. tetani ranges from 4-5 days up to 3 weeks. Muscle spasms usually involve the area of injury first and then the muscles of the jaw causing trismus or lockjaw. Gradually, other voluntary muscles become involved, resulting in tonic spasms. Any external stimulus can precipitate a tetanic generalized muscle spasm. The patient is conscious but may be in pain. Death usually results from respiratory paralysis.

Other options: Proteolysis of target SNARE proteins in the neurons inhibits the release of Ach at the synapse - this is the mechanism of action of Botulinum toxin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic with a chronic dry, nagging cough associated with weakness and fatigue for 1 year. He has worked in the stone-cutting industry for 20 years and complains that his efficiency at work has decreased drastically over the years. On examination, his vitals are stable. His chest x-ray shows bilateral eggshell calcification in the hilar region.  Histopathology of the lung shows the following.  Which of the following is the patient at increased risk for, compared to the general population?
questions.solution:
The clinical, radiological and histopathological features in this patient are suggestive of Silicosis. It causes pulmonary alveolar macrophage dysfunction, and hence, patients with silicosis have a higher risk of developing lung infections from organisms like M. Tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria, and fungi.

In this scenario, the key features suggestive of silicosis are:

  • A man who has worked in the stone-cutting industry (exposure to silica) for 20 years (long-term exposure)
  • Symptoms of chronic dry, nagging cough
  • CXR findings of eggshell calcification
  • Histological findings of silicotic nodules characterised by concentrically arranged hyalinised collagen fibres surrounding an amorphous centre in the hilar lymph nodes and the upper zones of the lungs.

Other options:

Pleural effusion, bronchogenic carcinoma, and mesothelioma are associated with asbestosis.

Asbestosis - X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. HRCT shows subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Risk of bronchogenic carcinoma > mesothelioma in asbestosis.
