Related Pearl: Eggshell calcification of lymph node on chest X-ray

Eggshell calcification refers to fine calcification seen at the periphery of a lymph node. Causes are -

  • Silicosis (most common)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Post-irradiation lymphoma
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Tuberculosis

questions.text: Attenuation reflex is an involuntary contraction of the muscles in the middle ear, in response to loud sounds. The muscles responsible for this reflex are mainly supplied by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Stapedius and tensor tympani muscles are responsible for the attenuation reflex. They are supplied by facial and trigeminal nerves respectively.

The attenuation reflex is a protective mechanism to protect the cochlea from damage due to loud sounds. Whenever a loud sound is transmitted across the ossicular system, there is a contraction of the stapedius and tensor tympani muscles. The tensor tympani muscle pulls the handle of the malleus while the stapedius muscle pulls the stapes. This decreases the conduction of the sound.

This attenuation reflex can reduce the intensity of lower-frequency sound transmission by 30 to 40 decibels

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a painless swelling near the angle of his jaw. He gives a history of nasal obstruction and occasional epistaxis. He also complains of decreased hearing ability. On performing Rinne and Weber’s tests, conductive hearing loss is seen on the same side as the swelling. Examination of the swelling revealed a single enlarged lymph node, 5 cm in size. Careful examination also revealed squint. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with cranial nerve involvement (indicating stage IV). The treatment of choice in this condition is radiotherapy + chemotherapy.

The given scenario describes nasal (obstruction and epistaxis), otologic (conductive hearing loss) and ophthalmic symptoms (squint) with cervical lymphadenopathy. This set of symptoms in an elderly man is highly suggestive of a tumor in the nasopharynx, nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma usually originates from the nasopharynx in the fossa of Rossenmuller. It presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal- Nasal obstruction due to blockage of the choana or the nasal cavity, denasal speech, nasal discharge, epistaxis.
  • Otologic- Obstruction of the eustachian tube leads to unilateral conductive hearing loss, serous or suppurative otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmologic- These symptoms occur due to the involvement of cranial nerves.
    • Squint and diplopia- involvement of cranial nerve VI.
    • Facial pain and reduced corneal reflex- cranial nerve V.
    • Exophthalmos and blindness- cranial nerve II.
  • Cervical node metastasis- Usually between the angle of jaw and the mastoid.
  • Distant metastasis- to bone, liver, lung, etc.

The treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Radiotherapy for stages I and II.
  • Radiotherapy + chemotherapy for stages III and IV.
  • Radical neck dissection can be done in case of recurrent or residual disease.

TNM staging of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is given below:

  • T1 Tumour confined to the nasopharynx 
  • T2 Tumour extends to soft tissues of oropharynx and/or nasal fossa
    • T2a without parapharyngeal extension
    • T2b with parapharyngeal extension
  • T3 Tumour invades bony structures and/or paranasal sinuses 
  • T4 Tumour with intracranial extension and/or involvement of cranial nerves, infratemporal fossa, hypopharynx or orbit or masticator space 

     Regional lymph nodes:

  • NX Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
  • N0 No regional lymph node metastasis 
  • N1 Unilateral metastasis in lymph node(s), 6 cm or less in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa
  • N2 Bilateral metastasis in lymph nodes, 6 cm or less in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa.
  • N3 Metastasis in a lymph node(s)
    • N3a Greater than 6 cm in dimension
    • N3b In the supraclavicular fossa

     Metastasis:

  • MX Distant metastasis cannot be assessed
  • M0 No distant metastasis
  • M1 Distant metastasis

     Stage grouping:

Stage T N M
0  Tis  N0  M0
I  T1 N0  M0
IIA  T2a  N0  M0
IIB   T1  N1 M0
  T2 N1 M0
  T2a N1 M0
  T2b N0, N1 M0
III T1 N2 M0
  T2a, T2b N2 M0
  T3 N0, N1, N2 M0
IVA T4 N0, N1, N2 M0
IVB Any T N3  
IVC Any T Any N M1

questions.text: A 27-year-old female comes to your clinic with a black eye and multiple bruises on her arms and legs. She is visibly upset and confides in you that she is a victim of domestic abuse. She says her husband has become very jealous and insecure, accuses her of cheating on him, and beats her as a result of his suspicions. He constantly checks her phone and logs into her social media account surreptitiously, on multiple occasions. She has tried her best to convince him that she has not been unfaithful to him and has reassured him repeatedly. The husband is most likely suffering from _____________
questions.solution:
The husband is most likely suffering from delusions of infidelity/ conjugal paranoia.

Delusions of infidelity limited to the spouse is called conjugal paranoia while the eponym Othello syndrome is used to describe morbid jealousy that can arise from multiple
concerns.

Othello syndrome is a psychiatric condition marked by morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. The person holds an abnormal belief that their spouse or partner is being unfaithful. Physical and verbal abuse may occur.

The delusion usually affects men, often those with no prior psychiatric illness. It can present as a primary delusional disorder or as a symptom of other disorders such as schizophrenia, mood disorders, drug abuse, epilepsy, and alcoholism.

It is difficult to treat and may diminish only on separation, divorce, or death of the spouse. If associated with another psychiatric disorder, treatment is directed at the cause.

Other options:

Option B: Fregoli syndrome - The person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Option C: Erotomania, also known as de Clerambault syndrome or psychose passionelle - The patient has the delusion that another person, usually of higher status, is in love with him or her.

Option D: Capgras syndrome- The belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an impostor.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Identify the fingerprint pattern shown below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fingerprint with loops. These are the most common fingerprint patterns. 

Patterns of fingerprints:

  • Loops - These constitute 60-70% of patterns encountered. 
  • Whorl - Represent 25-30% of patterns encountered.
  • Arch - Represent about 5% of patterns encountered. They may be plain, tented, or exceptional.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with headache and vomiting for 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. He had intermittent bloody stools for the past 6 months. He has a family history of colon carcinoma. An MRI of his brain is given below. Colonoscopy and biopsy revealed numerous adenomatous polyps in the rectum and the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a brain tumour as seen in the MRI. Hence the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Turcot's syndrome is characterised by malignant tumours of the central nervous system in association with FAP

Familial adenomatous polyposis (option A) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.

Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. More than 100 colonic adenomas are diagnostic of FAP. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%.

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)

Gardner's syndrome (option C) is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have osteomas of the mandible or skull, epidermal cysts and soft tissue tumours like desmoid tumours

In Peutz-Jegher's syndrome, (option D) there is pigmentation of the mouth and lips and multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestines. It is an autosomal dominant disease.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: A 12 year-old-boy, who is a known case of atopic dermatitis, went to play in a nearby farm after which he developed runny nose and sneezing. His symptoms subsided after he came back home. But he developed the same symptoms again on the next day even without going to the farm. These symptoms occurring on the next day are chiefly mediated by:
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes pollen allergy. The symptoms occurring on the next day point to late phase reaction that is chiefly mediated by eosinophils.

The development of symptoms again without a second exposure to the allergen is known as the late phase reaction of allergic response. This is chiefly mediated by leukocyte infiltration into the tissues, especially the eosinophils. 

Allergic response/ type 1 hypersensitivity usually develops within minutes of exposure to the allergen. This response is chiefly mediated by the activation of mast cells. But, in some cases, there is a second response that develops 2 to 24 hours after exposure to the allergen. This second response does not require second exposure to the allergen. This is known as late phase reaction. This occurs because of the leukocyte infiltration of the tissues which also keeps this response continued for many days.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl diagnosed with adenoid hypertrophy developed pain in the ears and reports decreased hearing and popping sensations in both ears. Otoscopy revealed air-fluid level and bubbles. What type of curve is obtained on tympanometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the child suggests serous otitis media, also known as otitis media with effusion or glue ear. Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in serous otitis media.

Serous otitis media is the collection of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft due to malfunctioning of the eustachian tube or increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa. It presents as conductive hearing loss, leading to delayed and defective speech in children.

Otoscopy reveals a fluid level, bubbles, and varying degrees of retraction, as shown below:

Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in serous otitis media. The fluid accumulation causes decreased mobility of the tympanic membrane leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve, as shown below:

 

Management includes the use of decongestants, antiallergic measures initially, and myringotomy and aspiration of fluid if unresolved. Adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy may be required to treat the cause of serous otitis media.

Other options: 

Option A: Type A curve is a normal tympanogram.

Option C: Type As curve is seen in fixation of ossicles such as otosclerosis.

Option D: Type C curve is seen in negative middle ear pressure and retracted tympanic membrane.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: On observing the presence of Fleischer vortex(whorl keratopathy) during the ocular examination of a patient, you would expect to find a history of intake of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy/ Fleisher vortex/ whorl keratopathy.

Chloroquine - ocular toxicity:

  • On short-term therapy, chloroquine causes blurring of vision and diplopia, which are reversible by stopping the drug.
  • Long-term (>5 years) use of high doses of chloroquine causes keratopathy, pigmentary retinopathy, and optic atrophy.
  • Hydroxychloroquine has lower ocular toxicity compared to chloroquine.
  • The maximum permissible dosage of chloroquine is 6mg/Kg in 24 hours, while that of hydroxychloroquine is 4.5mg/Kg in 24 hours.

Long-term treatment with chloroquine may sometimes cause whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata.

Other causes of corneal verticillata: 

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines
  • Atovaquone

Other side effects of Chloroquine are:

  • Gastrointestinal (common): Abdominal cramps, anorexia, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting
  • Cardiovascular: Atrioventricular block, bundle branch block, cardiac arrhythmia, cardiac failure, cardiomyopathy, ECG changes, hypotension, torsades de pointes, ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia
  • Dermatologic: Alopecia, bleaching of hair, blue-grey skin pigmentation, erythema multiforme, exacerbation of psoriasis, urticaria, etc
  • Endocrine & metabolic: Exacerbation of porphyria, severe hypoglycemia
  • Hematologic & oncologic: Agranulocytosis (reversible), aplastic anemia, hemolytic anemia (in G6PD-deficient patients), neutropenia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic: Hepatitis, increased liver enzymes
  • Nervous system: Agitation, anxiety, confusion, decreased deep tendon reflex, delirium, depression, extrapyramidal reaction (dystonia, dyskinesia, protrusion of the tongue, torticollis) etc
  • Neuromuscular & skeletal: Asthenia, myopathy, neuromuscular disease, proximal myopathy
  • Ophthalmic: Accommodation disturbances, blurred vision, corneal opacity (reversible), macular degeneration (may be irreversible), maculopathy (may be irreversible), night blindness, retinal pigment changes (bull’s eye appearance), retinopathy (including irreversible changes in long-term or high-dose therapy), transient scotomata, visual field defect (paracentral scotomas)
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines, as shown in the image below, is called corneal verticillata.

Image below shows increased fluorescence in the macular area and round-shaped blocked fluorescence in the central fovea. It is likely due chloroquine toxicity.

Other options:

  • Commonly seen side effects with leflunomide are headache, alopecia, skin rash, diarrhea and nausea.

  • Commonly seen side effects with primaquine are gastrointestinal, cardiac arrhythmia, dizziness, pruritus, skin rash, anemia, hemolytic anemia (in patients with G6PD deficiency), leukopenia and methemoglobinemia (in NADH-methemoglobin reductase-deficient individuals)

  • Commonly seen side effects with apraclonidine are gastrointestinal, xerostomia, eye discomfort, eye pruritus and ocular hyperemia.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Malaria

questions.text: A female patient presented to the emergency room with right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin for 1 day. Urinalysis shows crystals, as seen below. What are these crystals made up of?
questions.solution:
Dumbbell-shaped and envelope-shaped crystals in this patient are indicative of calcium oxalate stones.

The classic presentation for a patient with nephrolithiasis (renal calculi) is acute renal colic, which is the sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly (loin to groin). It is usually accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. Urinalysis showing dumbbell and envelope-shaped crystals confirm that the kidney stones are made up of calcium oxalate. 

Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones:

  • Hyperparathyroidism (Causes hypercalcemia)
  • Hypercalciuria with normal serum calcium:
    • Hyperabsorption of calcium from the intestine (absorptive hypercalciuria)
    • Intrinsic impairment in renal tubular reabsorption of calcium (renal hypercalciuria)
    • Idiopathic fasting hypercalciuria with normal parathyroid function
  • Hyperoxaluria: Hereditary or acquired (intestinal malabsorption syndromes or excess intake of oxalate)
  • Hyperuricosuria
  • Hypocitraturia: Due to idiopathic causes, acidosis or chronic diarrhea.

There are four main types of calculi

  • Calcium stones (most common): composed of calcium oxalate or calcium oxalate mixed with calcium phosphate
  • Triple stones or struvite stones: composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate
  • Uric acid stones 
  • Cystine

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes with complaints of drooping eyelids and double vision in both eyes, The symptoms worsen with repetitive eye movements and resolve after rest. Chest radiography revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Which of the following is not a feature of her condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of intermittent complaints of ptosis and weakness of extraocular muscles (causing diplopia), which worsen after repetitive eye movements, is suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). Chest radiography showing an anterior mediastinal mass (most likely a thymoma) supports this diagnosis. Deep tendon reflexes are normal in myasthenia gravis, not absent.

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest or chest radiography.

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. Weakness of the muscles of the face (option C), palate and tongue may lead to difficulty in swallowing (option D). When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs (option A) are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

  • Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay
  • Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response
  • Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG
  • Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium
  • Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

  • Presence of thymoma
  • Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient. 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old male with an on-and-off history of constipation now presents with complaints of severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. He is stabilized before being sent for radiological investigations. Which of the following radiological findings would prompt you to consider a diagnosis of sigmoid volvulus in this patient?
  1. Bent inner tube sign on plain x-ray
  2. Whorl sign on CT
  3. Northern exposure sign on a supine abdominal x-ray
  4. Pseudokidney sign on ultrasonography
  5. Target sign on USG

choices.text: I, II, III, IV  are correct

questions.solution:
Bent inner tube sign on plain x-ray, Northern exposure sign on a supine abdominal x-ray, and Mesenteric whorl sign on CT would be consistent with sigmoid volvulus.

Volvulus is a condition in which the bowel becomes twisted on its mesenteric axis, resulting in partial or complete obstruction of the bowel and impairment of its blood supply. The condition usually affects the colon, most commonly the sigmoid colon. Less frequently, the right colon and terminal ileum (referred to as cecal volvulus), the cecum alone, and rarely, the transverse colon can also be affected.

This may present as acute or subacute intestinal obstruction. The patients complain of sudden onset severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation. The abdomen is generally markedly distended and tympanitic.

Plain abdominal X Rays typically reveal a markedly dilated sigmoid colon resembling a bent inner tube, with the apex in the right upper quadrant - Coffee bean sign or Bent inner tube sign. An air-fluid level may be visualized in the dilated loop of the colon, and the rectum usually does not contain gas. 

On a supine abdominal x-ray, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus is seen above (cranial to) the transverse colon, known as the Northern exposure sign. This sign is considered highly specific for sigmoid volvulus.

CT demonstrates a characteristic whorl sign caused due to the twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels.

Treatment of the sigmoid volvulus involves appropriate resuscitation, followed by nonoperative decompression in most cases. Resection can be done as an elective procedure.

The radiograph below shows the 'coffee bean sign' or 'bent inner tube sign' of sigmoid volvulus.

Other options - Pseudokidney sign and target sign are seen on ultrasonography in cases of intussusception.

Target sign of intussusception, most likely seen in infants during the weaning period due to hypertrophy of the Peyer's patches. The target sign of intestinal intussusception is also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.

Ultrasound signs of intussusception include:

  • Target sign (Also known as the doughnut sign).
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains of amenorrhea and hot flushes for 3 months following pelvic radiotherapy. She had regular menses before the procedure. A urine pregnancy test was negative. Investigations revealed normal prolactin and TSH. FSH was elevated on two occasions. Which of the following findings are consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of secondary amenorrhea with signs of estrogen deficiency (hot flushes) along with elevated FSH in a woman <40 years is suggestive of premature ovarian failure (POF). Among the given options, low estradiol is consistent with this diagnosis.

Premature ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (range of 30 to 40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. Other findings consistent with POF are:

  • Low estradiol.
  • Elevated FSH/LH ratio 

Normal TSH and normal prolactin rules out other causes of secondary amenorrhea such as thyroid dysfunction and prolactinoma respectively. A urine pregnancy test must also be done on a woman of childbearing age with amenorrhea.

Causes of POF

  • Migration of germ cells from the yolk sac.
  • Germ cell apoptosis.
    • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Autoimmune diseases - hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, etc
    • Genital TB
    • Smoking
    • Radiation and chemotherapy
    • Hysterectomy
    • Prolonged GnRH therapy
    • Induction of multiple ovulation.

Management:

  • Treatment of cause
  • If not interested in pregnancy:
    • Hormone replacement therapy.
  • If interested in pregnancy:
    • Ovulation induction (if an ovarian reserve is present) or
    • Offer donor eggs for in vitro fertilization.

Other options:

Option B - FSH/LH ratio is elevated in POF.

Option C - Anti-Mullerian hormone levels are decreased in POF.

Option D - DHEAS (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) is elevated when an adrenal tumor is a cause of secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A young woman with a history of prior Chlamydia infection presents with low-grade fever and lower abdominal pain. She has cervical motion tenderness and a mucopurulent vaginal discharge on pelvic examination. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?

choices.text: Injection ceftriaxone  + oral doxycycline + oral metronidazole

questions.solution:
The best treatment is a single IM injection of ceftriaxone with oral doxycycline and oral metronidazole for 14 days for pelvic inflammatory disease most likely due to Chlamydia trachomatis. 

Criteria to diagnose PID: Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

Minimum criteria

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness.

Additional criteria

  • Oral temperature >38.3oC
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Presence of abundant WBC on saline microscopy of vaginal fluid
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.

The definitive diagnosis of PID is through histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy. Imaging (TVS/MRI) showing evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes indicating tubo-ovarian abscess. Laparoscopic evidence of PID is confirmative.

Outpatient management of PID: Inj. ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days.

Indications for hospitalization in PID 

  • Surgical emergencies like appendicitis, generalized peritonitis, etc. 
  • Tubo-ovarian abscess
  • Pregnancy
  • oral temperature >38.5°C, severe nausea and vomiting
  • Unable to follow or tolerate an outpatient oral regimen
  • No clinical response to oral antimicrobial therapy

Parenteral treatment for PID in hospitalized patients: 

  • Inj. cefotetan + oral doxycycline 
  • (or) Inj. cefoxitin + oral doxycycline
  • (or) Inj.clindamycin + inj. gentamicin 

After clinical improvement of the patient with parenteral therapy, transition to oral therapy with doxycycline and metronidazole is recommended to complete 14 days of antimicrobial therapy.

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and partners have been adequately treated.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman works at a garment factory. She has two children and is now pregnant. According to the Maternity Act of 2017, she can avail a paid maternity leave for:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the woman has 2 surviving children and is pregnant with the 3rd child. So according to the Maternity Act of 2017, she can avail of a paid maternity leave of 12 weeks. 

The Maternity Benefits Act of 1961 was formulated for the welfare of the women employed in factories, shops or commercial establishments in which 10 or more employees are working. It was amended in the year 2017 by which the maternity leave was extended from 12 to 26 weeks for the first two children. It also mentioned the provisions of crèche and work-from-home options under certain circumstances.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are contraindications for induction of labour?
  1. Intra-uterine growth restriction
  2. Placenta praevia
  3. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
  4. Placental abruption
  5. Transverse lie
questions.solution:
Among the given options, placenta praevia and transverse lie are contraindications for induction of labour.

Intra-uterine growth restriction, intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy and placental abruption are indications for induction of labour.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: An elderly man was admitted to the hospital with high-grade fever and night sweats along with productive cough. He also mentions that he has lost weight. He is a chronic alcoholic and smoker. His sputum sample was collected for Modified acid-fast stain and revealed the following. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
The organism shown in the image is the Nocardia asteroides. They are modified acid-fast positive and appear as branching, filamentous rods. Patients with nocardiosis usually present with symptoms mimicking tuberculosis, such as fever, cough, night sweats.  

Nocardia are gram-positive strict aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections mostly in the immunocompromised.

Pleuropulmonary nocardiosis is the main presentation and usually manifests as pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, cough with or without sputum production, and shortness of breath.

Hematogenous spread from the lung is most frequently to the brain. Other common sites include skin, kidneys, bones, muscles, and eyes, but almost any organ can be involved. Cutaneous infection may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, lymphocutaneous lesions or actinomycotic mycetoma.

Treatment- Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice.

Other options:

Option A - Mycobacteria tuberculosis is acid-fast but does not have branching filaments.

Option B - Actinomyces israelii is not acid-fast.

Option C - Corynebacterium diphtheriae is not acid-fast.

Image above: Gram-positive Corynebacterium diphtheriae, stained using the methylene blue technique

Image above: Mycobacterium tuberculosis stained with Ziehl–Neelsen stain

Related Pearl: Acid fast Organisms

Acid-fast organisms Sulfuric acid (%) required for decolorization 
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis 
 25%
  • Mycobacterium leprae
 5%

 

  • Eggs of Taenia saginata
  • Eggs of Schistosoma mansoni
  • Oocyst of Cryptosporidium
  • Oocyst of Cyclospora
  • Oocyst of Cystoisospora
 1%
  • Sperm head
  • Legionella micdadei
  • Nocardia
 0.5-1%
  • Bacterial spore
 0.25-0.5%

 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, associated with nausea and vomiting for the past 3 hours. He had a history of excessive alcohol consumption over the past week. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum amylase and lipase. There is no evidence of infection, shock, or organ failure. What will be the initial method of management for this patient?
  1. Intravenous fluids
  2. Intravenous antibiotics
  3. Parenteral nutrition
  4. Intravenous analgesics
  5. Intravenous antiemetics
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of mild acute pancreatitis. Because the patient does not have any evidence of infection, necrosis, or multiorgan failure, he should be managed with intravenous fluids, intravenous analgesics and antiemetics.


Patients with acute pancreatitis may be grouped into three groups based on their signs and symptoms. Mild acute pancreatitis, which shows no signs of organ failure or systemic complications, moderately severe acute pancreatitis with organ failure that resolves in 48 hours, and severe acute pancreatitis with persistent organ failure.

Ranson and Glasgow scoring systems are specific for acute pancreatitis, and a score of 3 or more at 48 hours indicates a severe attack.

Management of acute pancreatitis includes:

  • Aggressive fluid replacement guided by frequent measurement of vital signs, urine output and observation.
  • Pain control with the use of intravenous analgesics.
  • Intravenous anti-emetics are given to reduce vomiting and further fluid loss
  • Enteral nutrition is given through nasogastric tube if needed.
  • CT scan is done if clinical deterioration, signs of organ failure,or signs of sepsis develop. 
  • If gallstones are the cause of severe pancreatitis, or if the patient has jaundice or a dilated common bile duct, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy should be carried out within 72 hours.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics are used in patients with acute severe pancreatitis. Antibiotics of choice are intravenous cefuroxime, or imipenem, or ciprofloxacin plus metronidazole.

Local complications of acute pancreatitis usually develop after one week of onset of the disease. These include pancreatic necrosis, pseudocyst of panceas, pancreatic abcess, pancreatic ascites or effusion and portal vein thrombosis.

Systemic complications are more common in the first week of onset of symptoms and include shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Causes of Acute Pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

questions.text: During the assessment of a  patient with suspected diabetic ketoacidosis, you decide to perform an ABG. You would be correct in doing all of the following steps except:

choices.text: Choose Radial artery as the site for sample collection
Immerse the sample in icebath for 5 mins before processing
Draw in 0.5 ml Heparin into the syringe and flush it out
Choose a different site if palm remains pale even after 15 seconds in modified Allen's test

questions.solution:
After collection, the ABG specimen should be analyzed immediately or as early as possible. Only If a delay is anticipated, the specimen must be immersed in an ice bath.

Radial artery is the preferred site for arterial blood sample collection for ABG analysis.

Modified Allen's Test is used to test the adequacy of collateral blood flow to hand especially mandatory before radial artery cannulation and sometimes, before drawing blood for arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis.

Method:

It is performed by asking the patient to make a tight fist and then occluding the radial and ulnar arteries. Then, the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation: 

If the palm remains pale for more than 10-15 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow. - Modified Allen's test negative.

Note: 

  • Test positive in Allen's test indicates that the collateral blood flow is abnormal.
  • Test positive in modified Allen's test indicates that the collateral blood flow is normal.

Other options:

1 ml of Heparin is not added to the syringe before taking blood, rather 0.5ml is drawn and flushed out.

Very little heparin is actually needed in the sample to prevent clotting; 0.05 to 0.10 ml of a dilute solution will anticoagulate 1 ml of blood without affecting its pH. This is usually achieved by drawing in 0.5 ml into the syringe and flushing it out. The residue that remains adherent to the syringe is sufficient for the procedure.

Heparin must be added to the syringe as an anticoagulant. Because the pH of heparin is near 7.0, and the Po2 and Pco2 of the heparin solution are near room air values, excess heparin can alter all three ABG measurements. After flushing the syringe with heparin, a sufficient amount usually remains in the dead space of the syringe and needle for anticoagulation without distortion of the ABG determination.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: A 35-year-old asymptomatic woman was found to have a 6cm unilocular cyst in her right ovary on ultrasonography during a routine check-up. Her other ovary was normal. Which of the following statements is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Laparotomy is indicated to prevent malignant transformation
Oral combined pills can be given to hasten the regression
Follow up every 3 months with ultrasound and CA-125 levels.

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a functional cyst, which usually regresses spontaneously. Oral combined pills (conservative management) can be given to hasten the regression.

Ovarian cysts are usually conservatively managed when the following criteria are met:

  • Woman of childbearing age
  • Asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Unilateral
  • Less than 7cm

Features of a functional cyst:

  • Related to temporary hormonal variation
  • Benign and rarely become complicated
  • Usually 6-8cm in diameter
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Contains clear fluid, unless haemorrhage occurs
  • Lining epithelium corresponds to the functional epithelium of the unit from which they arise

Management of functional cysts:

  • Size <7cm
    • Follow up with ultrasound as spontaneous regression occurs after 4-6 months.
    • Oral combined pills for 3-4 months to hasten the regression of cyst.
  • Size <5cm and menopausal
    • Follow up every 3 months with ultrasound and CA-125 levels.
  • Size >7cm
    • Laparotomy to prevent complications or malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 2-week-old boy is brought by the mother with complaints of jaundice. She further gives a history of dark-colored urine and pale-colored stool. HIDA scan shows a good hepatic uptake but an absence of excretion into the duodenum. Which of the following anomalies are associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the imaging are suggestive of biliary atresia. The anomalies associated with it are:

  • Polysplenia
  • Situs inversus
  • Absent vena cava
  • Preduodenal portal vein

Biliary atresia is the progressive narrowing of the bile ducts. Affected children present with jaundice in the first week of life. The laboratory investigation will show an obstructive pattern with elevated direct bilirubin levels and alkaline phosphatase.

Biliary atresia may also be termed noncystic obliterative cholangiopathy. It is a disease of the intra and extrahepatic bile ducts of unknown etiology. 

The disease is classified according to the level of the most proximal biliary obstruction:

  • Type 1 biliary atresia- has patency to the level of the common bile duct (CBD)
  • Type 2 biliary atresia- has patency to the level of the common hepatic duct
  • Type 3 biliary atresia- occurs when the left and right hepatic ducts, at the level of the porta hepatis, are involved. 

Clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive). 

Laboratory evaluation will show features of obstructive jaundice like elevated direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. The meconium may be a little bile stained, but later the stools are pale and the urine is dark. Ultrasound will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and triangular cord sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy can also be performed. HIDA scan is useful in making the diagnosis. There is good hepatic uptake, but since there is atresia of the biliary tree, there is an absence of excretion of the dye into the intestine. However, the gold standard investigation is the intraoperative cholangiogram.

If biliary atresia is confirmed by cholangiogram, a Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy) should be performed. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

questions.text:
A 55 year old man complains of cramping and weakness in his hands and legs. He also says that he is dropping objects from his hand frequently. He also notes that his arms and legs have become thinner. Investigations revealed mutation of SOD1 gene. Which of the following will be seen in this condition?
  1. Loss of upper motor neurons
  2. Loss of lower motor neurons
  3. Bunina bodies in the neurons
  4. Atrophy of caudate nucleus
  5. Alpha synuclein in the neurons
questions.solution:
The given condition describes progressive weakness and reduction of muscle bulk. SOD1 (superoxide dismutase) mutation indicates amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. 

SOD 1 protein normally helps in detoxifying free radicals and prevent cell injury. The mutant SOD 1 protein is misfolded and causes formation of aggregates which lead to cellular injury by dysregulation of catabolism, interfering with axonal transport and mitochondrial function, and sequestration of other proteins. These aggregates eventually trigger apoptosis.

ALS is characterised by loss of both upper and lower motor neurons. Inclusion bodies known as Bunina bodies are seen in the neurons.

Bunina bodies- In ALS, there is a reduction in the number of anterior-horn neurons throughout the length of the spinal cord. The remaining neurons contain PAS-positive cytoplasmic inclusions called Bunina bodies, which appear to be remnants of autophagic vacuoles.

 

The clinical symptoms of ALS include:

  • Asymmetric weakness of hands- dropping objects and difficulty performing fine motor tasks.
  • Spasticity of arms and legs, fasciculations may also be seen.
  • Decreasing muscle bulk.
  • Involvement of respiratory muscles.
  • Progressive bulbar palsy when brainstem nucleii are involved.
  • Frontotemporal dementia when cerebral cortex is involved

The given image shows the following clinical features of ALS:

  • The patient needs assistance to stand
  • Advanced atrophy of the tongue
  • Upper limb and truncal muscle atrophy
  • Thenar muscle atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following gene is involved in Cowden syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cowden syndrome occurs due to the mutation of the PTEN gene.

Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN)-10q23 is a tumor suppressor gene and it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. PTEN gene is a negative regulator of PI3K/AKT signaling. PI3K/AKT signaling normally leads to increased glycolysis and accumulation of upstream glycolytic intermediates. These are then utilized in the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins. By inhibiting this pathway, the PTEN gene keeps a check on the carcinomas caused due to the upregulation of this pathway.

Cowden syndrome is characterized by skin appendage tumors and an increased incidence of epithelial cancers, particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid.

Other options:

Option A- CDKN2A- Involved in familial melanoma and sporadic carcinomas of the pancreas, breast, and esophagus.

Option B- VHL- Codes for von Hippel–Lindau protein and is involved in von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (cerebellar hemangioblastoma, retinal angioma, renal cell carcinoma)

Option C- PTCH- Involved in Gorlin syndrome (basal cell carcinoma, medulloblastoma, several benign tumors)

(neurofibromas and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors)

Neurofibromatosis type 2 (acoustic schwannoma and meningioma

Related Pearl: Cowden Disease

Autosomal dominant

Mutation of PTEN gene on chromosome 10q23.3

Components:

  • Hamartomas of all three embryonal cell layers
    • Intestinal hamartomatous polyp – usually ectodermal, most common in colon
  • Facial trichilemmomas – most common feature.
  • Cancer of the
    • Breast (30–50%)
    • Thyroid (10% - Mainly FTC, rarely PTC and Hurthle cell tumors)
    • Endometrium
  • CNS – 2nd most commonly involved system
    • Megalencephaly, ataxia, epilepsy, dysplastic gangliocytoma of cerebellum – Lhermitte Duclos syndrome.
  • Developmental anomalies – high arched palate, adenoid facies, prominent forehead, Hypoplastic mandible.
  • Skin disease – acral keratosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete injures his leg. He complains of pain in his knees. The following technique has been employed to alleviate his pain. This technique relieves pain using which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief. It is based on the gate control theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of pain pathways in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibers are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

Related Pearl: Types of mammalian nerve fibres (Erlanger and Gasser's classification)

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and short stature. His parents also say that he is frequently hungry and eats multiple times a day. On examination, truncal obesity and short hands and feet are noted. He has not developed secondary sexual characteristics. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible diagnosis is Prader-Willi syndrome, a genomic imprinting disorder.

Prader Willi syndrome occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes. Deletion of the paternal chromosome occurs in 70% of the cases, in the rest, it is caused due to uniparental disomy where there are two copies of the silenced maternal gene with absent paternal genes. The net effect in uniparental disomy is the same as deletion. Loss of the SNORP family of genes is responsible for this syndrome. It is characterized by:

  • Mental retardation
  • Obesity
  • Hyperphagia
  • Hypogonadism
  • Short stature
  • Small hands and feet
  • Abnormal facial features like
    • Small upturned nose
    • Narrow bifrontal distance
    • Thin upper lip

The above-mentioned features of short stature, obesity, small upturned nose, thin upper lip, and small hands and feet can be seen in the images given below. 

Other options:

Option A- Klinefelter syndrome occurs due to 47 XXY karyotype. It is one of the most common causes of male hypogonadism. The patients have tall stature with abnormally long legs and lack of secondary sexual characters. Gynecomastia may be present with atrophic testes and a small penis. The patients may have average to below-average cognitive abilities. Features of Kleinfelters are listed in the image given below.

Option B- Noonan syndrome- It is associated with abnormalities in the PTPN11 gene, RAS/MAPK pathway. The 3 most common characteristics of Noonan syndrome are:

  • Unusual facial features - a broad forehead, ptosis, ocular hypertelorism, a short, broad nose, low-set ears that are rotated towards the back of the head, small jaw,  short neck with excess skin fold,  a lowset hairline.
  • Short stature - Usually normal birth weight and length, but frequently associated with short stature and failure to thrive later in life. There is delayed puberty.
  • Heart defects present at birth -  Pulmonary stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and septal defects.

Most individuals have normal intelligence but are associated with behavioral abnormalities. An image of a child suffering from Noonan syndrome is given below in which a short posterior hairline, broad chest, a short webbed neck can be observed.

Option D- Angelman syndrome is characterized by deletion of ubiquitin ligase gene (UBE3A) on maternal chromosome 15q12 and silencing of the paternal chromosomal counterpart. It is characterized by:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Microcephaly
  • Ataxic gait 
  • Seizures
  • Inappropriate laughter

Due to inappropriate laughter and ataxia, they are also known as "happy puppets" as shown below.

Other diseases due to genomic imprinting are :

  • Angelman syndrome
  • Beckwith-Weidemann sydrome
  • Silver-Russell syndrome.

Mnemonic:

Prader–Willi Syndrome: Paternal gene deletion - P for P
Angelman syndrome: Maternal gene deletion (Mothers are Angels, Maternal gene deletion leads to Angelman syndrome)

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID Health Centre?

A. Respiratory rate of 25/min
B. SpO2 93%
C. Multiple comorbidities
D. Chest pain
E. Age
questions.solution: A, B, C & E are clinical criteria of admission under COVID-19 ward.

questions.text: A 3-year-old unimmunized child is brought to the emergency room with high-grade fever, drooling of saliva, and dysphagia. Auscultation revealed inspiratory stridor. His lateral X-ray of neck is given below. The next best step in his management is?

choices.text: Secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone
Give antipyretics and reassure the patient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, drooling, dysphagia, and inspiratory stridor along with the lateral X-ray neck showing the thumb sign suggests acute epiglottitis. The next best step in his management is to secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammatory condition of supra-glottic structures, i.e. epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoid. It is also known as supraglottic laryngitis and is a medical emergency. 

It commonly affects children aged 2–7 years. The most common organism responsible for this is Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib). 

Clinical features include high-grade fever, dysphagia, drooling of saliva, sore throat, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor.The patient usually adopts a tripod position by leaning forward on his arms and has his neck extended with his chin up and breathing through the mouth. Airway obstruction occurs due to inflammation and edema of the surrounding structures. 

The direct laryngoscopic shows an inflamed and swollen epiglottis that has a characteristic cherry-red-colored appearance. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign (shown below). 

Treatment includes: 

  • Immediate hospitalization 
  • Securing airway by endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or by tracheostomy, irrespective of the degree of respiratory obstruction
  • Empirical management by third-generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime, ceftriaxone) or ampicillin
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema
  • Humidified oxygen can also be given

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of sudden painless visual loss in his right eye. The patient describes the loss of vision as a veil covering the visual field. He is slightly myopic and had a successful cataract extraction with intraocular lens implantation 3 years ago. His history is significant for well-controlled diabetes and hypertension. The examination finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows tobacco dust appearance (Shaffer's sign) in the anterior vitreous. This suggests the presence of a retinal tear. So the most likely diagnosis is rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD- due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

Rhegmatogenous RD:

In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of retinal break is superiotemporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreo-retinal traction at site of the break.
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous hemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Treatment of rhegmatogenous RD includes:

  • Prophylactic laser barrage
  • Scleral buckling
  • Pneumatic retinopexy
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to:

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in the Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformation such as keratoconus.
  • Birth trauma.

Option B - Exudative RD

It occurs in patients who have an accumulation of fluid beneath the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes:
    • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis.
    • Choroidal tumours like melanoma.
    • Toxemia of pregnancy
    • Central serous retinopathy
    • Coats disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is smooth.
    • Shifting fluid is seen.
    • No breaks are seen.

Option C - Tractional RD:

It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause
Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painful loss of vision
  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball
Gradual painless diminution of vision
  • Corneal dystrophy
  • Senile cataract
  • Primary open angle glaucoma
  • Optic atrophy
  • ARMD
  • Refractive error
  • Diabetic retinopathy
Gradual painful diminution of vision
  • Chronic iridocyclitis
  • Corneal ulceration

questions.text: During the attempted intubation of a patient, the senior resident complains that the glottis is too anterior and asks the junior resident to perform a maneuver so that the senior resident would be able to visualize the glottis better as shown below. Identify the correct sequence of steps that the junior resident would have performed for obtaining such a result.
questions.solution:
The maneuver that the junior resident would have performed is the BURP maneuver, where a Backwards->Upwards->Rightwards pressure is applied externally so as to move an anteriorly positioned glottis posterior for getting better visualization.

You can visualize the step-by-step result of the maneuver in the video below.

Note:

BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text:
A patient is posted for appendicectomy. Before induction, the anesthetist and the nurse confirmed the patient’s identity, consent, the procedure, checked the medications taken by the patient, and if the site of the incision is marked. They then checked if the antibiotic prophylaxis has been given to the patient. After this, the surgeon arrived, and all the team members introduced themselves and reconfirmed the patient’s identity and procedure. They also checked if the required imaging is displayed within the operating room. The operation went uneventful, and before the patient left the operating room, the nurse verbally confirmed the name of the procedure, and counts of instruments, sponges, needle to the surgeon and anesthetist. She also read the labeling of the appendicectomy specimen.

Identify the incorrectly done step in the surgical safety checklist.

choices.text: Reading of the specimen label by the nurse
Nurse and anaesthetist checking for the antibiotic prophylaxis administration
Nurse and anaesthetist checking the medications taken by the patient
Checking for the required imaging after the surgeon arrived

questions.solution:
Nurse and anesthetist checking for the antibiotic prophylaxis administration is the incorrect step. Surgeon should also be present during this step.
 
The WHO surgical safety checklist was developed to decrease errors and increase teamwork during the surgery. It contains 19 items which have to be performed by the surgeon, anesthetist and nurse during surgery.
Before induction of anesthesia, anesthetist and nurse should check for the 
  • patient’s identity, site of procedure, procedure done and consent
  • if the site of the surgery is marked
  • working of anesthesia machine and pulse oximetry
  • Check the medications
  • risk of allergy, aspiration and blood loss in the patient
Before the incision of the skin, the surgeon, anesthetist, and nurse should
  • introduce themselves by name and their role
  • reconfirm the patient’s name, procedure and site of incision
  • check if the antibiotic prophylaxis has been given to the patient
  • check if the essential imaging is displayed
  • discuss the anticipated critical events
Before patient leaves the operating room, the nurse should verbally confirm 
  • name of the procedure
  • counts of the instruments, sponges, and needles
  • labelling of the specimen infront of the surgeon and anaesthetist.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of shortness of breath for 6 months. On examination, he has a hyperdynamic apical impulse with wide pulse pressure and a diastolic murmur in the second intercostal space on the left sternal border. The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb by 24 mmHg. Which among the following is the above-mentioned sign?
questions.solution:
In this patient, shortness of breath along with examination findings of wide pulse pressure, hyperdynamic apical impulse, and diastolic murmur in the second intercostal space on the left sternal border points toward a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation. In aortic regurgitation (AR), if the systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20 mmHg, the sign is called Hill's sign.

Normally, the systolic blood pressure in the lower limb is 10-20 mm higher than the upper limb pressure. The increased blood pressure is due to the summation of reflected pressure waves. In aortic regurgitation, the systolic blood pressure in the lower limb is more than 20 mmHg higher than the systolic blood pressure in the upper limb.  

Further, there are a number of other signs seen in aortic regurgitation.

Other peripheral signs seen in AR:

  • de Musset's sign is the head bobbing with each arterial pulsation
  • Corrigan's sign is the rapidly rising water hammer pulse, which collapses quickly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole
  • Traube's sign is the booming pistol shot sound over femoral arteries.

The total stroke volume ejected by the left ventricle is increased in aortic regurgitation. It is the sum of the effective forward stroke volume and the volume of blood that regurgitates back into the left ventricle. This occurs due to valve leaflets or primary aortic root disease. AR results in left ventricular (LV) volume overload. This increase in LV end-diastolic volume causes dilatation and eccentric hypertrophy of the LV. Over time, these adaptive measures fail, which leads to a further rise in the end-diastolic volume, and the forward stroke volume and ejection fraction (EF) decline.

LV decompensation results in decreased compliance and increased LV end-diastolic volume and pressure. The increase in LV mass leads to increased myocardial oxygen requirements and reduced coronary perfusion pressure. This results in exertional chest pain.

A high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo diastolic murmur, heard best in the third intercostal space along the left sternal border can be auscultated in aortic regurgitation. It is best heard when the patient leans forward with breath held in forced expiration. The below image shows auscultatory findings in aortic regurgitation.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign
