questions.text:
A mother brings her 3-year-old child to the hospital with complains that the left eye looks strange and different from the right eye. Initial assessment revealed a white pupillary reflex. Further evaluation by a specialist revealed a chalky white, grey retinal mass with vitreous and subretinal seeding and an overlying total retinal detachment. A diagnosis of retinoblastoma is confirmed. Which among the following drugs are part of the 3-drug regimen that is commonly used​ in the treatment of this condition?

1. Vincristine
2. Vinblastine
3. Cisplatin
4. Carboplatin
5. Etoposide
questions.solution:
The commonly used three-drug regimen in the chemotherapy of retinoblastoma is

  • Vincristine (Option 1)
  • Carboplatin (Option 4)
  • Etoposide (Option 5)

Retinoblastoma is a proliferation of neural cells which have failed to evolve normally. It is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.

The most common presenting sign is leukocoria or white pupillary reflex at around 3 years of age. It is often associated with retinal detachment and vitreal seeding of the tumour.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy (systemic or intra-arterial) plus focal therapy with laser or cryotherapy. In advanced cases, enucleation may be required.

Image showing leukocoria of left eye

questions.text: Anu is a 30-year-old woman who comes to your clinic with a positive urine pregnancy test. She is anxious and tells you that she has used a UPT kit 'X' that is new in the market. You want to know more about the test and read an article about a study done on 1000 women to validate the test 'X'. Among them, 200 were pregnant and test X gave a positive result for 180 pregnant women and a negative result for 20 pregnant women.  The remaining 800 women were not pregnant but test X's results were positive in 20 of them and negative in the rest. Assuming that Anu is from the same population as in the clinical trial and given that she has a positive pregnancy test, how likely is it that she is truly pregnant?
questions.solution:
There is a 90% probability that Anu is truly pregnant. This gives the Positive Predictive Value (PPV) of the test 'X'.

Among the 200 pregnant women, 180 were true positives (TP). Of the remaining 800 women who were not pregnant, 20 falsely tested positive (FP). PPV = TP/(TP + FP) = 180/(180+20), or 90%.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: In a suspected case of rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following markers should be used to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate marker to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibody as it is the most specific marker for RA.

Anti-CCP, ESR, and CRP values correlate with the disease activity.

Rheumatoid factor can occur in other autoimmune diseases as well as in chronic infections. Therefore it is not considered specific.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male with a 35 pack-year history of smoking presents for his annual health checkup. His elder brother was recently diagnosed with lung cancer and he is apprehensive about the same. He insists on getting tested to know if he too has lung cancer though he doesn't have any specific complaints/ symptoms suggestive of the same. Which among the following would be the best-suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
As the scenario entails screening an asymptomatic patient with increased risk for lung cancer, the best-suited option would be to use Low-dose, thin-slice spiral chest CT. 

LDCT refers to a non-contrast study obtained with a multidetector CT scanner during a single maximal inspiratory breath-hold with a scanning time under 25 seconds. LDCT scans were shown to detect more lung nodules and cancers than the standard CXR in high-risk populations. 

Criteria for annual low dose CT scan screening for lung cancer (American College of Chest Physicians):

  • ages 55 to 77 years
  • with ≥30 pack-year history of smoking
  • current smoker or quit within the past 15 years.

Clinical features of lung cancer: There are a wide range of symptoms due to the intrathoracic effects of cancer, but the most common are:

  • cough
  • hemoptysis
  • chest pain
  • dyspnea
  • superior vena cava syndrome
  • Pancoast syndrome
  • hoarseness

Other options:

Chest X-ray and sputum cytology: Screening for lung cancer by chest radiograph and/or sputum cytology is not recommended anymore. Early trials of chest radiograph screening in males at high risk for lung cancer found no mortality benefit for radiograph alone or radiograph plus sputum cytology.

Contrast-enhanced High-resolution CT would not be a good option due to the radiation dose exposure that it entails. For LDCT, the estimated effective radiation dose is 1.4 mSv compared with average effective radiation doses of 7 to 8 mSv for one standard-dose diagnostic chest CT. 

Related Pearl: Incidence of lung cancer according to histology

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

questions.text: A histological image of the dermis is shown below. The structure marked in the image is
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the histological image of the dermis is the Pacinian corpuscle which appears as a large, onion-like structure in the dermis and hypodermis.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are very rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors and are specialized for sensing coarse touch, pressure (sustained touch), and fast vibration.

Apart from skin, they are also present in the connective tissue of organs located deep in the body, including the wall of the rectum and urinary bladder.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: A 14-months-old girl is brought by her concerned mother after she had two episodes of convulsions in the morning. She says that the child has been irritable for the past 3 days and has sweet-smelling urine in the diaper. She had recently been started on a high protein diet by the mother based on the advice of a relative. She has had an uneventful course since birth with normal developmental progress and complete immunization to date. The urine test shows a positive dinitrophenylhydrazine test. Inability to metabolize which of the following amino acids would explain these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). It occurs due to the defective metabolism of the branched-chain amino acids like leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a partial or complete deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKD). This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids. These amino acids and their corresponding α-keto acids accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain.

Intermittent maple syrup urine disease is the second most common type of MSUD, after the classic type. It is a milder form due to the presence of greater enzyme activity than classical. The child has normal growth and intelligence and is generally asymptomatic until age 12-24 months, unlike the classical type which presents in neonates aged 3-7 days. The first presentation in intermittent MSUD occurs in response to catabolic stress as due to illness like otitis media or a surge in protein intake. During such episodes, the characteristic maple syrup odor becomes evident, and metabolic decompensation occurs. Ataxia, lethargy, seizures, and coma may follow.

The disease is characterized by feeding problems, vomiting, ketoacidosis, changes in muscle tone, and various neurologic problems.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Since the patient has ketonuria, the urine will show a positive dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Treatment involves restricting the intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

Related Pearl: Inborn Errors of Amino Acid Metabolism and Their Associated Urine Odor

Inborn Error of Metabolism

Urine Odor

questions.text: The type of fracture shown in the image below occurs due to:

choices.text: Elasticity of the bones in children
Blow from a heavy weapon with small striking surface

questions.solution:
The given image shows a depressed fracture of the skull. It occurs when a heavy weapon with a small striking surface is used. This fracture also indicates the impression of the weapon used. Hence, it is known as a signature fracture.

Other options:

Option B- Elasticity of the bones in children prevents the formation of fracture lines. This results in only indentation of the skull known as Pond's fracture.

Option D- An oblique bullet wound may lead to a gutter fracture.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: A woman with a history of 2 abortions undergoes an HSG which shows the presence of a bicornuate uterus. Defect in the development of which of the following structures leads to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Bicornuate uterus results from the defective development of the paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct. The uterus and the cervix develop from the paramesonephric ducts (Mullerian ducts).

The derivatives of the paramesonephric (Mullerian) ducts in the female include

  • Uterine tube
  • Uterus and cervix
  • Upper part of vagina

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and Paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct

Structures arising from mesonephric/Wolffian duct

Males Females
Ureteric bud and its derivatives Ureteric bud and its derivatives
Trigone of bladder Trigone of bladder
The proximal part of the prostatic urethra The posterior wall of the urethra
Spermatic pathway Gartner's duct
Appendix of epididymis  

Structures arising from the paramesonephric/Mullerian duct

Males Females
Appendix of testis Fallopian tube
Prostatic utricle Uterus
  Cervix
  Upper vaginal wall

 

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the clinic with fatigue and weakness. Pallor of the conjunctiva and pale skin are evident. Yellowing of the sclera is also seen. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly.  A peripheral smear is ordered and it is shown below. Which of the following is the most specific test for the diagnosis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The eosin-5-maleimide test is the most specific among the given tests for diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis. It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein. 

This patient's fatigue, weakness, pallor of the conjunctiva, and pale skin are indicative of anemia. Yellowing of sclera i.e icterus and splenomegaly suggests the type of anemia is likely to be hemolytic. Further, the peripheral smear shows numerous spherocytes, i.e. the red blood cells appear abnormally small and lack the central pale area that is present in normal red blood cells. All these findings make hereditary spherocytosis the most likely diagnosis.

Although relatively rare, hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is the most common cause of hemolytic anemia due to a red cell membrane defect. It is a result of heterogeneous alterations in one of five genes that encode red blood cells. The most common mode of inheritance of hereditary spherocytosis is autosomal dominant. It can be caused by mutations of ankyrin and band 3.1 proteins.

Mechanism of hemolysis

Spectrin deficiency acts directly on the bilayer to create areas of weakness that allow membrane loss. This leads to the conversion of normal RBCs to spherocytes. Spherocytes are prone to hemolysis. The mechanisms include reduced deformability, which impairs passage through constricted regions of the microcirculation, and phagocytosis by splenic macrophages, which occurs in response to splenic trapping. Loss of spectrin appears to be especially correlated with the severity of hemolysis.

Classification of HS

A classification for HS has been developed based on the severity of anemia and markers of hemolysis (reticulocyte count and bilirubin). It characterizes patients as having one of the following:

Type Hemoglobin (g/dl) Reticulocytes (%) Bilirubin (mg/dl)
HS trait Normal Normal Normal
Mild HS 11-15 3-6 1-2
Moderate HS 8-12 >6 >2
Severe HS 6-8 >10 >3

Confirmatory tests for HS

The eosin-5-maleimide test (EMA) is the most specific test for diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis. It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein. Advantages of EMA binding include its high sensitivity and specificity, rapid turnaround time (approximately two hours) and need for only a minimal amount of blood (a few microliters), which is especially advantageous for testing neonates.

Other options:

  • Acidified glycerol lysis test: Spherocytes from patients with hereditary spherocytosis lyse more quickly than normal red blood cells when incubated in phosphate-buffered hypotonic solution with added glycerol. It has greater sensitivity and specificity than the osmotic fragility test.
  • Osmotic fragility test: If EMA binding is not available, osmotic fragility testing (OFT) is another useful specialized test for HS. Detects hemolysis by measuring the fraction of total hemoglobin released from red cells when suspended in progressively more dilute salt concentrations.
  • NESTROFT (Naked Eye Single Tube Red-cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a highly sensitive test used as a screening test for thalassemia.

questions.text:
During the abdominal examination on a 6-month-old infant, you notice the following finding. Which of the following are false regarding this condition?
  1. Incidence of this condition is higher in premature births
  2. Sac decreases in size when the baby cries
  3. Commonly seen in children with congenital hyperthyroidism
  4. Obstruction and strangulation are common below the age of 2 years.
  5. Spontaneous resolution is unlikely if it persists beyond 2 years
questions.solution:
The image shows a mass protruding out of the umbilicus indicative of an umbilical hernia. Sac increases in size when the baby cries. Commonly seen in children with congenital hypothyroidism. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon below the age of 3 years.

An umbilical hernia occurs when a loop of the intestine protrudes through the umbilicus. It is common in newborn children, especially in premature babies. Both sexes are equally affected and the incidence in black infants is up to eight times higher than in white. The hernia is often symptomless, but increases in size on crying and assumes a classic conical shape. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon in umbilical hernias.

Conservative treatment is indicated under the age of 2 years when the hernia is symptomless. The majority of them will resolve spontaneously. If the hernia persists beyond the age of 2 years of age, surgical repair is indicated, as a spontaneous resolution becomes unlikely beyond 2 years of age.

Procedure: A small curved incision is made below the umbilicus and the neck of the sac is opened. The contents are returned to the peritoneal cavity and the redundant sac is excised after closing it. The defect in the linea alba is closed with interrupted sutures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of HIV infection for 10 years. She was also diagnosed with invasive cervical cancer 1 year back. She suffered from pneumocystis pneumonia 2 months back which was treated successfully. On examination, she has oral candidiasis. Her BP is found to be 130/90, RR 12/min, and pulse 82 bpm. She also has skin lesions as shown below. Which of the following options is not an AIDS-defining illness in this patient?
questions.solution:
Candidiasis of the mouth/thrush is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of the esophagus, bronchi, trachea, or lungs is an AIDS-defining illness.

Other options:

  • Kaposi sarcoma: The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques together with the clinical features and the biopsy finding is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma which is caused by Human herpesvirus 8. Contact with oral secretions is likely the most common route of transmission of HHV-8. It is the most common HIV-related malignancy and is an AIDS-defining illness.
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia: Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is a serious infection that causes inflammation and fluid buildup in your lungs. It's brought on by a fungus called Pneumocystis jirovecii that spreads through the air and affects mainly immunocompromised patients. It is an AIDS-defining illness.
  • Invasive Cervical cancer: Invasive cervical cancer is an AIDS-defining illness.

AIDS-defining illnesses:

  • Candidiasis of the esophagus, bronchi, trachea, or lungs [(but NOT the mouth (thrush)]
  • Cervical cancer, invasive
  • Coccidioidomycosis, disseminated or extrapulmonary
  • Cryptococcosis, extrapulmonary
  • Cryptosporidiosis, chronic intestinal (greater than one month's duration)
  • Cytomegalovirus disease (other than liver, spleen, or nodes)
  • Cytomegalovirus retinitis (with loss of vision)
  • Encephalopathy, HIV related
  • Herpes simplex: chronic ulcer(s) (more than 1 month in duration); or bronchitis, pneumonitis, or esophagitis
  • Histoplasmosis, disseminated or extrapulmonary
  • Isosporiasis, chronic intestinal (more than 1 month in duration)
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Lymphoma, Burkitt's (or equivalent term)
  • Lymphoma, immunoblastic (or equivalent term)
  • Lymphoma, primary, of brain
  • Mycobacterium avium complex or M kansasii, disseminated or extrapulmonary
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis, any site (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
  • Mycobacterium, other species or unidentified species, disseminated or extrapulmonary
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia
  • Pneumonia, recurrent
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Salmonella septicemia, recurrent
  • Toxoplasmosis of brain Wasting syndrome due to HIV

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with tingling and numbness of hands and feet. He also complains of fatigue and constant pain in his lower limbs. Careful history taking reveals episodes of confusion. Blood investigations reveal anaemia and monoclonal spike.  A radiograph of his femur is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes polyneuropathy, symptoms of hypercalcemia (fatigue, confusion), anaemia and monoclonal spike with image showing lytic lesions in the bone.  All these features are suggestive of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myelomas: Malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by:

  • Presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine
  • Bone destruction (lytic lesions)
  • Disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years

Signs and symptoms

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pathologic fractures/lytic bone lesions
  • Renal failure
  • Anemia
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Other options:

Option A- Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia- It usually occurs in older adults in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (B cell neoplasm). The tumor cells undergo terminal differentiation to plasma cells which secrete monoclonal IgM that causes hyperviscocity syndrome. In this syndrome, light chains secretion very rarely lead to renal failure and bone destruction is not seen.

Option C- Cryoglobulinemia- It results in precipitation of macroglobulins at lower temperatures leading to Raynaud's phenomenon.

Option D- Senile systemic amyloidosis- It refers to systemic deposition of amyloid in elderly patients. The amyloid in this condition is derived from normal TTR (transthyretin). It usually involves the heart.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants
A. PLASMA CELL NEOPLASMS
 Multiple myeloma (previously plasma cell myeloma)
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 3g/dL and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L
Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone
Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome 
  • POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes
  • TEMPI syndrome 
  • AESOP syndrome
B. MONOCLONAL IMMUNOGLOBULIN DEPOSITION DISEASES 
Immunoglobulin-related (AL) amyloidosis (previously primary amyloidosis)
  • Systemic AL amyloidosis
  • Localised AL amyloidosis
  • Heavy chain amyloidosis
Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition disease (previously light and heavy chain deposition disease)
  • Light chain deposition disease
  • Heavy chain deposition disease
  • Light and heavy chain deposition disease
C. MONOCLONAL GAMMOPATHIES
  • Cold agglutinin disease
  • Monoclonal gammopathy of renal significance
  • IgM and non-IgM monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined signifcance

questions.text:
A 29-year-old, HIV-positive male was admitted to the hospital with a two-
week history of non-productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. On
examination, he had a mild fever, tachypnoea and tachycardia.
Investigations reveal a CD4 count of 146/cumm, elevated serum LDH
levels and significantly reduced arterial oxygen levels. A chest X-ray
demonstrated bilateral perihilar pulmonary infiltration. The microscopy of a sample of sputum obtained by bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), stained with toluidine blue is shown below. Which of the following is
incorrect about the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Serum beta-1,3-D glucan levels will be elevated
Treatment should be done with cotrimoxazole
BAL culture on selective medium incubated at 37 °C will grow off-white fluffy colonies in a week’s time

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is typical of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) and option D is the incorrect statement about the diagnosis.

The image shows cysts of Pneumocystis jiroveci stained with toluidine blue. Pneumocystis is an opportunistic fungus that cannot be cultured, and is an important cause of pneumonia in the immunocompromised, mainly in those with HIV infection. Most immunocompetent individuals are infected in early childhood but are resistant to the disease. Cell-mediated immunity plays a major role in this.

It presents as pneumonia characterized by dyspnea, fever, and nonproductive cough, and ultimately respiratory failure and death. Extrapulmonary manifestations of PCP are rare but mainly involve lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

Patients have decreased oxygen saturation which progresses to severe hypoxemia if not treated. Chest examination may be normal initially but may later develop diffuse rales and signs of consolidation.

Laboratory Findings:

  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is often elevated, reflecting lung injury. However, it is not specific to PCP.
  • Serum or plasma BG (beta-1,3-D glucan) are raised in PCP and can be used as an adjunctive diagnostic tool.
  • Demonstration of organisms in lung tissue or bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid by staining with methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, Giemsa, or with a specific immunofluorescent antibody is diagnostic.

Chest radiograph of symptomatic PCP classically shows diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates. The interstitial infiltrates can progress to alveolar filling. Cysts and pneumothoraces are commonly seen on chest X-rays of HIV patients. Chest CT shows diffuse ground-glass opacities. A normal chest CT rules out the diagnosis of PCP.

Pneumocystis jiroveci though classified as a fungus, does not respond to antifungals. The treatment of choice for PCP is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole), either IV or PO for 14 days to non-HIV-infected patients with mild disease and for 21 days to all other patients.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A young man was brought to the emergency department unconscious following a road traffic accident.  Later he gained consciousness and was appearing normal. The doctor performed a CT scan and the image is given below. This patient would need surgical evacuation if
questions.solution:
The above CT image shows a lentiform or biconvex-shaped epidural hematoma. The patient would need surgical evacuation if the hematoma is more than 30 mL.

Open craniotomy or Burr hole drainage of the hematoma is required if:

  • The volume of hematoma is more than 30 mL
  • The thickness of the hematoma is >1.5 cm
  • Midline shift is > 5mm
  • GCS is <8.

Extradural/epidural hematoma (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from injury to the middle meningeal artery.

Usually, it has a three-stage clinical presentation. The patient is initially unconscious due to the head injury. The patient then awakens and appears normal, which is called a lucid interval. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the condition of the patient rapidly worsens.

On CT, extradural hematoma appears as a lentiform or biconvex-shaped hyperdense lesion between the skull and the dura.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with back pain and increasing difficulty with initiating a urinary stream for the past 1 year. On rectal examination, he is found to have a hard, irregularly enlarged prostate. The doctor advised for the levels of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) and it was found to be elevated. Bone scan shows osteoblastic lesions in the vertebral column and in the bones of the pelvis. A needle biopsy of the prostate shows well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the first-line therapy in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicts metastatic prostate cancer. The first-line therapy in this condition is hormone ablation. The levels of testosterone are reduced either by orchidectomy or by the use of luteinizing hormone releasing hormone (LHRH) agonists and androgen receptor blockers.

Treatment of the prostate carcinoma:

  • Low-risk prostatic cancer with low PSA and small foci of Gleason 6 disease can be managed by active surveillance. The patient is evaluated every 3 -4 months by digital rectal examination and the levels of prostate-specific antigen. Radical prostatectomy is considered in men whose life expectancy is more than 10 years.
  • Intermediate risk disease -Younger men are treated by radical radiotherapy or radical prostatectomy. In the elderly patient with outflow obstruction, transurethral resection with or without hormone therapy is indicated.
  • High risk disease- Androgen ablation coupled with radiotherapy and surgery
  • Metastatic disease- Hormone ablation remains the first line of therapy. The levels of testosterone are reduced by
    • Orchidectomy, or
    • Medical castration - Use of luteinizing hormone releasing hormone (LHRH) agonists, androgen receptor blockers (flutamide and bicalutamide) etc.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man injured his back in a road traffic accident. On examination, it is found that he has a loss of proprioception and vibration sense in both lower limbs. Which of the following is true about the type of nerve fibers that are damaged in this patient?

choices.text: Small diameter, unmyelinated, low conduction velocity
Medium sized, myelinated, high conduction velocity
Large diameter, unmyelinated, low conduction velocity
Large diameter, myelinated, high conduction velocity

questions.solution:
The sensations of proprioception and vibration are carried by A-alpha nerve fibers. These are nerve fibers with large axonal diameter, myelinated, and have high conduction velocity. These are carried along the dorsal column of the spinal cord.

Other options:

Option A- Type C fibers are small diameter unmyelinated fibers with low conduction velocity. They carry pain sensation.

Option B- Type A beta, gamma, and delta fibers are medium-sized myelinated fibers. They carry touch and pressure sensations and supply muscle spindles.

Option C- Large diameter nerve fibers are myelinated, both these factors contribute to high conduction velocity.

Related Pearl: Ascending tracts of spinal cord

 

Pathway Dorsal column Anterior spinothalamic tract Lateral spinothalamic tract
Receptor Meissner corpuscles, pacinian corpuscles, muscle spindles, golgi tendon organs Free nerve endings Free nerve endings 
First-order neuron

First-order neurons from the receptors enter spinal cord from dorsal root >

ascend ipsilaterally as fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus >

synapse in nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus in medulla > 

 First-order neurons from dorsal root ganglion ascend for a few segments and synapse with the cells in the posterior gray column >
Second-order neuron

second-order neurons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus continue as internal arcuate fibers > 

decussate in the lower medulla and ascends as medial lemniscus on the contralateral side >

synapse in the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus

Second-order neurons from the posterior gray column crossover to the opposite side and ascend as anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract >

form the spinal lemniscus in the medulla >

ascend through pons and synapses in the ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus >
Third-order neuron third-order neuron from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus ascend in the posterior limb of internal capsule and corona radiata and terminate in somatosensory cortex Third-order neurons from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus ascend through the posterior limb of internal capsule and corona radiata and terminate in the somatosensory cortex
Decussation Medulla Spinal cord - few segments above the entry point   Spinal cord- one segment above the entry point
Sensations carried Proprioception, Fine touch(discriminative touch), pressure intesity, vibration, position sense Crude touch, pressure  Pain and temperature

questions.text: An elderly man presents with severe, worsening abdominal pain since the previous day. He had undergone angioplasty for coronary artery disease 2 years back. The patient was hemodynamically stable. On examination, a pulsatile mass was palpated in the abdomen. Ultrasound revealed an intact abdominal aortic aneurysm of diameter 4.5 cm. What should be the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Follow-up every 6 months; operate if diameter is >5.5 cm
Follow-up every 2 months; operate if diameter is >5 cm
Immediate surgical repair of the aneurysm
Follow-up every 3 months; operate if diameter is >5.5 cm

questions.solution:
The management of a patient with a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm is immediate surgical repair of the aneurysm.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm. The most important risk factor to develop AAA is atherosclerosis. In the majority of cases, it occurs below the renal arteries.

Risk factors for AAA are age, male sex, atherosclerosis, smoking history, hypertension, and connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

The patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms of abdominal pain or back pain. They might have a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation. The patients are hemodynamically stable in case of an intact aneurysm. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm should be suspected in a patient with the triad of severe abdominal/back pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass.

Abdominal ultrasound can be used, but only a CT scan is useful in the diagnosis of an aneurysm.

Treatment:

Surgical repair of AAA is indicated in

  • Symptomatic patients/ patients with a ruptured aneurysm
  • Asymptomatic patients if the diameter is >5.5 cm
  • Rapidly enlarging AAA, increasing in diameter by >0.5 cm within 6 months
  • Those associated with peripheral artery aneurysms undergoing repair

Surgical options for the repair of aortic aneurysms are endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and open aneurysm repair. EVAR is preferred over open aneurysm repair in current practice.

The other options are incorrect. The frequency for follow-up is every 6 months if the AAA has a diameter of <5.5 cm. 

Related Pearl: Indications for operative repair of thoracic aortic aneurysm

Clinical scenario Indication for operative repair
Symptomatic aneurysm Any size
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5.5 cm
When the diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increased > 0.5 cm per year
Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter or > 6 cm
When the diameter of descending  aortic aneurysm has increased  > 1 cm per year
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter in patients with Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve 4-5cm

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with hyperpigmented areas in both axillae, as shown below. She also complained of irregular menstruation and fatigue. On examination, her BMI is 32, and there are signs of hyperandrogenism. Identify the false statement about the finding seen in the image below.

choices.text: Histopathology shows an increased number of melanocytes.
It can be associated with an internal malignancy.
Application of salicylic acid improves the appearance.

questions.solution:
The finding in the image is acanthosis nigricans, and the false statement is option B. Pigmentation is due to hyperkeratosis, and there is no increase in melanocyte numbers or melanin production. 

 Acanthosis nigricans (AN) is a dermatosis characterized by symmetrical darkening of the skin of intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. The skin is thickened, has a vel­vety texture, and may be studded by skin tags.

Acanthosis nigricans can be benign or malignant. Benign AN is very common, while malignant AN is rare and reflects internal cancer, most commonly GI cancers (option C). The familial variant is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. (option A)

Histology shows hyperkeratosis and finger‐like upward projections of der­mal papillae (papillomatosis).

Obesity (≥30 kg/m2) and insulin resistance are the most common associations with AN. Familial AN is rare and transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait. Other conditions associated with AN are:

  • Diabetes 
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Drug-induced- hormones, insulin, nicotinic acid, systemic corticos­teroids, testosterone, and exogenous estrogens, including oral contraceptives.
  • HAIR‐AN syndrome
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Wilson syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gallbladder and bile duct cancer
  • Bladder cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Gynecological cancer

Management:
Treatment of the underlying condition is the mainstay. AN associated with obesity responds to dietary restriction and weight loss. Drug-induced AN resolves after discontinuation of the drug. The cosmetic appear­ance of the condition can be treated with: 

  • Topical retinoids - reduce hyperkeratosis
  • Topical keratolytics like salicylic acid – improve the appearance by reducing hyperkeratosis (option D)
  • Oral isotretinoin for extensive cases

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

Cutaneous markers and their commonly associated internal malignancy:

pancreatic islet cell adenoma

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome. The physician performs a clinical test, where direct compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs. Which of the following clinical tests is being performed?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is Durkan's test or carpal compression test.

Clinical tests in carpal tunnel syndrome include the reproduction of sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pain by performing the following tests:

  • Durkan's test - By applying direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds.
  • Tinel's test (sign) - By percussing the median nerve.
  • Phalen's test - By holding the wrist in flexion for about 60 seconds.

The following image shows Phalen's test:

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies can be done in patients with atypical symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome. The tests will show slowing of nerve conduction across the wrist.

Carpal tunnel syndrome usually presents at an age of 40-50 years. The common risk factors are pregnancy, rheumatoid disease, renal failure, and gout.

Most of the patients present with burning pain, tingling, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve. The symptoms worsen with activity and at night. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed and shaking the arm relieve the pain.

Night pain and pregnancy-related symptoms can be reduced by using splints to prevent wrist flexion. Temporary relief from pain can be attained using steroid injection and is a diagnostic tool also.

In patients with an intermediate and chronic syndrome, an early carpal tunnel release can be performed. This surgery is beneficial in most patients and maximum improvement is seen in 6 months after the release.

Other options:

Option D- Semmes-Weinstein monofilament test measures the response to a touching sensation of the monofilaments using a numerical quantity. It is used to detect peripheral nerve injuries and compression syndromes.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

questions.text: A 33 year old woman is on treatment for infertility. Microscopic examination of her cervical mucus specimen is shown below. Which of the following can be inferred about this phase of the patient’s uterine cycle?

choices.text: Beginning of a new cycle after menstruation

questions.solution:
The given image shows ferning pattern of cervical mucus which is indicative of the high estrogen levels around the time of ovulation in the menstrual cycle. Hence, LH surge is the correct inference among the given options.

Cervical mucus is normally thick and protects the uterus from ascending infections. But around the time of ovulation, it becomes thin and stretchy under the influence of estrogen. It has a higher concentration of sodium chloride and shows a ferning pattern when it is dried on a slide and observed under the microscope.

Other options:

Option C:  Ferning is a feature of mid-cycle and not the beginning of a new cycle.

Options B and D: Corpus luteum secreting progesterone and low FSH levels are features of luteal phase of menstrual cycle.

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking Bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with complaints of a lesion in the lower eyelid. She says that the lesion was initially like a bump and now it is ulcerated. She is a farmer by occupation. On examination, an ulcerative lesion with raised and pearly white edge is seen in the lower eyelid of the right eye. The biopsy was taken from the lesion and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of cell nests. In the periphery of the cell nest, the cells are arranged in the palisading pattern. This is diagnostic of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma is the malignant tumor of the epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis.

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face.

BCC can be divided into localized and generalized. The localized can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic- account for the majority of BCC
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented
  • Naevoid.

Generalized can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative.

The characteristic finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests.

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery.

Other options

Option A- Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the malignancy of the keratinizing cells of the epidermis. It is associated with exposure to UV radiation and chronic inflammation (chronic sinus tracts, pre-existing scars, osteomyelitis, and burns).

The microscopy of SCC consists of irregular masses of squamous epithelium. They may show keratin production.

Below image shows the microscopic appearance of SCC.

Option B- Marjolin's ulcer- It is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that appears on a pre-existing scar.

Option D- Molluscum contagiosum consists of multiple pink pruritic papules on the skin and mucous membranes with central umbilication. Microscopically it shows the presence of cytoplasmic inclusions in the cells of stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.

Below images show the macroscopic and microscopic appearance of molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the emergency department following several episodes of blood-stained vomitus. The patient reported that the symptoms started after attempts of forceful retching after a binge-eating episode. Her endoscopy finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Mallory-Weiss tears. The given clinical scenario describes bulimia, which is a disorder in which the patient first indulges in binge eating and then vomits out the food. Forceful vomiting in bulimia may lead to Mallory-Weiss tears.

Mallory-Weiss tears are longitudinal mucosal tears near the gastroesophageal junction.

It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Mallory-Weiss tear

  1. Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting
  2. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy
  3. Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails
  4. High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail

Option A: Barrett's esophagus presents clinically with features similar to GERD. The patients complain of heartburn, dysphagia, and regurgitation of sour-tasting gastric contents, most often post-prandially.

Option B: Esophageal varices are tortuous dilated veins within the mucosa and submucosa of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach. Variceal hemorrhage is an emergency that can be treated medically by inducing splanchnic vasoconstriction or endoscopically by sclerotherapy, balloon tamponade, or variceal ligation.

Option C: Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural tearing and rupture of the distal esophagus. This catastrophic event produces severe mediastinitis and generally requires surgical intervention. The patients initially present with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with severe acute pain abdomen. Her past history is significant for a uterine fibroid. On examination, her temperature is 38.5°C and the uterus is tender. Investigations revealed leukocytosis and elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, there is a severe acute pain abdomen with fever and elevated leukocyte count in a 28-week pregnant woman with fibroid. Hence the most likely diagnosis is red degeneration of fibroid.

Red degeneration is the most common complication of fibroids in pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. Key clinical features in this condition are:

  • Low-grade fever
  • Tender uterus on palpation
  • Elevated leukocytes
  • Elevated ESR

The diagnosis is confirmed with an ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Other options

Option A - Calcareous degeneration of fibroid is associated with deposition of phosphates and carbonates in the periphery along the course of the vessels. It is seen in old patients with long-standing myomas. They are described as 'womb-stones' in graveyards. They can be detected on a plain X-ray of the abdomen.

Option B - Sarcomatous change of fibroid is rare in women <40 years of age. It is more commonly seen in a postmenopausal woman, who presents with a tumor which grows suddenly, causing pain and postmenopausal bleeding.

Option D - Torsion of fibroid is seen with pedunculated fibroids and can present with abdominal pain in pregnancy. However, it is not associated with fever and elevated leukocytes.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Complications of pregnancy due to fibroids

  • Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage
  • Preterm labor
  • Abnormal presentation
  • Accidental hemorrhage
  • Dystocic labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Uterine inversion

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her college roommate with fever since one day, neck pain, and altered mental status. On examination, she has neck
stiffness and a non-blanching erythematous rash on her extremities. Meningitis is suspected, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis reveals gram-negative diplococcus. The roommate mentions that the patient often volunteers as a teaching assistant in an 8th-standard class, but has not been to work for the past 10 days since she just returned from a trip overseas. Which of the following control measures is most appropriate after confirming the diagnosis?

choices.text: Rifampin prophylaxis for the pregnant nurse who performed initial vital signs measurement
Ciprofloxacin prophylaxis for patient’s roommate even if she has completed a full set of meningococcal vaccines
Rifampin prophylaxis for all the 8th standard students
Ciprofloxacin prophylaxis for all the 8th standard students

questions.solution:
The presence of gram-negative diplococcus on CSF analysis suggests meningococcal meningitis, and ciprofloxacin prophylaxis should be given to the patient’s roommate even if she has been vaccinated against meningococcus.

Prophylaxis should be given to all the contacts at the same time, ideally within 24 hours after the case is diagnosed. This is done to prevent further infection and spread of the meningococci from untreated contacts. Prophylaxis given later than 14 days after onset of illness is of limited or no value.

Drugs used for prophylaxis:

  • Ceftriaxone IV or IM single dose - highly effective for all age groups and safe in pregnancy.
  • Ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin - highly effective, can be given orally, not recommended in pregnancy.
  • Rifampin - effective but not recommended in pregnancy. 

Antibiotic prophylaxis is usually given to:

  • Persons who are intimate and/or household contacts, child care, and preschool contacts.
  • Health care workers who have been directly exposed to respiratory secretions. (Example- mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, endotracheal intubation, or endotracheal tube management).

Other options:

Option A: Rifampin is contraindicated in pregnancy. The nurse is not directly exposed to respiratory secretions, she does not require prophylaxis.

Options C and D: Usually, members of wider communities like at schools or colleges, are not offered prophylaxis.

questions.text: When can a patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock be discharged?

choices.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.solution:
A patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock can be discharged after the return of appetite. 

Criteria for the discharge of patients recovering from dengue:

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs
  • Platelet count >50,000/cu.mm
  • Return of appetite
  • Adequate urine output
  • Visible clinical improvement
  • Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.text: A nulliparous woman presented with amenorrhoea and galactorrhea. She also complains of frequent episodes of headache and vomiting. She is currently taking treatment for infertility. Her pregnancy test was negative. Which type of visual defect can this patient develop?
questions.solution:
This patient can develop heteronymous bitemporal hemianopia.

The symptoms of amenorrhoea, galactorrhea, and infertility are suggestive of hyperprolactineamia. Frequent episodes of headache and vomiting are suggestive of a tumor. Hence, these symptoms are most likely due to prolactinoma which is a pituitary tumor. This can cause compression of the optic chiasma and injure the nasal fibers of both sides leading to bitemporal hemianopia.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common triggering factor for the skin lesion shown in the image below?

choices.text: Contact with irritants like poison ivy

questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic target lesions of Erythema multiforme. It is most commonly associated with a preceding herpes simplex infection (facial or genital).

Target lesions, also known as bull's-eye lesions are a type of rash with a central clearing. They can appear on any part of the body, including the face, upper chest, back, arms, legs, hands, feet, and mucous membranes. They are a typical feature of erythema multiforme, a condition that often resolves in three to six weeks. Erythema multiforme lesions are annular, with a violaceous centre, pink halo, and pale ring. They are usually not painful but may cause a burning sensation. Target lesions are also a typical feature of Lyme disease, where they are known as erythema migrans.

Target lesions have three zones:

  • The central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  • Middle paler zone of edema, and
  • The outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Atypical target lesions have only two of the three zones.

Erythema multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis that results from a cell‐mediated hypersensitivity reaction. It presents as a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic form -acral iris or target lesions. These lesions may involve the palms or trunk. The oral and genital mucosa can also be involved, and are associated with erosions.

The common triggers are

  • Herpes simplex infection (most common)
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy: carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia (Option B)
  • Drug reactions: sulfonamides, rifampicin, penicillins, hydantoin derivatives (Option C)
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), Sarcoidosis, Polyarteritis Nodosa

Topical agents like poison ivy can also trigger Erythema multiforme-like reactions but it is not the most common cause (Option A).

The image below shows typical target lesions:

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

 

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell syndrome)
% Body Surface-area

Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

questions.text: A 53-year-old fisherman presented with complaints of blood in urine. He had frequent and burning micturition for the past few days. Urine culture was negative. He then underwent diagnostic cystoscopy and urinary bladder biopsy is shown below. This condition predisposes to which of the following types of bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the eggs of Schistosomia hematobium in the urinary bladder. The given scenario describes hemorrhagic cystitis caused by Schistosoma hematobium. This infection is a predisposing factor for the development of squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder.

Schistosoma haematobium infections in endemic areas (Egypt, Sudan) are an established risk to develop urothelial carcinomas. 

The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response that induces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia, dysplasia, and neoplasia.

The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response that induces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia, dysplasia, or, neoplasia. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common bladder cancer to occur in patients infected with Schistosoma hematobium. Other bladder cancers that may develop include urothelial or glandular (the least common type).

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

Histological subtype Risk factors

Exposure to aniline dyes

Pelvic irradiation

Inherited cancer syndromes:

  • Lynch syndrome
  • Hereditary retinoblastoma
  • Costello syndrome
