  • Activating mutations in RAS and PI-3 kinase
  • Disruption of p53 and RB genes in muscle-invasive cancers

questions.text: The intravenous urogram of a 5-year-old girl is given below. Identify the characteristic sign seen.
questions.solution:
The characteristic sign seen in the given intravenous urogram is the cobra head sign(spring onion sign) due to a ureterocele. 

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter and affects females more often than males. They are mostly detected on routine prenatal screening, or as an incidental finding on imaging studies in adults.

If they present clinically, they usually present with an infection in children, whereas in adults, they can present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’ or ‘adder head’ sign or 'spring onion sign'. It refers to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim of ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter.

Other options:

Option A: Drooping lily sign is a urographic sign in some patients with a duplicated collecting system. It is shown below.

 

Option C: Banana sign is an ultrasound sign in open spina bifida. The fetal head at the level of the posterior fossa demonstrates the anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna. It is shown in the image below.

 

Option D: Corkscrew appearance is seen on barium swallow in diffuse esophageal spasm.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a progressive blurring of vision in his left eye. He said that a branch of a plant injured his eye 1 week ago while working in his field. On examination, an ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Microscopy of the ulcer scraping showed branched septate hyphae. He was started on natamycin 5% eye drops. Which adjuvant drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. The adjuvant drug that can be given to this patient is atropine sulfate eye drops.

Fungal corneal ulcers are usually caused due to injury to the eye with vegetable matter. The signs are more pronounced but the symptoms are mild. 

Examination findings include:

  • Dry-looking ulcer with feathery margins
  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessely's immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes
  • Satellite lesions
  • Thick, non-sterile hypopyon

Specific treatment of fungal corneal ulcer:

  • Topical drugs: Natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops against Aspergillus and Fusarium and nystatin against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Oral ketoconazole or voriconazole for ulcers that are severe with hypopyon, perforated, or with suspicion of endophthalmitis.

Non-specific supportive treatment:

  • Atropine (1%) drops or ointment should be instilled in the affected eye two or three times a day to prevent complications like ciliary spasm posterior synechiae formation.
  • Local heat

Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal corneal ulcers because fungi, which are usually symbiotic saprophytes under normal conditions, become facultative pathogens in the presence of steroids and can cause perforation.

Image showing a fungal corneal ulcer with feathery margins and a non-sterile hypopyon:

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old asthma female patient comes to the clinic because she has been experiencing daily daytime exacerbations. She also complains of exacerbations of asthma during nights to be two per week approximately.  Her regular medications include a salbutamol inhaler and a daily low dose of inhaled corticosteroid. On examination, her BP is found to be 120/80, pulse rate is 94 bpm. Which of the following medications should be added to her regimen?
questions.solution:
Daily daytime exacerbations and >1/week nighttime symptoms indicate the patient has moderate persistent asthma. Long-acting bronchodilators (LABA) should be added to her regimen.

Step 1 (intermittent) As needed low dose ICS + Formoterol
Step 2 (mild persistent) Daily low dose ICS
Step 3 (moderate persistent) Daily low dose ICS + LABA
Step 4 (severe persistent) Medium dose ICS + LABA +/- add-on therapy
Step 5 High dose ICS + LABA + oral steroids +/- add-on therapy

LABA - Long-acting Beta 2 Agonists, ICS - Inhaled corticosteroids
Add-on therapy includes long-acting anticholinergics, leukotriene antagonists, mast cell stabilizers, methylxanthines and antibodies.

Drugs used in the treatment of bronchial asthma

Bronchodilators

  • Beta-2 sympathomimetics: Salmeterol, Formoterol
  • Methylxanthines: Theophylline, Aminophylline
  • Anticholinergics: Ipratropium bromide, Tiotropium bromide

Anti-inflammatory

  • Corticosteroids (Inhalational): Beclomethasone, Budesonide, Fluticasone
  • Corticosteroids (Systemic): Prednisolone, Hydrocortisone
  • Mast cell stabilizers: Sodium cromoglycate, Ketotifen
  • Leukotriene antagonists: Montelukast, Zafirlukast
  • anti-IgE - Omalizumab
  • anti-IL5 - Mepolizumab, Reslizumab
  • anti-IL4 receptor - Dupilumab

Important Update - According to GINA 2019, Short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABA) have no role in treating acute exacerbations. Even though SABA provides short-term relief of symptoms, there is strong evidence that SABA only treatment increases the risk of exacerbations. 
GINA now recommends that symptom-driven (in mild asthma), a daily dose of ICS (inhaled corticosteroids) containing treatment to reduce the risk of serious exacerbations. This is said to be the most important change in asthma management in 30 years

questions.text: A 32-year-old cyclist developed a fracture of the distal femur following a road traffic accident. During surgery, the fracture was stabilised as shown in the image below. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a rail fixator (Orthofix fixator). In this, multiple pins are inserted into the bone. These pins are then attached to different blocks which can move over a tract or rail.

Other options:

Option B - Ilizarov ring fixator - In this, pins are attached to an adjustable ring system.

Option C - Pin fixator - In this, pins are then attached to a tubular rod.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A new drug that has been discovered is said to have the potential to bring down stress levels. The psychiatry department of your medical college decides to conduct a study comparing the effects of a placebo and the experimental drug in a group of students. The lead investigator conducting the study includes more exam-going students with a higher level of stress in the control group than in the experimental group. What is the type of bias introduced here?
questions.solution:
The type of bias introduced in the given scenario is selection bias. This type of bias occurs when the investigator does not select the subjects of a study or group randomly and when group assignment is done without randomization. 

Hence, the cases and controls in the sample may not be representative of those in the general population. The case group and control group may show systematic differences; in the given example, the control group has a higher number of stressed-out, exam-going students than the case group. 

Other options:

The Hawthorne effect describes a change in the behavior of an individual that results from their awareness of being observed.

Neyman bias or prevalence-incidence bias is due to selective survival in prevalent cases; it is usually seen in fatal diseases.

Interviewer bias is a bias in which the interviewer is aware of the hypothesis and the identity of the cases and, therefore, conducts more thorough interviews for cases than the controls.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text:
A mountain climber ascends a high mountain peak. He feels short of breath because of low oxygen levels and starts hyperventilating. Which of the following structures are involved in this respiratory response?

1. Aortic body

2. Carotid sinus

3. J receptors

4. Vagal afferents

5. Nerve of Herring

6. Apneustic center

7. Respiratory center
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes hyperventilation due to decreased oxygen tension. The structures involved in this response are:

  • Peripheral chemoreceptors-
    • Aortic bodies and
    • Carotid bodies
  • Nerves carrying impulses from these centers to the medulla-
    • Vagal afferents from aortic bodies and
    • Nerve of Herring- Glossopharangeal nerve from carotid boides
  • Nucleus of tractus solitarius (NTS)- the afferent nerves relay here
  • Dorsal and ventral group of the respiratory center- receive information from NTS and increase respiratory activity leading to hyperventilation.

Other options:

Carotid sinus is a baroreceptor, whereas, carotid body is a chemoreceptor.

J receptors are sensory nerve ending that are juxtapositioned to the pulmonary capillaries. They are stimulated when pulmonary capillaries are engorged with blood/during pulmonary edema. Their stimulation induces the feeling of dyspnoea.

Apneustic center is responsible for apneustic breathing pattern- long inspirations and brief expirations. This is seen in response to head and neck injuries.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presented with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and nausea at 8 weeks of gestation. Serum β-HCG level was found to be 5500 mIU/mL. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 5 cm gestational sac in the right fallopian tube, with fetal cardiac activity. There is no evidence of bleeding or rupture. What is the preferred mode of management for this patient?

choices.text: Observation and follow-up with β-HCG measurement

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The preferred mode of management in this scenario is surgical, suitably laparoscopic salpingostomy as she has not yet started a family.

Medical vs Surgical management

For an unruptured ectopic, the preferred mode of management is medical management with an injection of methotrexate. However, surgical management is preferred when:

  • Gestational sac size >4 cm
  • Serum β-HCG levels >5000 mIU/mL
  • Fetal heart rate (FHR) present
  • Patient hemodynamically unstable

Salpingectomy vs Salpingostomy

  • For an unruptured ectopic, either procedure can be done laparoscopically.
    • Salpingectomy - removal of the fallopian tube.
      • When the family is complete or
      • A desire for sterilization.
    • Salpingostomy - incising the tube to remove the tubal gestation but leaving the remainder of the tube intact.
      • When the family is incomplete or
      • A desire to retain fertility or
      • Contralateral tube is abnormal.
  • For a ruptured ectopic only salpingectomy can be done
    • Hemodynamically stable - laparoscopically done
    • Hemodynamically unstable - laparotomy is done

Other options:

Observation and β-hCG follow-up is part of the expectant management with hopes of spontaneous resolution. It is done only in a small subset of patients with unruptured ectopic gestation. Its indications are:

  • Initial serum β-hCG level <1000 mIU/mL and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestational sac size is <4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound.
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on transvaginal ultrasound.

Note: β-hCG follow-up is not just part of expectant management, it is done after all modes of treatment (medical, surgical, and expectant) to detect persistent trophoblastic disease.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic with complaints of palpitations. He is diagnosed with tachyarrhythmia. He is started on a drug that resolves his arrhythmia. ECG taken 3 days after starting medication appears as below, with QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?

 QTc: corrected QT interval
questions.solution:
The patient has a QTc of 477 ms which indicates QT prolongation on taking the drug (normal QT- < 440 ms in males). Among the given options, QT prolongation is seen with procainamide, a Class 1A anti-arrhythmic drug.

A QT interval is slowed by a decreased heart rate. A QTc (corrected QT interval) is calculated as QT/√RR, to remove the effect of HR. Normal QTc is about 440 ms. Values of more than 440 ms in males and 450 ms in females are considered to be prolonged.

A QT prolongation can present as syncope or cardiac arrest. Prompt intravenous administration of 1-2mg magnesium sulfate is needed. It gives time to correct electrolyte imbalances and remove the offending agent.

Other anti-arrhythmic drugs associated with QT prolongation i.e (Class 1A and Class 3):

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Related Pearl: Drugs causing QT prolongation and torsades de pointes

Antiarrhythmics:

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Antimicrobials:

  • Levofloxacin

Antipsychotics:

  • Droperidol

Others:

questions.text:
Baby Divya is to celebrate her 2nd birthday in two weeks. Her mother brings her to your clinic for vaccination. The mother says that the child was 9 months old when she received vaccines previously and had completed all vaccines uptil 9 months. Which among the following vaccines should be given to the child?
  1. DPT booster- 1
  2. PCV booster
  3. Vitamin A
  4. Rotavirus
  5. MR
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the child could be given DPT booster, MR and Vitamin A at 24 months. PCV booster is given at 9 months. Rotavirus schedule would have been completed for this child at 14 weeks.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is bought to your outpatient department with complaints of bleeding gums. Investigations reveal a normal platelet count and a prolonged bleeding time. Further workup revealed a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX. What is the underlying pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX are suggestive of Bernard-Soulier syndrome. It is a disorder of platelet adhesion.

Platelet adhesion normally occurs due to interaction between Gp Ib of the platelets and von Willebrand factor (vWF) of the subendothelium of blood vessels. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the defect in Gp Ib/IX results in impaired adhesion of platelets. This causes a defect in the formation of the primary platelet plug, leading to abnormal bleeding tendency.

Other options:

Option A- Disorder of platelet aggregation - Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a disorder of platelet aggregation. It occurs because of the dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb–IIIa, which is responsible for bridge formation between the platelets by binding fibrinogen.

Option C- Disorder of platelet activation - These are characterized by the defective release of certain mediators of platelet activation, such as thromboxanes and granule-bound ADP. These include platelet storage pool disorders and Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.

Option D- Disorder of platelet production - These may include disorders involving ineffective hematopoiesis such as leukemias and bone marrow failure or they may be drug-induced.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation

(aggregation of platelets)

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings are likely to be seen in a 6-month-old infant with an isolated small ventricular septal defect?

choices.text: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound

questions.solution:
A patient with a small ventricular septal defect will have a loud pansystolic murmur.

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most commonly seen congenital cardiac lesion. This results in the shunting of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle. The affected babies do not have cyanosis.

Auscultatory findings seen in patients with VSD are:

Murmurs in VSD:

  • Small VSD- loud pansystolic murmur
  • Large VSD-
    • Pansystolic murmur of grade 1 or 2
    • Mid diastolic murmur due to increased flow across the mitral valve.
    • Pulmonary ejection systolic murmur due to increased blood flow in the pulmonary artery

Heart sounds in VSD-

  • Wide splitting of the second heart sound
  • A loud second heart sound can be heard if the pulmonary vascular resistance increases.

Small VSDs close spontaneously, most frequently during the first 2 years of life. Medium to large VSDs, VSDs in which clinical symptoms and failure to thrive cannot be controlled medically requires surgical closure of the defect.

Fixed splitting of the second heart sound indicates the presence of an atrial septal defect (ASD), not a VSD

questions.text:
Which of the following indicates the therapeutic index of a drug?

ED50 - Median effective dose

LD50 - Median lethal dose
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio. The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI in the following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 or TD50/ED50

where LD50 is the mean lethal dose, TD50 is the mean toxic dose, and ED50 is the median effective dose 

Median lethal dose (LD50) and median toxic dose (TD50)

  • LD50 is the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die.
  • In human trials, TD50 can be considered. It is the dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
  • Larger the LD50 or TD50, the safer the drug. 

Median effective dose (ED50)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect
  • ED50 is the quantity of a drug that can produce the desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

The therapeutic window refers to a range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: A 28-year-old basketball player falls while rebounding and is unable to run and jump. On examination, he has pain and weakness when extending his hip and flexing his leg. There is tenderness in the posterior aspect of the knee joint. Which muscle is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The muscle likely to be injured is semitendinosus which is marked as 2.

Semitendinosus muscle- It arises from the inferomedial impression on the upper area of the ischial tuberosity. It inserts into the upper part of the medial surface of the tibia behind the attachment of the sartorius and gracilis.

It functions as an extensor of the hip joint, flexor of the knee, and medial rotator of the leg.

Other options

Muscle marked as 1 is vastus lateralis. It is a component of the quadriceps femoris. It extends the knee.

Muscle marked 3 and 4 are the lateral and medial heads of gastrocnemius respectively. It is the plantar flexor of the foot and flexor of the knee joint.

questions.text:
A patient who is diagnosed with Grave's disease is posted for subtotal thyroidectomy. Identify the image which corresponds to the procedure.

Note: White portion enclosed in the dotted line corresponds to the surgically removed portion, while the colored region of the image denotes the portion left behind in the body after surgery.
questions.solution:
Image B indicates subtotal thyroidectomy. This procedure involves subtotal lobectomy of both the lobes and isthmusectomy. Subtotal and total thyroidectomies are usually done in Grave's disease.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: You are called to examine a 1-day-old boy because the nurse is concerned that he is jaundiced. He was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 19-year-old G1P1 after a full-term, uncomplicated pregnancy. The mother had no illnesses during her pregnancy and did not use tobacco, alcohol, or drugs. There was no significant past medical or family history. On examination, the infant is mildly jaundiced, has notable microcephaly. The liver and spleen are enlarged. Neurologic examination is notable for the lack of a startle response to loud noise. CT of his head reveals periventricular calcifications. You explain to the child’s mother that the virus involved is commonly transmitted via transplacental infection. Which of the following is a feature of the likely etiological agent?

choices.text: Nuclear replication in the host cell

questions.solution:
The most likely etiology here is cytomegalovirus (CMV), and its nuclear replication occurs in the host cell. The clinical scenario of jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, hearing loss, and microcephaly with periventricular calcifications on CT scan are features suggestive of CMV infection in newborns.

CMVs have a DNA genome, and an icosahedral protein capsid, which is surrounded by a lipoprotein envelope. It replicates in the host cell nucleus and is associated with the production of large intranuclear inclusions and smaller cytoplasmic inclusions. It is transmitted by close contact, from mother to fetus in utero, from the mother’s genital tract during delivery, and even from maternal breast milk.

Features of CMV inclusion disease of newborns include:

  • Intrauterine growth retardation
  • Jaundice
  • Petechial rash
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microcephaly

Primary CMV infection of older children and adults is usually asymptomatic but occasionally causes an infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome. Congenital infection can result in intrauterine death of the fetus. It is the most common viral pathogen complicating organ transplantation recipients.

Diagnosis of Cytomegalic inclusion disease:

  • Lab findings- elevated alanine aminotransferase, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, hemolysis, thrombocytopenia.
  • CSF- elevated protein levels.
  • Demonstration of CMV in saliva or urine samples by PCR amplification or culture.
  • CT of head - microcephaly with periventricular calcifications.

Treatment for symptomatic neonates is with valganciclovir orally or by gastrostomy tube for 6 months. Asymptomatic infants with CMV infection should not receive antiviral treatment.

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever for 3 days associated with chills and rigors. His temperature is 102°F. Cardiac auscultation shows a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region. His past history is significant for prosthetic valve surgery 2 years back. Which of the following organism is the most likely cause for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Patient developing endocarditis 2 years after prosthetic valve surgery suggests late-onset endocarditis. In such cases, the most common causative organism is streptococci.

Fever plus a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region with a history of prosthetic valve surgery is strongly suggestive of infective endocarditis as the likely diagnosis. 

Clinical features of infective endocarditis include:

  • Fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain, and arthralgias
  • Cardiac murmurs, mycotic aneurysm, heart failure
  • Splenomegaly, splenic infarction, renal infarction, glomerulonephritis
  • Stroke, Meningitis
  • Vertebral osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, and abscesses

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding.
  • Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules are usually found on the distal pads of the digits as shown below.

 

  • Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles as shown below.

 

  • Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers as shown below.

Other options-

Option B: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing infective endocarditis overall.

Option C: Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoS) is the most common group of organisms causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery).

Option D: HACEK organisms cause subacute infective endocarditis.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of a lump in her right breast for the past 1 year. She had her last menstrual cycle 5 years back. The doctor examines the breast and finds a 2cm X 2.5 cm lump in the upper outer quadrant. It is hard, non-tender, and movable. The doctor orders a mammogram and the radiologist reports the lump as BIRADS category 4a. What will be the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Follow up with MRI after 3 months
Follow up with MRI after 6 months
Perform surgical excision of the lump
Advise for biopsy of the lump

questions.solution:
The management of a patient with BIRADs category 4a is to advise for the biopsy of the lump.

Category 4 of BIRADS can be further divided as

Category Management Likelihood of cancer
4a- Low suspicion for malignancy Biopsy    > 2% to ≤ 10% 
4b- Moderate suspicion for malignancy > 10% to ≤ 50% 
 4c- High suspicion for malignancy  > 50% to < 95%

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy  ≥95% Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy-proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

Related Pearl: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with a high fever and noisy breathing. The child had a cough and cold for the past few days. A lateral x-ray of the neck showed a soft tissue swelling and widening of the prevertebral shadow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the widening of prevertebral shadow on a lateral x-ray of the neck in a 2-year-old child suggests a diagnosis of retropharyngeal abscess. 

An acute retropharyngeal abscess commonly occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils, causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes, which leads to abscess formation. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is uncommon and usually occurs secondary to trauma.

The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis (extended stiff neck), and unilateral swelling on the midline of the posterior pharyngeal wall. The lateral view of the radiograph shows soft tissue swelling and the widening of the prevertebral shadow. The extent of the abscess can be visualised on a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

Treatment is usually done by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics. Tracheostomy is required in cases of a large abscess causing obstruction to the airway or leading to laryngeal oedema. 

The image below shows a retropharyngeal abscess seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck:

Other options:

Option A - Parapharyngeal abscess can occur from acute and chronic infections of the tonsils like dental infections, Bezold abscess, petrositis, trauma to the neck, and infections of the parotid, retropharyngeal and submaxillary spaces. Patients with anterior compartment involvement present with prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar pillar, trismus, and swelling of the parotid region. Patients with posterior compartment involvement present with bulges of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar; paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII and sympathetic chain; and swelling of the parotid region. Symptoms common to both compartments are fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis, and signs of toxaemia. The extent of a lesion can be revealed by a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck. 

The image below shows an enhanced CT scan revealing a large mass involving the left parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal spaces, causing significant airway narrowing.

Option C- Peritonsillar abscess/quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. It presents with severe pain in the throat, fever, chills and rigours, and a hot potato voice. There is congestion and swelling of the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. On examination, a bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil can be seen. Uvula may be pushed to the opposite side. The presence and the extent of the abscess can be identified on a contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI. 

The image below shows a peritonsillar abscess.

Option D- Acute epiglottitis is an acute inflammatory condition involving the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoids (supraglottic structures). It is usually caused by Haemophilus influenzae and group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. The symptoms have an acute onset with a rapid progression. These include fever, sore throat, dysphagia, dyspnea, and stridor. Indirect laryngoscopy shows oedema and congestion of the supraglottic structure. A lateral x-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis (thumb sign).

Below is an image showing the thumb sign on a radiograph:

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 27-year-old man came to the clinic with complaints of weakness in the lower limbs and unsteadiness of gait for the past 1 month. Detailed workup revealed hemangioblastomas in the left cerebellar hemisphere and the spinal cord. There is history of similar problems in the patient's brother, aunt, and father. In view of the occurrence of multiple hemangioblastomas and significant family history, an abdominal ultrasound was advised. It revealed the presence of multiple renal and pancreatic cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple hemangioblastomas with multiple renal and pancreatic cysts is most likely to be von Hippel- Lindau disease.

It is an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by the development of highly vascularized tumors in multiple organs. These include:

  • Haemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system
  • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Renal cysts- develop into clear renal cell cancer.
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Ovary cystadenoma
  • Epididymal cystadenoma

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

VHL: von Hippel–Lindau

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: On a cold winter night, a 2-week old neonate is brought by her concerned parents who observed some skin changes. On examination, red and blue lacy, reticulated patterns can be observed on the trunk and lower limbs. The baby is otherwise healthy and alert. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child with lacy, reticulated red or blue cutaneous vascular patterns over the body surface as seen in the image above after exposure to cold temperatures is likely to have cutis marmorata.

This condition is usually is seen in an infant who is exposed to low environmental temperatures. It occurs as a result of an exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response. This response disappears as the children age but may also be present in older children.

It does not require treatment. 

 

Other options:

Option B- Salmon patch or naevus simplex is a small, pale pink vascular macule that occurs most commonly on the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. It occurs in normal newborns.

Option C- Neonatal pustular melanosis is a benign lesion characterized by the presence of superficial pustules, ruptured pustules, and hyperpigmented macules.

Option D- Harlequin color change- When the infant is placed on one side, the upper half of the body becomes pale and the dependent half becomes dark red. The color change lasts only for a few minutes. Changing the infant's position may reverse the pattern. It occurs due to the impairment of the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of several episodes of seizures. During the examination, the baby was found to have fair skin, blue eyes, and developmental delay. The laboratory tests revealed elevated levels of phenylalanine and was diagnosed with phenylketonuria. The infant was placed on a low-phenylalanine diet with tyrosine supplementation, but the baby continued to have neurological symptoms. A defect in which of the following enzymes would best explain the given condition?
questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria can be caused by a defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase or dihydropteridin reductase. In this case, restriction of phenylalanine and supplementation of tyrosine did not improve symptoms, so the defect in dihydropteridin reductase best explains the condition.

Dihydropteridine reductase is required for the conversion of dihydrobiopterin to tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). BH4 is the coenzyme for phenylalanine hydroxylase, tyrosine hydroxylase, and tryptophan hydroxylase. In addition to decreased levels of tyrosine, these patients also have decreased levels of catecholamines and 5-hydroxytryptophan. Therefore the symptoms do not improve with the restriction of phenylalanine alone. It also requires supplementation with BH4, dihydroxyphenylalanine, and 5-hydroxytryptophan.

Phenylketonuria

It is the most common inborn error of amino acid metabolism. It commonly occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria). Less commonly it can also occur due to a defect in dihydropteridin reductase. These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. The patient develops clinical features due to elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine.

Clinical features include intellectual disability, developmental delay, and seizures. Fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes are seen due to tyrosine deficiency which is required for melanin synthesis.

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of phenylalanine. Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test, and Tandem mass spectrometry can help in the diagnosis.

A diet low in phenylalanine and supplementation of tyrosine can prevent the mental retardation of PKU. Other treatment options are large neutral amino acid supplementation, sapropterin (commercially available BH4), and the use of the enzyme substitute pegvaliase (phenylalanine ammonia-lyase).

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with loss of memory, urinary incontinence, and decreased ability to perform day-to-day activities. She is oriented to time and place, but not to person. On gait assessment, you notice a hypokinetic magnetic gait. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of dementia, hypokinetic magnetic gait, and urinary incontinence seen in this patient suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of

  • Dementia (mostly executive function),
  • Ataxic or apractic gait, and
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too).

It is classified as idiopathic (primary) or symptomatic (secondary) occurring due to prior brain infection, injury, radiation, or hemorrhage. 

The etiology is poorly understood but is thought to be related to the hyperdynamic flow of CSF in the aqueduct, reduced compliance of the subarachnoid space, increased CSF pulse pressure, and reduced reabsorption of CSF. 

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test, which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting: It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options:

Option B - Frontotemporal dementia is a group of syndromes that is characterized by frontotemporal lobar degeneration. The most common variant, the behavioral variant, presents with social and emotional dysfunction which manifests as apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, loss of empathy, overeating, and may have deficits in executive control.

Option C - Parkinson disease is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by tremors at rest, rigidity, bradykinesia, gait dysfunction, postural instability, speech difficulty, swallowing impairment, and autonomic disturbances. 

Option D - Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a degenerative brain disorder due to prions that leads to rapid mental deterioration, usually within a few months with associated myoclonus and behavioral changes.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has frequent episodes of fever with a productive cough and frequent headaches. On examination, his second heart sound was prominently heard on the right side of the chest. The patient reported infertility for the past 7 years. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in the lungs of this patient?

choices.text: Dilated airways in the lower lobes
Collapse of the right lower lobe

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes Kartegener syndrome. The findings of bronchiectasis will be seen in the lung, which is dilated airways in the lower lobes.

Kartagener syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder presenting with the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus - leading to the right-sided heartbeat
  • Chronic sinusitis - leading to headaches
  • Bronchiectasis - leading to fever, excessive productive cough, and foul-smelling expectoration.

Bronchiectasis is defined as the permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles caused by the destruction of the smooth muscle and the supporting elastic tissue by chronic necrotizing infections.

It presents as a severe, persistent cough with foul-smelling expectoration, and on occasion bloody sputum and hemoptysis. In severe cases, it may present as orthopnea, dyspnea, cor pulmonale, brain abscess, and amyloidosis.

In bronchiectasis, normal clearing mechanisms are impaired, either due to congenital causes or due to bronchial obstruction which results in pooling of secretions, secondary infection, and inflammation, often with necrosis, fibrosis, and eventually dilation of airways as shown below:

Bronchiectasis usually affects the lower lobes bilaterally, with a predilection to vertical segments and distal bronchi and bronchioles. The airways are dilated up to four times the normal size and a probe can sometimes be passed all the way to the pleural surface. On the cut surface, the bronchi appear as cystic and are filled with mucopurulent secretions as shown below.

Other options:

Option A - Panacinar emphysema is seen in cases of α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

Option C - Collapse of the right lower lobe is not associated with bronchiectasis.

Option D - Interstitial fibrosis is seen in diseases like idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A researcher wants to combine twenty different clinical trials to assess the effect of a drug used for Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following best explains the type of study conducted?
questions.solution:
The type of study described here is a meta-analysis that involves combining results from multiple studies on a given topic.

Meta-analysis is the quantitative analysis of the results obtained from a systematic review. A systematic review uses certain inclusion and exclusion criteria to objectively review multiple studies. In the hierarchy of evidence, meta-analysis along with systematic reviews are grouped in evidence synthesis which is considered the best evidence. By combining the results of multiple studies, the power of analysis and generalizability is increased.

Other options

Option A - A cohort study is a type of analytical study that is done to support or refute an association between a suspected cause and disease. It can be prospective, retrospective, or a combination of the two. The cohorts are selected prior to the appearance of the disease being studied in prospective studies. In retrospective studies, the outcome has already occurred before the start of the study.

Option B - A case-control study is another type of analytical study. It is often called retrospective studies. It is a common method used to test causal hypothesis initially. It proceeds from effect to cause. Both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. It has a control and comparison group.

Option D - A randomized control trial (RCT) is used to evaluate methods of treatment and prevention by scientific techniques. By randomization, the participants are divided into two groups - study and control. The former group receives the procedure or intervention while the latter does. This helps to eliminate bias and ensures comparability. 

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A physician is evaluating for speech abnormalities in a patient with a cerebrovascular accident. During the examination, it is found that the patient is unable to understand the written or spoken words. He speaks fluently, but what he speaks cannot be understood by the doctor and relatives. It also consists of some new words. Repetition is also impaired. Damage to which of the following areas will lead to this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
The areas marked in the image are:

1- Middle temporal gyrus

2- Inferior frontal gyrus

3- Superior temporal gyrus

4- Superior frontal gyrus

The clinical scenario shows that comprehension and repetition are impaired in the patient while fluency is intact. This is seen in Wernicke’s aphasia. The structure marked as 3 is the Wernicke's area which is the superior temporal gyrus.

Broca's area (Brodmann area 44, 45) is present in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. A lesion in this area results in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, comprehension of language is intact, and speech fluency, repetition, and naming are impaired.

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

questions.text: A male baby was born by a cesarean section for obstructed labor. On examination of the baby, the anterior and posterior fontanels were wide open, the sutures were widely separated and the occiput was very prominent. MRI imaging showed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the dilation of the fourth ventricle with hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis. The diagnosis is likely to be Dandy-Walker syndrome. It is a congenital malformation that involves cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, hydrocephalus, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. It is associated with the atresia of the foramen of Magendie.

Other options

Option A- Mega cisterna magna can also cause hydrocephalus. It is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis.

Option B- Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, ataxia, breathing abnormalities including episodic apnea and hyperpnea. Imaging will show the presence of cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and molar tooth sign (a deepening of the interpeduncular fossa with thick and straight superior cerebellar peduncles)

Option C- Chiari malformation is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain. It consists of the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Often, there is also an associated developmental abnormality of the bones of the skull base leading to a small posterior fossa.

questions.text: A man was stuck inside a building that caught fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. Burn injuries were minimal. Which of the following postmortem changes is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The person died of suffocation due to smoke. This indicates carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, which causes cherry-red postmortem hypostasis.

Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin as compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced. It can cause anaemic hypoxia. The binding of CO to haemoglobin results in cherry-red discolouration.

Other options:

Option A- Greenish-blue postmortem hypostasis is seen in poisoning due to hydrogen sulphide poisoning.

Option B- Pugilistic attitude is seen when muscle proteins are coagulated at high temperatures. Since this person did not die of burn injuries, a pugilistic attitude will not be seen.

Option D- Rigor mortis is not delayed. On the contrary, it may have a rapid onset because of heat.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

questions.text: A middle-aged lady was referred to a dermatology clinic for a lesion on her left cheek as shown in the image below. On diascopy, apple jelly nodules were seen. Skin biopsy showed tubercles with absent central caseation surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes in the superficial dermis.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows numerous reddish-brown papules with an elevated scaly surface and scarring. These lesions, together with the features of apple jelly nodules on diascopy and tubercles with absent central caseation, point towards a diagnosis of lupus vulgaris.

Lupus vulgaris is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary form of cutaneous tuberculosis which occurs in previously sensitized individuals. The characteristic lesion is a plaque, consisting of soft, reddish-brown papules. It grows by slow peripheral extension, becoming discoid in shape with areas of atrophy. The lesions are acquired either by hematogenous spread or by direct inoculation. 

There are five clinical variants of lupus vulgaris:

  • Plaque form
  • Ulcerative and mutilating forms
  • Vegetating form
  • Tumor-like forms
  • Papular and nodular form

On diascopy, characteristic 'apple jelly nodules' are seen. Histology shows tubercles with scanty or absent central caseation, surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells, present in the superficial dermis. Usually, tubercle bacilli are scanty or absent. Treatment is by standard multidrug antituberculosis therapy.

Complications include scarring, contractures, and tissue destruction. Malignant changes (most commonly, squamous cell carcinomas) are known to arise in longstanding lupus vulgaris.

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris- Lesions are due to inflammation of the pilosebaceous unit. It can present with open and closed comedones and/or papules, pustules, and nodules.

Option C: Tuberculoid leprosy- Typical lesions are erythematous, copper-colored, or purple plaques, with raised edges sloping towards a hypopigmented center.

Option D: Discoid lupus erythematosus: It is an inflammatory disorder of the skin. The lesions are characterized by well‐defined red, scaly patches of variable size.

The image below shows how diascopy is done:

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic smoker has recently been discharged from the hospital after being admitted for an acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. He is now motivated to quit smoking and wants to know about medications that will help him with quitting. All of the following can be used in him, except ______.
questions.solution:
Mirtazapine is not used in smoking cessation.

Mirtazapine is a serotonin receptor antagonist, used in the treatment of major depression.

Pharmacological methods to quit smoking:

1. Nicotine replacement therapy - is highly effective, because it reduces withdrawal symptoms. It is available as - 

  • Nicotine gum - available over the counter and releases nicotine via buccal absorption. One to two pieces of gum per hour up to a maximum of 24 pieces per day can be used
  • Nicotine lozenges - useful for patients who smoke a cigarette immediately on awakening
  • Nicotine patches - administered every morning and produce blood concentrations of nicotine about half those of smoking
  • Nicotine nasal spray - available only by prescription, produces nicotine concentrations in the blood comparable to smoking a cigarette and is helpful for heavily dependent smokers However, adverse effects like rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing are experienced by most patients
  • Nicotine inhalers deliver 4 mg per cartridge and resultant nicotine levels are low

2. Non-nicotine medications:

1st line:

  • Bupropion - both dopaminergic and adrenergic actions. 
  • Varenicline - a partial agonist for nicotinic Ach receptor. Side effects include sleep disturbances, depression, and increased suicidal tendencies.

2nd line:

  • Nortriptyline - tricyclic antidepressant which appears to be effective for smoking cessation.
  • Clonidine - alpha-agonist which decreases sympathetic activity and thus decreases withdrawal symptoms.

It is recommended to offer nicotine patches or varenicline along with counselling and behavior therapy as a part of the cessation attempt. Acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis are valuable "teachable moments" for the patient and can help reaffirm the smoking cessation message serving as a springboard for a cessation attempt.

questions.text:
A patient of a road traffic accident needs blood transfusion. The doctor administers the blood brought by the nurse without verifying the blood group. The patient dies of transfusion reaction due to blood group incompatibility. The punishment for this act is described under which section of the BNS (IPC)?

BNS- Bharatiya Nayaya Sanhita; IPC - Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the doctor fails to verify the blood group of the blood to be administered. This amounts to causing death by rash or negligent act which is defined under BNS Sec 106 (304A IPC). This act can lead to a punishment of imprisonment of up to 2 years and a fine.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl complains that she has a feeling of obstruction in the nose while breathing. She has a history of frequent colds on exposure to dust. On examination, Cottle’s test is negative, and the given finding is seen. The mass does not disappear on blowing the nose. On probe testing, the mass feels soft, can be moved up and down, and does not bleed easily on probing. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of nasal obstruction in a young person with a history of allergic rhinitis along with the image showing a pink fleshy unilateral swelling in the nasal cavity is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp.

Antrochoanal polyp arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavities. 

It is usually single and unilateral which is more commonly seen in children and young adults. It has 3 parts namely:

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice. It is soft and can be moved up and down with a probe.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Other options:

Option A: Angiofibroma leads to severe and recurrent epistaxis and bleeds easily on probing. 

Option B: Hypertrophied turbinate feels firm on probe testing and cannot be moved up and down on probing.

Option C: Ethmoidal polyps are usually bilateral. They occur in adults.

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A 6-month old male child is brought to the emergency because of epistaxis for the last 2 hours. He has a history of eczema which got infected with S. aureus. He later developed petechiae in the infected area as well as on unaffected sites. He also has a history of sinusitis and bacterial pneumonia in the last month. Routine immunizations including conjugated Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and pneumococcus vaccines had been given without any untoward consequences.  Blood analysis shows HB 9.5 g/dl, normal WBC count, platelets abnormally small, and platelet count 10,000 per μl. Which of the following is wrong about the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Serum IgA and IgE levels are likely to be low

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario shows atopic dermatitis, increased susceptibility to infections, and low platelet count, suggesting a diagnosis of Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome (WAS), and option b is the incorrect statement, as IgA and IgE are elevated in this condition (not low).

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by atopic dermatitis, thrombocytopenic purpura, and increased susceptibility to infections. The WAS gene, encoding the Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome Protein (WASp), is located on the short arm of the X chromosome. The disease is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

There is a progressive loss of T cells in the peripheral blood and in the lymph nodes, with variable defects in cellular immunity and an impaired humoral immune response to polysaccharide antigens. The predominant immunoglobulin pattern is a low serum level of IgM, elevated IgA and IgE, and a normal or slightly low IgG concentration.

Patients with WAS are more susceptible to infections by mostly encapsulated bacteria like S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b (Hib), and S. aureus. Later, infections with agents such as P. jiroveci and the herpesviruses become more frequent. As the disease develops, autoimmunity and B-cell malignancy (lymphomas or leukemias) are not uncommon.

A definitive diagnosis of WAS can be made by gene sequencing to identify a mutation and by flow cytometry of the patient’s blood cells to determine if the WASp protein is expressed at normal levels.

Mild forms of the disease can be treated symptomatically - transfusions for bleeding and passive antibodies or antibiotics for bacterial infections. Severe cases require hematopoietic stem cell transfer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complains of persistently aching legs. He also complained of hearing loss. However, his blood tests reveal an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. An X-ray of the skull is given below. Which of the following malignancies is a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma is a malignant complication of this condition.

The given clinical scenario with a radiograph showing cotton-wool skull is suggestive of Paget's disease of bone.

Paget's disease is characterized by focal areas of increased bone remodelling, resulting in the overgrowth of poorly organized bone. This unbalanced process leads to osseous deformities, nerve compressions, and pathological fractures.

Paget's disease is usually seen at age >50 years. They are mostly asymptomatic but can present with a dull ache. Deformities are usually seen in the lower limbs such as bowing of the tibia or femur. They may have deformities such as bowing of bones—for instance, the tibia bends anteriorly and the femur bends anterolateral. If the skull is affected, enlargement of the skull is seen. Disorganized and increased bone deposition may lead to stenosis of various canals and foramina resulting in compression of cranial nerves, spinal cord, and nerve roots (due to spinal stenosis). Hearing loss is a fairly common feature, due to compression of the cranial nerve and otosclerosis resulting in mixed sensorineural and conductive hearing loss. Pathological fractures of the long bones may be seen. 

Investigations

Serum calcium and phosphate are usually normal. Serum alkaline phosphatase is elevated.

The x-ray findings are characteristic and appear in stages.

  • Osteolytic phase - It involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization. Radiographically, this manifests as an advancing lytic wedge on the shaft of the bone, or blade of grass, or flame-shaped lesion.
  • Sclerotic phase - Bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a thick, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone (coarse trabeculations)

Some of the radiographical signs include:

  • Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 
  • Picture-frame appearance manifests with cortical thickening and sclerosis encasing the vertebral margins.
  • Ivory vertebra sign may be seen due to diffuse and homogeneous increase in opacity of a vertebral body.
  • Osteogenesis circumscripta describes circumscribed patches of radiolucency due to osteoporosis in the skull.

The arrow mark in the following image indicates a "blade of grass/flame-shaped lesion" appearance.

The image given below depicts the Ivory vertebra sign.

Below is an image depicting the picture-frame appearance seen in vertebral bodies.

Treatment:

Medical management includes bisphosphonates, IV Zolendronate is preferred. Surgical correction is done in cases of deformities and pathological fractures.

Complications:

  • Risk of fractures due to decreased strength of bone
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Bony overgrowth leads to spinal stenosis and nerve compression
  • High output cardiac failure due to the increased blood flow to skeletal bones
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen in prolonged immobilization
  • Cranial nerve-2nd, 5th, 7th, 8th palsy is seen
  • Deafness due to nerve compression or otosclerosis
  • Malignant transformation to osteosarcoma
