questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is referred by her paediatrician for evaluation of truncal asymmetry identified by screening during a routine physical examination. She is asymptomatic and describes herself as very active in school. She has recently noticed a growth spurt. On physical examination, she is thin and her right shoulder appears to be slightly elevated compared with the left. On forward bending, a right-sided mid-thoracic prominence was noted. AP and lateral x-ray findings are given below. The Cobb angle was measured to be 30°. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS). The next step in management is bracing with a Boston brace.

AIS is the most common type of scoliosis and develops between the ages of 10-18 years. It is asymptomatic and usually identified on routine physical examination. The spine may be obviously deviated from the mid-line, or a prominence may become apparent when the patient bends forward (the Adams test).

Confirmation of the diagnosis is through full-length lateral and PA x-rays. A Cobb angle of >10° is diagnostic. It is a measure of the degree of curvature using projected lines from the top of the uppermost and bottom of the lowermost vertebral bodies.

Management of AIS

  • Observation and follow up until skeletal maturity
    • When Cobb angle <30°
  • Bracing
    • When Cobb angles are 30°-49°
  • Corrective surgery
    • When Cobb angle ≥50°

Most curves are managed with a Boston brace (thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis [TLSO]). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. It is shown in the image below.

 

Milwaukee brace (cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis [CTLSO]) is used less commonly nowadays as it is bulky and difficult to hide under clothes. It is however still used for curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine. It is shown in the image below.

 

Other braces and casts used in Scoliosis:

Risser's cast is a body cast that extended up to the cervical spine and contacting the chin and skull. A hole is cut in the abdominal region to make breathing easy. It is shown in the image below.

Charleston bending brace and Providence brace are used while laying down and sleeping at night for 8 to 10 hours. These braces are best suited for single thoracolumbar or lumbar curves.

The SpineCor brace is a modern, flexible brace that is simpler, more comfortable and highly effective.

questions.text: A 28-year-old multiparous woman delivered a full-term male baby by spontaneous vaginal delivery. Soon after the delivery of the baby, the patient immediately went into a state of shock. After establishing adequate IV access, she was started on IV fluids and blood transfusion. On abdominal examination, the fundus of the uterus could not be felt. Examination of genital tract revealed no obvious source of bleeding. The placenta is still attached, and initial attempt to reposition the uterus has failed. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of shock immediately after delivery and absent uterine fundus on abdominal examination is suggestive of uterine inversion. After resuscitation, the next step in management is to administer tocolytics.

Uterine inversion is a rare cause of postpartum collapse which is acute in onset and occurs immediately after delivery.

Causes:

  • Mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor - Delivering a yet to be separated placenta (Creede’s method)
  • Spontaneous
  • Placenta accreta.

Features:

  • Shock appears immediately after delivery.
  • The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding
  • Shock is both neurogenic and hemorrhagic.
  • Per abdomen examination: Fundus of the uterus is felt to be absent. 

Management:

The following steps are done in uterine inversion.

  • Discontinue uterotonics
  • Administration of IV crystalloids through large-bore IV cannulas to prevent/treat neurogenic and hemorrhagic shock. This is followed by blood transfusion to replace losses.
  • Repositioning is tried after confirming that the inverted uterus is not firmly retracted or contracted. If the placenta is attached to the uterus, it is done with the placenta in-situ. The palm and the fingers are used to push up the uterine fundus along the vaginal axis.
  • Administer tocolytics such as terbutaline, magnesium sulphate, and nitroglycerin can be used to relax the uterus for repositioning, if the initial attempt has failed. An inhalational anaesthetic agent can be used if relaxation is not sufficient with tocolytics. Once the uterus is relaxed, repositioning is re-attempted.
  • Oxytocin infusion is started and tocolytics are stopped after repositioning. Await spontaneous expulsion of placenta.
  • The position of the uterus is maintained while applying bimanual compression.
  • Surgical intervention is needed if repositioning fails or can't be done.

Other options:

Option A - Uterotonic agents should be stopped immediately. They are administered after the uterus is repositioned and tocolytics if admistered are stopped.

Option C - Uterine repositioning is re-attempted after the uterus has been relaxed following tocolytic administration.

Option D - Controlled cord traction must not be done in uterine inversion. It is done in the active management of third stage of labour.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with dichorionic diamniotic twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a vertex position and the second twin was found to be in a breech position. Maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 2+ proteinuria. The fetal non-stress test was reassuring. What is the ideal next step in management?

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Expectant management upto 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a patient with pre-eclampsia and twin gestation at 38 weeks of gestation, induction of labour is the ideal next step in management.

The ACOG recommends termination of pregnancy at 38 weeks of pregnancy in dichorionic gestations. Normal vaginal delivery is preferred as the first twin is in a vertex position. The second twin may be delivered through an assisted breech delivery. Additionally, pre-eclampsia necessitates termination of pregnancy beyond 37 weeks of gestation.

Diagnostic criteria of pre-eclampsia

It is defined as:

  • New-onset hypertension
    • mild: BP >140/90 mmHg on two occasions at least 4 h apart after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive patient.
    • severe: BP >160/110 mmHg on two occasions at least 4 h apart after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive patient.
  • And proteinuria
    • >300 mg/24 h or
    • Protein:creatinine ratio >0.3 or
    • Urine dipstick 2+
  • In the absence of proteinuria, it is defined as new-onset hypertension with any one of the following
    • Thrombocytopenia (PLT <1,00,000/mm3)
    • Renal insufficiency
    • Impaired liver function
    • Pulmonary edema
    • Headache or visual symptoms.

Management of hypertension in pregnancy

  • Begin anti-hypertensives when BP >160/110 mmHg
    • Labetalol
    • Nifedipine
    • Methyl-dopa
    • Hydralazine.
  • Definitive management is the termination of pregnancy
    • Mode - Vaginal delivery. C-section is indicated only for obstetric reasons.
    • Timing
      • Mild pre-eclampsia >37 weeks
      • Severe pre-eclampsia >34 weeks.

Other options

Option D - Cesarean section would be preferred if the first twin is in a breech position. An attempted vaginal delivery can cause locking of the fetuses, trapping of the fetal head above the cervix and umbilical cord prolapse.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: Identify the deformity in the x-ray of the tibia given below. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hypertrophic non-union of tibia. The most appropriate treatment would be stabilization alone.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Hypertrophic nonunion: 
    • These fractures have adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur.
    • It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization.
    • On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation with an intervening dark area of fibrocartilage-lacking mineral.
  • Oligotrophic nonunion:
    • There is minimal callus formation
    • It is due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces.
    • On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction.
  • Atrophic nonunion: 
    • Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site.
    • The blood supply is typically poor.
    • On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction.

Management of non-union

  • Hypertrophic non-union
    • Stabilisation alone is sufficient
      • Conservative - functional bracing
      • Operative - Add or change to a stronger internal fixation
  • Oligotrophic or atrophic non-union
    • Stabilisation with bone grafting and/or bone curettage

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the indices for sex determination?
  1. Sciatic notch index is lesser in females
  2. Corporobasal index is lesser in females
  3. Ischiopubic index is greater in females
  4. Sacral index is greater in females
questions.solution:
Statements 2,3, and 4 are correct. All the given indices of sex determination are greater in females, except for the corporobasal index, which is more in males.

questions.text: A 60 year old man presents with congestive cardiac failure. He has been administered a drug that inhibits Na+-K+ ATPase. This drug leads to increase in intracellular Ca2+ by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Activating SERCA to release more calcium

questions.solution:
The drug being described is digoxin. The increase in intracellular calcium due to digoxin occurs as an indirect consequence of increased intracellular sodium. 

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used in the management of congestive cardiac failure and cardiac arrhythmias. In congestive cardiac failure, it is used to improve cardiac contractility by increasing the intracellular calcium.

Digoxin inhibits Na+-K+ ATPase which results in intracellular accumulation of sodium. This increased sodium inhibits the function of Na+-Ca2+ exchanger on the cell membrane which normally releases Ca2+ out of the cell in exchange for Na+. This results in accumulation of Ca2+ inside the cell. 

Other options:

Options C and D: SERCA (sarco endoplasmic reticulum calcium transport ATPase) transports Ca2+ from the cytosol into the sarcoplasmic reticulum. It does not release Ca2+ into the cytosol. Digoxin neither activates nor inhibits SERCA.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of eye ache and decreasing vision in his left eye. He underwent phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation in the same eye 2 days back. Examination of his left eye appears as shown in the image given below. A slit lamp examination revealed cells and flares in the anterior chamber. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing inflammation of the eyeball and hypopyon, in a patient 2 days after cataract surgery is suggestive of acute postoperative endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation, which predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e., the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common organism involved in pathogenesis.

Clinically, patients present with symptoms of pain, swelling of the eyelid, decrease in vision 48 to 72 hours after surgery.

Signs include conjunctival chemosis, corneal edema and haziness, and hypopyon due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Slit-lamp examination usually reveals white blood cells (cells) and protein (flare) within the anterior chamber. The diagnosis is confirmed by positive aqueous or vitreous culture.

Intravitreal injections of antibiotics like ceftazidime and vancomycin should be administered immediately after culture specimens have been obtained. Other treatments include:

  • Topical antibiotic
  • Topical mydriatics and cycloplegics
  • Oral steroids
  • Pars plana vitrectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Toxic anterior segment syndrome (TASS) is a sterile postoperative inflammation of the anterior segment caused by either the ethylene gas used for sterilizing intraocular lens (in early cases) or by the lens material (in late cases). It is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, no hypopyon, and no vitreal inflammation. It responds well to steroids.

Option B: Anterior scleritis is characterized by edema and inflammation of the sclera and is more commonly associated with autoimmune conditions.

Option C: Posterior capsular opacification also called after cataract, is the opacification that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens particles left over from surgery.

The illustration given below shows different types of after-cataract.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A lady presents difficulty in swallowing food, progressive hoarseness of voice, and loss of taste sensation. On examination, there is a loss of taste sensation on the posterior part of her tongue, absent gag reflex, and difficulty in shrugging her shoulders. Her MRI scan reveals a dural meningioma at an opening located in the base of the skull. The opening most likely to be involved is:
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the MRI brain showing dural meningioma at the opening in the base of the skull suggests the opening most likely to be involved is 1 i.e. the jugular foramen. 

The jugular foramen is an opening situated between the temporal and the occipital bone. It is present just above and lateral to the foramen magnum. Structures passing through the jugular foramen are:

  • Inferior petrosal sinus passes in the anterior part of the foramen
  • Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) cranial nerves pass through the middle of the foramen
  • Internal jugular vein passes through the posterior part of the foramen.

Other options: 

Option A: 3 - Foramen rotundum - The structure passing through this foramen is the maxillary division of cranial nerve V (V2). 

Option B: 2 - Foramen ovale - The structures passing through this foramen are: Mandibular division of CN V (V3), accessory meningeal artery, lesser petrosal nerve, and emissary veins. 

Option C: 4 - Foramen spinosum - The structures passing through this foramen are: Middle meningeal artery, nervus spinosus, and middle meningeal vein.

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis was started on antitubercular therapy. Among the following antitubercular drugs given below, which of the following option selects all the drugs that have a bactericidal action?
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Rifampicin
  3. Pyrazinamide
  4. Ethambutol
  5. Streptomycin
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is the only bacteriostatic agent among the given options. All the options are examples of bactericidal drugs. Therefore, option D (1, 2, 3, 5) is the right answer. 

Bactericidal antituberculosis agents (RIPS)

  • R: Rifampicin (R)
  • I: Isoniazid (H)
  • P: Pyrazinamide (Z)
  • S: Streptomycin (S)

Treatment regimens for pulmonary tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis consist of an initial 2-month phase of a 4-drug regimen, followed by a continuation phase of an additional 4 months of isoniazid and rifampin for pulmonary tuberculosis.

Isoniazid is used for the treatment of tuberculosis (as part of combination therapy) or for latent tuberculosis infection (as monotherapy or part of combination therapy). The antimicrobial activity of INH is selective for mycobacteria, likely due to its ability to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis, which interferes with cell wall synthesis, thereby producing a bactericidal effect 

Rifampicin is thought to inhibit bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which appears to occur as a result of drug binding in the polymerase subunit deep within the DNA/RNA channel, facilitating direct blocking of the elongating RNA. Along with Isoniazid, Rifampicin is also given in both the initial phase and continuation phase of the treatment of TB.

Pyrazinamide is most commonly used for the treatment of active tuberculosis (TB) during the initial phase of therapy only(generally the first two months of treatment), in combination with other agents. The spectrum of pyrazinamide is relatively narrow; it demonstrates clinically significant antibacterial activity only against Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium africanum.

Streptomycin is an injectable drug, also a bactericidal drug used sometimes in the initial phase of treatment of pulmonary TB.

Ethambutol is the only drug in the initial phase which is an example of a bacteriostatic drug. There is evidence that the drug exerts its bacteriostatic activity by virtue of inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme that polymerizes arabinose into arabinan and then arabinogalactan, a mycobacterial cell wall constituent.

Related Pearl: General properties of the first line drugs in TB

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past. These include:

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown/undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes for a routine check-up. She gives a history of gastritis for 1 year for which she uses antacids obtained over the counter. She says that she attains immediate relief with antacids and therefore, uses it 6-8 times per day. On examination, her vitals are stable. Blood tests are ordered and it shows hypercalcemia. Which of the following options is the patient at risk for?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia can lead to nephrogenic DI.

Excessive use of calcium carbonate, found in common antacids can lead to high calcium levels. This patient gives a clear history of overusing antacids for 1 year for her gastritis.

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) results due to resistance to the antidiuretic action of AVP (arginine vasopressin). The causes of nephrogenic DI are:

  • Genetic - X linked recessive and autosomal dominant or recessive due to mutations in the aquaporin channel
  • Acquired - 
    • Drugs - lithium, demeclocycline, amphotericin B, cisplatin, rifampicin
    • Metabolic- hypercalcemia, hypokalemia
    • Ureteral obstruction
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Sarcoma
    • Amyloidosis
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Idiopathic

Other options:

  • Primary Polydipsia:
    • Dipsogenic – Due to inappropriate thirst.
    • Iatrogenic – Due to an increase in fluid intake due to its presumed health benefits.
    • Psychogenic – Due to psychosis or obsessive-compulsive disorder.
  • Neurogenic or Central DI: Central diabetes insipidus is a lack of the hormone vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone) that causes excessive production of very dilute urine (polyuria). Central diabetes insipidus has several causes which includes pituitary tumor, a brain injury, brain surgery, and other diseases.

questions.text: On examination of a newborn, you notice that the baby is hypotonic, has a high forehead, large anterior fontanelle, markedly separated cranial sutures, and hepatomegaly. Imaging reveals renal cysts. Investigations reveal elevated levels of very-long-chain fatty acids,  abnormal intermediates of bile acid synthesis, and deficiency of plasmalogens. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypotonia, dysmorphic facial features, hepatomegaly, renal cysts and accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormal intermediates of bile acid synthesis, with a deficiency of plasmalogens are suggestive of Zellweger syndrome. It is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome 

It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins from the cytosol to the peroxisomes. It severely impairs the functions of peroxisomes resulting in defective beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with

  • Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, etc
  • Profound developmental delay
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Renal cysts
  • Chondrodysplasia punctata- calcific stippling of the patellae, hips, and other epiphysis is seen in the majority of the patients.

Biochemical findings will show :

  • accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid
  • abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
  • marked reduction of plasmalogens

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum disease is a disorder of alpha fatty acid oxidation. It occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase (PAHX). It typically occurs in individuals between 10-15 years and is characterized by retinitis pigmentosa, anosmia, peripheral neuropathy, ichthyosis, cardiac conduction defects. There are elevated CSF protein levels without an increase in cells.

It can be diagnosed by elevated levels of phytanic acid and decreased activity of PAHX in the fibroblasts. VLCFA levels are normal in this condition.

Infantile Refsums disease presents at one to six months of age with severe developmental delay but generally without the dysmorphic features.

Option C- Neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy is a disorder of beta-oxidation that results in the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in all tissues. The abnormalities primarily affect the central nervous system, adrenal cortex, and Leydig cells. The craniofacial appearance is dysmorphic, but less marked than Zellweger syndrome and consists primarily of mid-face hypoplasia. Patients typically have hepatomegaly but do not have renal microcysts or chondrodysplasia punctata.

Option D- Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata is also a disorder of peroxisomes. They also present with profound mental retardation and dysmorphic facies. The unique feature is that it primarily affects the proximal long bones resulting in severe short stature. They might also have congenital cataracts and ichthyosis. VLCFA levels are not elevated in this condition. 

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the blood pressures of people in different cities. Sample sizes of different cities 1, 2, and 3 are 1000, 800, and 600 respectively.  Three normal distribution curves of different sample sizes of the three cities are given below in the image. The X-axis shows the standard deviation from the mean blood pressure. The order of margin of error will be ____________.
questions.solution:
Curve 1 has the least margin of error, followed by curve 2 and then curve 3. So the order is 3>2>1.

The image shows three normal distribution curves of different sample sizes, having the same mean but different standard deviation.

As the sample size is decreasing, the peak decreases and the curve becomes flatter, implying a wider confidence interval for the given mean.

The margin of error is a statistic expressing the amount of random sampling error in the results of a survey. The larger the margin of error, the less confidence.

The width of the base of the curve is directly proportional to the margin of error. 

  • Many data such as blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc., form a normal distribution
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text:
Which of the following pharmacological agents are approved for use in the management of COVID19?
  1. Tocilizumab
  2. Baricitnib
  3. Crizanlizumab
  4. Remdesivir
  5. Ublituximab
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option b.

The drugs that have been approved for use in the management of COVID19 are tocilizumab, baricitnib, and remdesivir. Recent updates regarding these drugs are mentioned below. 

Tocilizumab an IL-6 inhibitor in combination with dexamethasone is approved for emergency usage and is recommended in the management of hospitalized patients with rapid respiratory decompensation due to covid. Tocilizumab is also used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. 

Baricitnib is a Janus kinase inhibitor approved for emergency usage in the management of hospitalized COVID patients requiring supplemental oxygen, invasive mechanical ventilation, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

Remdesivir, the FDA-approved antiviral drug works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. The guidelines panel of the WHO recently issued a conditional recommendation against the use of remdesivir in hospitalized COVID patients, regardless of disease severity, as there is currently no evidence that remdesivir improves survival. As per the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare guidelines, in India, remdesivir is considered in moderate and severe hospitalized COVID patients requiring supplemental oxygen/oxygen delivery. Contraindications of remdesivir are as follows:

  • AST/ALT > 5 times upper limit of normal
  • Severe renal impairment (i.e., eGFR < 30ml/min/m2 or need for hemodialysis) 
  • Pregnancy or lactating females 
  • Children <12 years of age

Other options:

Ublituximab (TG-1101) is an investigational glycoengineered monoclonal antibody that is under development for Non-Hodgkin lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis.

Crizanlizumab is a monoclonal antibody that is FDA approved to reduce the frequency of vaso-occlusive crises in adults and pediatric patients aged 16 years and older with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of erratic behaviour in school. He is unable to sit still in class for more than a few minutes at a time, pushes other children, never waits for his turn, and disturbs his classmates. His parents say that he is hyperactive at home as well. The language and milestones are appropriate for his age. Any of the following drugs can be used in his condition except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above of a child with inattention and hyperactivity points towards a diagnosis of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Tricyclic antidepressants like desipramine are not recommended in the treatment of ADHD due to potential cardiac arrhythmia effects. There have been reports of sudden death in children with ADHD being treated with desipramine.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may disappear in some cases, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

questions.text:
Match the following patients with the corresponding healthcare programs that can suitably cater to some aspect of their needs.

Column I

  1. An adolescent girl who is menstruating and requires suvidha sanitary napkins
  2. A pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester needing antenatal care service
  3. A poor elderly male destitute requiring a coronary artery bypass graft
  4. A woman requiring a cesarean section who has to be transferred to a higher center

Column II

a. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram

b. Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Janaushadhi Pariyojana

c. Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan

d. Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 1- b, 2- c, 3- d, and 4- a.

An adolescent girl who is menstruating and requires suvidha sanitary napkins - Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Janaushadhi Pariyojana 

A pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester needing antenatal care service - Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan

A poor elderly male destitute requiring a coronary artery bypass graft  - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana 

A woman requiring a cesarean section who has to be transferred to a higher center - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram 

The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram has provisions for free transport from home to the health institutions, between facilities in case of referral, and back home from the health institution. These provisions are for pregnant women and sick infants till 30 days after birth. Other services include free treatment, free drugs and consumables, and free delivery including cesarean section.

The Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA) ensures quality antenatal care service. With this, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic. This happens on the 9th of every month.

The Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana was launched on the 23rd of September 2018. 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • More than 10.74 crore poor and vulnerable families (approximately 50 crore beneficiaries) are covered across the country.
  • Cashless access to quality health care services.
  • Primitive tribal groups, destitute, and households without shelters are automatically included.

Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana provides 'suvidha', a 100% biodegradable sanitary napkin for Rs.1 per pad in over 6300 Janaushadhi Kendras for the underprivileged women of India.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the given pathogen except:

choices.text: Follows a Blaschkoid distribution of lesions
Cigar shaped cells on PAS stained preparations
Amphotericin B is used for disseminated infection
It can be transmitted to humans by infected animals

questions.solution:
Option A is the incorrect statement. The organism in the given picture is Sporothrix schenckii, the lesions of which are distributed along the lymphatic channels and not along the lines of Blaschko.

Lines of Blaschko are a system of lines representing developmental growth patterns in the skin. Skin lesions like incontinetia pigmenti, epidermal naevi, etc. follow a Blaschkoid distribution.

The given image shows teardrop-shaped conidia branching directly from the septate hyphae, seen in clusters as well as singularly. A conidiophore with a cluster of conidia on top is seen in the center of the image. 

S. schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by secondary spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. It may also be transmitted by infected animals. 

Days or weeks after inoculation, a papule develops which usually ulcerates. Similar lesions develop sequentially along the lymphatic channels moving proximal to the original lesion. Some patients may develop a verrucous or ulcerative lesion that remains localized without lymphatic extension.

Other forms of sporotrichosis include

  • Osteoarticular sporotrichosis -presenting as chronic synovitis or septic arthritis
  • Pulmonary sporotrichosis - may mimick tuberculosis or fungal pneumonias

S. schenckii grows well on routine agar media, and colonies are blackish and shiny. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, which carry flower-like clusters (rosettes) of small conidia at the tapering ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells at 37°C and as mycelial forms at 25°C . Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver - cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain- cell wall appears red 
  • Fluorescent antibody staining- Yeasts appear spherical to elongated, 3-5 μm

Diagnosis: Histopathologic examination shows a mixed granulomatous and pyogenic reaction, with tiny oval or cigar-shaped yeasts.

Treatment:

  • Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis- Itraconazole (drug of choice), Saturated solution of potassium iodide (SSKI) 
  • Pulmonary and osteoarticular forms - Itraconazole for at least 1 year.  Amphotericin B followed by Itraconazole  for severe pulmonary and disseminated sporotrichosis

questions.text:
A patient on treatment for small cell lung cancer now presents with headache, nausea, and lethargy. He also had one episode of vomiting. Investigations reveal the values given below. Which of the following is responsible for his symptoms?
Sodium 120 mmol/L
Potassium 4.2 mmol/L
Calcium  9 mg/dl
Uric acid 2 mg/dl
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of the symptoms in the given scenario is vasopressin/ ADH excess.

The given clinical scenario describes hyponatremia in a patient with small-cell lung cancer. This is suggestive of SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) due to ectopic secretion of vasopressin (ADH) by the small cell carcinoma.

Other options:

Option A- Adrenocorticotropic hormone deficiency leads to secondary adrenal insufficiency which presents with hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

Option B- Small cell lung cancer can also secrete PTH-related peptide leading to hypercalcemia which causes similar symptoms. However, in this patient calcium levels are normal.

Option D- Renin and RAAS axis result in sodium and water retention. It does not lead to hyponatremia.

questions.text:
In the given image, the marked parts of the pancreas are mainly supplied by which of the following arteries?
  1. Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery
  2. Arteria pancreatica magna
  3. Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery
questions.solution:
The structures marked in the image are the head and the uncinate process of the pancreas.

They are supplied by

  • Superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries - branches of the gastroduodenal artery from the celiac trunk
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries - branches of the superior mesenteric artery

The body and tail of the pancreas are mainly supplied by the branches of the splenic artery:

  • Dorsal pancreatic artery
  • Greater pancreatic artery (Arteria pancreatica magna)
  • Artery to the tail of the pancreas

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with body pain and easy fatigability. Investigations revealed a hemoglobin level of 7 gm/dL.  The peripheral smear revealed macrocytic hypochromic cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. Further investigations revealed elevated serum levels of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid. This condition may also lead to?

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency may lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. 

Megaloblastic anemia can be due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In vitamin B12 deficiency, serum levels of both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid are elevated whereas, in folate deficiency, only homocysteine levels are elevated.

Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord occurs due to defective myelin synthesis which leads to degeneration of the ascending and descending spinal tracts. It presents with symmetrical paraesthesia and progresses to weakness, ataxia, and spasticity. Complications include complete paraplegia. It can be treated by the administration of vitamin B12. 

Other options:

Option A- Syringomyelia is characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity in the spinal cord. It is associated with Chiari I malformation. It leads to progressive myelopathy and presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper limbs.

Option B- Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is an encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms.

Option D- Central pontine myelinolysis occurs due to the loss of myelin in the base of the pons. It occurs after rapid correction of hyponatremia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with acute bleeding following delivery in the ambulance. On examination, a perineal tear was observed involving the anal sphincter and anal mucosa. The bleeding has been controlled. When is the ideal time to perform sphincter reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
As the patient was delivered in the ambulance on the way to the hospital, she has presented immediately (within 24 hours) with a complete perineal tear. Sphincter reconstructive surgery must be performed immediately.

A tear of the perineal body involving the sphincter ani externus with or without the involvement of anorectal mucosa is termed a complete perineal tear. Complete perineal tears (3rd or 4th-degree tears) that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery.

In 3 months, local infection would subside with improvement in the general condition of the patient and baby can also be kept at home. Beyond 6 months, due to excessive fibrosis at the margin, it becomes inconvenient for the patient.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents for a routine gynaecological examination. A pap smear was taken which showed dysplastic cells in >2/3rd of the cervix. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Pap smear showing dysplastic cells >⅔ of cervix is called CIN III. The treatment of choice in CIN III is LEEP.

Management of CIN

  • CIN I or mild dysplasia
    • Follow up every 3-6 months
  • CIN I which is progressive or persistent for over a year
    • Laser ablation
    • Cryotherapy
  • CIN II, III or moderate-severe dysplasia
    • Large loop excision of transformation zone (LLETZ) or Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP)
    • Cold knife or Laser conization
  • Carcinoma in situ or confirmed microinvasion
    • Hysterectomy

Comparison of the different systems of classification

PAP classification CIN (WHO) Bethesda grading
Class I Normal Normal
Class II Inflammatory

Inflammatory

HPV

ASCUS
Class III CIN I

Low SIL
Class IV CIN II, CIN III, CIS

High SIL
Class V SCC

SCC

CIS: Carcinoma in situ, CIN: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, SCC: Squamous cell carcinoma, SIL: Squamous intraepithelial lesion, ASCUS: Atypical squamous cell of undetermined significance, HPV: Human Papilloma Virus

Other options

Option A - Excision (LEEP or LLETZ) is preferred over ablation (laser ablation or cryotherapy) as it provides a specimen to review diagnosis even when a diagnostic specimen is not essential.

Option B & D - Hysterectomy and conization are invasive and not usually done in CIN III. Its indications are given below:

  • Indications of hysterectomy
    • Older & parous women
    • The uterus is suspected with fibroid, bleeding or prolapse
    • Microinvasion confirmed
    • Recurrence or persistent lesion
    • In – situ adenocarcinoma cervix.
  • Indications of conization
    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • The transformation zone is not completely visualized
    • When there is a discrepancy of findings between cytology, colposcopy & biopsy
    • Microinvasion is suspected.

An image showing normal cervical epithelium is given below.

An image showing LSIL or CIN I is given below

An image showing HSIL or CIN II is given below

An image showing HSIL or CIN III is given below

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with congestive cardiac failure develops difficulty in breathing. A section of his lung tissue is shown below. What are the cells indicated in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows heart failure cells and the clinical scenario describes pulmonary edema due to heart failure. Heart failure cells are siderophages (hemosiderin-containing macrophages) seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema due to left heart failure.

The alveolar walls become thickened, fibrosed and contain these pigmented macrophages which produces brown induration of lung.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of pressure epiphysis?
questions.solution:
Head of the femur is an example of a pressure epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis is articular in nature and takes part in the transmission of weight. Examples are head of the femur, the lower end of radius, etc.

Other options

Options A and D: Tubercles of humerus and trochanters of femur are examples of traction epiphysis.

Option C: Coracoid process of scapula is an example of the atavistic epiphysis.

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: Rohit, a 30-year-old man, visits you for a health check-up. On further inquiry, you come to understand that he is a smoker, drug abuser, and an alcoholic. He also admits to having unprotected sexual intercourse with commercial sex workers on multiple occasions. His physical examination is unremarkable. Which among the following is an example of secondary prevention most suitable to this patient?

choices.text: Counselling on lung cancer risk due to smoking

questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most appropriate secondary prevention would be to screen for HIV infection and other STDs.

Primary prevention

It is action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes/reduces the possibility that a disease will ever occur. For example: Improving standard of living, vaccination, infection control (hand-washing), counselling etc.

Secondary prevention

It is action which halts the progress of a disease at an early stage and prevention of complications. It includes early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment of specific conditions. For example: Pap smears, BP screening, mammographies, colonoscopy screenings etc.

Other options:

ARV is not indicated for this patient as his HIV status is unknown.

Safe sex counselling and Counselling on lung cancer risk due to smoking would be a primary prevention method as he is currently in the risk factor phase.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Tertiary

Late stage of disease

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering
