questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with watery diarrhea associated with frequent epigastric pain, bloating, and indigestion for the past few weeks that did not respond to medications. Stool culture is negative. His lab reports show microcytic hypochromic anemia and serum K+ 2.9 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia (serum K+<3.5 mM), and symptoms of achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency) which suggests the diagnosis of WDHA syndrome caused by VIPoma.

VIPoma is pancreatic endocrine neoplasia. The tumor secretes vasoactive intestinal peptides which are responsible for the secretory watery diarrhea and other symptoms mentioned above. While suspecting a case of VIPoma it is essential to conduct a VIP assay so as to confirm the presence of other tumors of neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma. 

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhea.

Other options: 

Option A: Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. The most common presentations of gastrinoma are epigastric pain, diarrhea, and peptic ulcers. The ulcers occur at typical locations (proximal duodenum) and atypical locations (distal duodenum, jejunum). However, in this scenario, the endoscopy findings were normal.

Option C: Delta cell tumor, aka somatostatinoma, is also a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor presents with cholelithiasis, diarrhea, neurofibromatosis.

Option D: Pancreatic carcinoid is associated with excess serotonin and presents with sweating, flushing, diarrhea, and edema.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of progressively worsening menstrual pain that is now causing her distress for most of the month. She finds no relief from contraceptive pills. She underwent laparotomy and an ovarian cyst was excised which is shown in the image below. Which among the following is not a risk factor for this condition?

DES - Diethyl stilbesterol
questions.solution:
The image shows a chocolate cyst which is diagnostic of endometriosis. Early menopause is not a risk factor.

Chocolate cysts of the ovaries represent the most important manifestation of endometriosis. Gross examination shows thickening of the tunica albuginea, and well-marked vascular red adhesions on the undersurface of the ovary. The inner surface of the cyst wall is vascular and contains areas of dark brown tissue as shown in the image. The chocolate cyst lies between the ovary and the lateral pelvic wall

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus. It is an estrogen-dependent disease primarily affecting women of the reproductive age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary followed by the pouch of Douglas.

 The risk factors for the development of endometriosis are - 

  • Family history
  • Nulliparity
  • Prolonged exposure to endogenous estrogen
    • Early menarche and
    • Late menopause
  • Estrogen therapy
  • In utero exposure to Diethyl stilbesterol (DES)
  • Obstruction to menstrual flow
  • Shorter menstrual cycles
  • White and Asian race

The protective factors for endometriosis are -

  • Multiparity
  • Extended intervals of lactation
  • Late menarche 
  • Increased consumption of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids
  • Black and Hispanic race

The various theories that explain the development of endometriosis are:

  1. Sampson's theory of retrograde menstruation or Implantation theory attributes the development of endometriosis to reflux menstrual endometrium via the fallopian tubes and its subsequent implantation and growth on the pelvic peritoneum and nearby structures.
  2. Meyer and Ivanhoff's coelomic metaplasia theory attributes the development of endometriosis to metaplastic changes in embryonic cell rests of embryonic mesothelium, which are capable to respond to hormonal stimuli.
  3. Halban's metastatic theory explains the presence of endometriosis in far-off sites like the lung, pleura, endocardium, and extremities. It attributes the development of endometriosis to the embolization of menstrual fragments via vascular or lymphatic channels.
  4. The hormonal theory states that the development of endometriosis depends mainly on estrogen. Progesterone causes atrophy of endometrioses.
  5. The immunological theory states that impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.

Clinical presentations of endometriosis are - 

  • Chocolate cysts as described above
  • Red-colored papular and vesicular lesions filled with hemorrhagic fluid over the pelvic peritoneum, pouch of Douglas, and uterosacral ligaments.
  • Dysmenorrhoea is the most common symptom. It commonly presents before the onset of menses, gradually builds up until the flow begins, and decreases thereafter. Deeper lesions cause more pain than superficial ones.
  • Backache is also a common symptom.
  • Lower abdominal pain of varying intensity
  • Dyspareunia
  • Infertility
  • Menorrhagia
  • Chronic pelvic pain syndrome
Laparoscopy is the gold standard in the diagnosis of endometriosis. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst or clumps of high-density echoes suggestive of clots. Colour doppler shows a diffuse increase in vascularity. An elevated CA-125 level is suggestive of endometriosis. 

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management:

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analogs
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterones orally or as Mirena IUCD

Surgical management:

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Combined medical and surgical therapy
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 19 year old boy is brought to the doctor because his family found him dressed like a woman. He says that he feels better when he dresses like this and he likes the idea of feeling like a woman. He also says that he has been doing this for many years. He however has no wish to undergo sex change surgery. His family says that his behaviour is normal apart from this issue. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with hormonal instability
It is not associated with genital abnormality

questions.solution:
The condition described in the given scenario is dual-role transvestism.

It is a condition in which the person temporarily likes to identify with the opposite gender by dressing like them. It is a gender identity disorder. It is not associated with any genital or hormonal abnormality. This condition is not a sexual paraphilia as it is not accompanied by sexual excitement derived from cross dressing. They do not want to undergo sex change surgery as they are otherwise comfortable with leading a life as their assigned gender.

Gender identity disorders may be seen in anyone, including homosexual people, but it does not have any association with homosexuality.

ICD 10 classifies gender and sexuality related disorders as follows:

Gender identity disorders:

  • Transsexualism is a condition where the person wants to live life as a member of the oppositte sex. They often prefer to undergo sex change surgery.
  • Dual-role transvestism
  • Gender identity disorder of childhood- persistent excessive preoccupation with the dressing and activities of the opposite sex and desire to be one among the members of opposite sex. This is accompanied by distress with one's assigned gender.

Disorders of sexual preference:

  • Fetishism- Using non living objects, usually those belonging to the opposite sex, as stimulus for sexual gratification.
  • Fetishistic transvestism is a sexual paraphilia where the person dresses as the opposite sex to derive sexual pleasure.
  • Exhibitionism- Reccurent tendency to expose genitalia to strangers.
  • Voyeurism- Recurrent urge to observe a person while undressing or engaging in sexual activity.
  • Paedophilia- Sexual preference for pre pubertal or early pubertal children.
  • Sadomasochism- Preference for inflicting pain on sexual partner or being subjected to pain by sexual partner.

Note- If the term transvestism is used in the mcq without mentioning dual-role transvestism or fetishistic transvestism, please consider it as sexual paraphilia. Here in this mcq, the person does not practice transvestism to obtain sexual gratification, hence it is clearly not fetishistic transvestism.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy presents with low-pitched inspiratory stridor, present since a few days after birth. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying.  The observation made on direct laryngoscopy is shown in the image below.  What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of inspiratory stridor since birth with omega-shaped epiglottis, as shown in the image, is suggestive of laryngomalacia. The next step in management is expectant observation.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. In this condition, the supraglottic portion of the larynx is excessively flaccid and subsequently gets sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia. It subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying. 

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Treatment of laryngomalacia is mainly conservative, as it self-corrects by the time the child is 2 years of age. Tracheostomy may be required in some cases with severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Other options:

Options A & C: Endotracheal intubation and IV ceftriaxone are immediate management modalities of acute epiglottitis, which is a medical emergency. It is characterized by sore throat, dysphagia in adults, dyspnoea, and stridor in children, which are both rapidly progressive and associated with fever up to 40°C. Thumb sign, that is, a swollen epiglottis, is observed on a lateral view x-ray of the neck.

Option D: Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline is the immediate management of acute laryngotracheobronchitis. It is characterized by a low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

Related Pearl: Differences between adult and infant Larynx

Feature

Infants

Adults

Position

Opposite C3-C4

Opposite C5-C6

Epiglottis

Omega-shaped

Leaf-shaped

Thyroid cartilage

Flat

Angulated

Larynx

Conical

Cylindrical

Narrowest part

Subglottis

Glottis

Submucosal tissue

More and loose

Less and dense

Laryngeal cartilages

Soft and collapsible

Hard and ossified

questions.text: A primigravid woman in her 36th week of gestation presented with progressive jaundice, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Investigations revealed abnormal liver function tests pointing towards a diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A deficiency of fetal long-chain 3-hydroxy acyl CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) is involved in the pathogenesis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Acute fatty liver is a common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. It occurs either due to poor placental mitochondrial function or due to a fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl coenzyme A dehydrogenase (LCHAD).

The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastric pain. Features like hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. There is hemolysis, with decreased platelets and fibrinogen. Elevated d-dimer is seen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.

The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Trial of labor by induction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements about ASHA are false?

i) It is mandatory that she had formal schooling until 12th Std
ii) ASHA ensures birth registration of the newborn
iii) The total incentive received by ASHA after the delivery of twins is Rs.250
iv) She must visit all newborns on Day 1
questions.solution:
ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3).
  • In case a newborn is discharged from SNCU, then ASHA will receive full incentive after completing the remaining visits.
  • ASHA will do additional follow-up visits every month for low-birth-weight newborns up to two years, and SNCU discharged babies up to one year. For each follow-up visit, ASHA will receive an additional Rs. 50.
  • If the woman delivers at her maternal house and returns to her husband’s house or vice versa, the visits might have been done by two ASHAs at the two different places. In such cases, if each ASHA completes at least 3 visits, they will receive Rs 125 each. If ASHA completes less than 3 visits, they will not receive any incentive.
  • In the case of twins/triplets, then ASHA will receive twice (Rs. 500) or thrice (Rs. 750), the regular payment.

The payments are made to ASHA on 45th day, subject to the following conditions:

  • The birth weight is recorded in the Maternal and Child Protection (MCP) Card.
  • Ensuring that the newborn is immunized with: BCG, first doses of OPV and DPT/Pentavalent, and entered into the MCP card.
  • Enabling birth registration.
  • Both mother and newborn are safe until 42nd day.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had multiple nodular skin lesions for the past 5 years. Previous investigations showed CD 4 T helper cells in these lesions. He has been using topical steroids for its management. He now presents with rapid onset diffuse erythema of the skin. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased CD 8 T cells in the skin
Abnormal T cells with cerebriform nucleus in blood
Increased mast cells around dermal blood vessels

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the development of Sezary syndrome in a patient with mycosis fungoides. This syndrome shows the presence of abnormal T cells with cerebriform nucleii (Sezary cells) in the blood.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ Helper T cells) which usually stays confined to the skin. It can disseminate into blood which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Mycoses fungoides presents as scaly red-brown patches, raised scaling plaques, and fungating nodules. It passes through 3 phases:

  • Inflammatory pre-mycotic phase- eczema like lesions
  • Plaque phase- raised plaques are seen
  • Tumor phase- multiple tumor nodules indicating systemic spread

The given image shows mycosis fungoides:

Sezary syndrome occurs when malignant T cells from mycoses fungoides are seeded into blood. This leads to diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body surface. The skin lesions in case of Sezary syndrome rarely reach tumefaction phase.

The given image shows erythrodermic sezary syndrome:

The given image shows Sezary cells:

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with right wrist pain. She says that the pain aggravates while working and improves with rest. On examination, there is local tenderness in the area of the dorsal radial styloid. There is no limitation of motion, but the ulnar deviation is very painful. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's disease.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work.
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid.
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test - The examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.

Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

Other options:

The site of pain and tenderness can be diagnostic

Condition Site of pain
Kienböck’s disease Over the lunate
Scaphoid fracture Anatomical snuffbox
Carpometacarpal osteoarthritis The base of the first metacarpal


Note: Kienböck’s disease is the traumatic softening of the lunate bone. This condition is characterized by ischemic necrosis which may be due to chronic stress or injury.

questions.text: A resident working in a trauma ward came across a patient with polytrauma following RTA. As a routine protocol, a COVID RT PCR was done and the patient turned out to be COVID-19 positive. The resident started developing fever and cough in 3 days.  A COVID -19 Rapid Antigen Test was done and the result was negative. What is the next step in the management of the resident?
questions.solution:
Symptomatic individuals with a negative Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) need to be retested with RT-PCR immediately.

Studies have shown that swabbing the nose with a rapid antigen test will not detect the new variant Omicron in the first few days of infection. People can already transmit the infection to others when it has affected the throat & saliva.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes with complaints of patchy hair loss, as seen in the photograph below. Dermoscopy of the scalp skin was normal. On histology, numerous empty canals were seen. Clefts were noticed in the hair matrix and the follicular epithelium is separated from the connec­tive tissue sheath. Intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and image suggest that the most likely diagnosis is trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania is a psychiatric disorder characterized by com­pulsive hair pulling. There is increased tension before the hair-pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair-pulling. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.

Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.

Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages. Numerous empty canals, severely damaged follicles, and clefts in the hair matrix are also seen. The follicular epithelium separates from the connec­tive tissue sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. 

The image below shows alopecia areata:

Option B: Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows Tinea capitis:

Option D: Traction alopecia is caused by hairstyles that impose a sus­tained pull on the hair roots. The pattern of the hair loss will reflect the dis­tribution of the traction.

questions.text: Swarming by Proteus species can be inhibited by all the following except:
questions.solution:
Swarming by Proteus species is not inhibited by blood agar.

Proteus species are Gram-negative, non-capsulated, pleomorphic, motile rods. They are widespread in the environment and are normal inhabitants of the GIT. P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris most commonly produce infections. The spot-indole test is useful for distinguishing between the two: P. vulgaris is indole positive, whereas P. mirabilis is negative.

Proteus species are urease-positive, non-lactose fermenters. They possess the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA reaction).

Proteus species exhibit swarming on solid media such as blood agar by using their peritrichous flagella. Swarming can be inhibited by:

  • Increasing the concentration of agar to 6%
  • Chloral hydrate
  • Sodium azide
  • Alcohol (5-6%)
  • Sulphonamide
  • Surface-active agents or boric acid
  • MacConkey medium due to the presence of bile
  • CLED (cystine-lactose-electrolyte- deficient) medium.

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia

The image below shows swarming of proteus on blood agar.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

Related Pearl: Types of flagella:

questions.text: A veterinarian presents with symptoms of myalgia, fatigue and low-grade fever for the past 10 days. On examination, he had non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Sabin-Feldman dye test was positive. Identify the parasite responsible for these findings in the patient.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a veterinarian presenting with myalgia, fatigue and low-grade fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a positive Sabin Feldman dye test is indicative of toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii.

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular coccidian parasite and is the causative agent of toxoplasmosis. Its definitive hosts are cats and other felines while humans are intermediate hosts.

The life cycle of toxoplasma gondii is shown below.

Humans acquire the infection upon consumption of meat containing tissue cysts, food or water containing mature oocysts, or fingers contaminated by cat feces.

Infection can also be transmitted from the mother to the fetus or from an infected donor to the recipient subsequent to a blood transfusion or organ transplantation.

Manifestations are mostly asymptomatic and if symptomatic can be congenital or acquired. Features such as fever, headache, myalgia, splenomegaly, and lymphade­nopathy commonly affect the cervical lymph nodes.

Central nervous system involvement is observed in toxoplasma infection affecting immunocompromised individuals. Toxoplasma infection in pregnancy can lead to congenital toxoplasmosis that most frequently presents with chorioretinitis. Chorioretinitis can also present in ocular toxoplasmosis.

Trophozoites and tissue cysts can be detected in tissue and body fluids. The tachyzoites appear as crescent-shaped structures with blue cytoplasm and dark nucleus. 

The Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of IgG antibodies against toxoplasma. It is based on the presence of antibodies that lyse the parasite membrane and hence prevent methylene blue dye from staining the cytoplasm of trophozoites (tachyzoites). If there are no antibodies, trophozoites with an intact membrane are stained and appear blue under the microscope, indicative of a negative result.

A false-positive test is seen in infection with Sarcocystis, Trichomonas vaginalis, and Trypanosoma Lewisi. Other tests done include indirect fluorescent antibody test, latex agglutination test, and ELISA, the latter of which can measure circulating IgG antibodies to Toxoplasma.

MRI and CT are used to diagnose toxoplasmosis with CNS involvement.

Other options:

Option A: In Leishmania infection, Montenegro test/Leishmanin test is positive. It is a skin test based on delayed hypersensitivity to an antigen derived from cultured Leishmania. Features include high-grade fever, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and lymphadenopathy.

Option B: In Echinococcus infection, Casoni’s test is done. It is a skin test based on immediate hypersensitivity to an antigen derived from hydatid fluid. It is positive in hydatid disease. The typical features are hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice. If lungs are involved, cough and hemoptysis can be present.

Option C: Is Schistosoma infection, Fairley's test is done. It is a skin test that is group-specific to all schistosomiasis. Manifestations include skin rash, anaphylaxis in acute stages. It can be associated with bladder carcinoma and infections in chronic stages.

questions.text: A patient was admitted for acute diarrhea and vomiting 2 days ago. The doctor on duty assessed that he has recovered from dehydration and ordered discontinuation of the IV fluids. The ward nurse by mistake administered 0.45% NaCl to this patient. Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams represents the fluid shift in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient did not need IV fluids but was administered hypotonic saline (0.45% NaCl). The Darrow Yannet diagram in image 3 represents the fluid shift in case of hypotonic fluid administration as seen in this patient. 

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either the addition or removal of fluid.

Hypotonic saline leads to the decreased osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. The net result is the decreased osmolarity and increased volume of both the compartments.

Other options:

Image 1- Normal ECF and ICF balance.

Image 2- The addition of isotonic saline to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Image 4- The addition of hypertonic saline to the ECF pulls the fluid from the ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a  3 months history of amenorrhea, headache,  vomiting, loss of libido, and galactorrhea. On examination, her vitals are within range but her eye examination shows bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following drug is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of prolactinoma of the pituitary. Among the given options, cabergoline is the preferred drug for this patient.

Prolactinoma: Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. The symptoms include

  • Headache and vomiting
  • Bitemporal hemianopia suggestive of a local mass effect
  • Increased intracranial pressure due to a pituitary tumor
  • In females- amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility
  • In males- impotence, loss of libido, and gynecomastia

The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Treatment is only required in symptomatic cases as microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas. The mainstay of treatment is medical management. Dopamine and dopamine agonists are used and they act as inhibitory signals to prolactin secretion in the pituitary. 

Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity and is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. It effectively suppresses prolactin secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or along with somatostatin analogs.

Another drug used in prolactinoma is bromocriptine. It is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline. The adverse effects of bromocriptine include hypotension and nausea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought to the casualty unconscious and pale, with agonal respirations and without a pulse. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, 40 pack-years of cigarette smoking and was witnessed falling to the ground suddenly at home. He had not complained of any preceding symptoms. A cardiac monitor was connected and the following tracing was obtained. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient is in cardiac arrest and the rhythm shown is ventricular fibrillation. The next step in management is immediate defibrillation.

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm. The energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator: 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator: 120-200 J

Note - The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Chest compressions are to be started following defibrillation.

Other options

Option B - Synchronized cardioversion is used in unstable tachyarrhythmias. It is not used in cardiac arrests.

Option C - Adenosine is used in regular narrow complex tachycardia and in stable wide complex tachycardia with monomorphic QRS complexes. It is not used in cardiac arrests.

Option D - Epinephrine is used after administering defibrillation and also in non-shockable rhythms (asystole and pulseless electrical activity).

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of inability to gain weight. During the evaluation, the doctor notices that the child has a developmental delay, coarse facial features, and restricted movements in the shoulder and elbow joints. There is mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show that the activities of β-hexosaminidase, iduronate sulfatase, and arylsulfatase A are deficient in cultured fibroblasts, but are 15 times more than normal in serum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is I cell disease. 

It is a lysosomal storage disorder in which the enzymes are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum, but are not able to enter the lysosome. It occurs as a result of the deficiency of mannose 6-phosphate that helps in the endocytosis. It is also called mucolipidosis II because it has clinical characteristics that include mucopolysaccharidoses and sphingolipidoses.

Important clinical features are:

  • Developmental delay
  • Coarse facial features
  • Joint abnormalities- hip dislocations, restricted joint movements
  • Skeletal abnormalities- short bones, kyphosis, scoliosis, etc.
  • Mild hepatomegaly

Diagnosis - It can be diagnosed by measuring the lysosomal enzyme activities. They are deficient in cultured fibroblasts, whereas 10-20 times the normal in the serum.

Other options

Option A and B-Hurler and Hunter syndrome can also present with the symptoms of developmental delay, coarse facial features, and hepatosplenomegaly. In addition to these, Hurler syndrome might also have cloudy cornea. The urinary examination will show the increased levels of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

Option D- Sialidosis, also known as mucolipidosis type I, is a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme neuraminidase. This results in the increased accumulation of oligosaccharides and gangliosides. A definitive diagnosis of sialidosis is made by demonstrating a deficiency of Alpha-N -acetyl neuraminidase activity in amniocytes, leukocytes, and cultured fibroblasts.

questions.text: At around 11.30 PM, a 45-year-old man is wheeled into the casualty with anginal pain for which the consultant advises nitrates. On administration of nitrates, his BP suddenly drops and the patient goes into sudden hypotension. On probing into his medical history, his wife mentions that he has been taking a drug for erectile dysfunction. What is the likely mechanism of the action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Erectile dysfunction is treated by phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, and tadalafil. PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates should not be prescribed together due to an increased risk of hypotension.

The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection. PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP and are, therefore, used in the management of erectile dysfunction.

Drug interactions of PDE-5 and nitrates- PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP by preventing its degradation and therefore cause vasodilation. Since nitrates also act by increasing cyclic GMP mechanism, they can therefore potentiate the effects of PDE-5 inhibitors. Hence, men treated with PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates are at risk for severe hypotension and syncope.

Adverse effects of PDE-5 inhibitors-

  • The most common side effects reported include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, nasopharyngitis, and dyspepsia. Rare but serious reports of prolonged erections lasting more than 4 hours and priapism (painful erections lasting more than 4 hours) have been reported with PDE5 inhibitors. 
  • Sildenafil and vardenafil also cause retinal PDE-6 inhibition and can result in blurring of vision and blue-green tinting of the vision.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman was incidentally found to have a liver mass while undergoing ultrasound for renal calculi. CECT showed the following image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with contrast-enhanced CT showing hypervascular lesion with a central non-enhancing scar points towards focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

Focal nodular hyperplasia is the second most common benign tumour in the liver and is mostly seen in women. This condition is characterised by focal overgrowth of functional liver tissue and the supporting fibrous stroma.

Patients are mostly asymptomatic and FNH is often an incidental finding. If patients are symptomatic, they usually complain of abdominal pain.

On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. A central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern is also seen.

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy comes to the clinic in summer with red plaques over axillae and inguinal folds. A biopsy of the skin lesions revealed a ‘dilapidated brick wall’ appearance. What is the most likely reason for this appearance?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological appearance are indicative of Hailey-Hailey disease. The reason for the dilapidated brick wall appearance is the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes, which occurs due to the breakdown of intercellular bridges.

Hailey–Hailey disease is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by erosions and blistering in the flexures. It typically presents between the second and fourth decade with painful, pruritic, and often malodorous lesions of flexures or other sites of friction.

Secondary infection with Staphylococcus aureus (most common), Herpes simplex virus and Candida is a common complication. A skin biopsy helps confirm the diagnosis. The histology of lesions demonstrates widespread acantholysis, with acantholytic clefts and bullae seen suprabasally. Mild dyskeratosis may also be present, as seen in the image below.

Secondary infection with, Staphylococcus aureus, viruses like herpes simplex virus and Candida is a common complication. A skin biopsy helps confirm the diagnosis.

First-line treatment involves a reduction in friction, with the use of emollients and a moderately potent topical steroid. Long‐term antibiotics may be required for those with secondary infections.

 

Other options:

Option A: Widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes due to fluid accumulation is seen in spongiosis. It is seen in acute and subacute eczematous reactions.

Option B: An increase in the number of keratinocytes in the prickle cell layer of the epidermis is seen in acanthosis. Some of the conditions that it is seen in include psoriasis, epidermal naevi, viral warts, lichen planus, melanoma, Darier's disease, etc

Option D: Nuclear pyknosis and bright pink condensation of the cytoplasm of keratinocytes is an abnormality in epithelial cell keratinization and refers to dyskeratosis. It is seen in squamous cell carcinoma, Bowen disease, solar keratosis, and Darier disease.

questions.text: While collecting a blood sample for investigations, you accidentally drop and spill a 5 ml tube of blood. Which among the following is the best solution to clean it?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite solution in 1:100 dilution is used to clean a blood spill of less than 10 ml.

Blood spills may occur because a laboratory sample breaks during the procedure or during transport, or because there is excessive bleeding during the procedure. In such cases, clean up the spill and record the incident, using the following steps:

  1. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves or appropriate PPE.
  2. Use appropriate instruments (like tongs or a pan and brush) to sweep up any broken glass (or container) as
    possible. Do not pick up pieces with your hands.
  3. Discard the broken glass in a sharps container. If not possible due to the size of the broken glass, wrap it in several layers of paper and discard it carefully in a separate container. It should not be discarded in the regular waste container.
  4. Use disposable paper towels to absorb as much of the body fluids as possible.
  5. Wipe the area with water and detergent until it is visibly clean.
  6. Saturate the area again with 5.25-6.15% sodium hypochlorite, which should be prepared daily.
    • Spills < 10ml are cleaned with 1:100 dilution sodium hypochlorite
    • Spills >10ml or involving a culture spill in the laboratory are cleaned with 1:10 dilution sodium hypochlorite.
  7. Follow this decontamination process with terminal disinfection, using a 1:100 dilution of sodium hypochlorite.
  8. Rinse off the tongs, brush, and pan.
  9. Remove and discard the gloves.
  10. Wash hands carefully with soap and water, and dry with a disposable towel.
  11. Record the incident if a specimen was lost, or persons were exposed to blood and body fluids.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old boy presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae for the last 3 days. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He had a viral fever one week ago which has now resolved. His investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
This patient has a short history of jaundice, which appeared only during a period of stress (viral fever). The lab reports show increased unconjugated bilirubin (normal 0.2-0.8 mg/dL) and normal AST and ALT levels. All this points toward a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and bilirubinuria. Patients are asymptomatic and other laboratory tests are normal. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment in the lysosomes of the centrilobular hepatocytes.

Option B: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but has a milder presentation. Conjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. The liver biopsy does not show pigment deposition.

Option D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is another syndrome that has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is of two types, with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in infancy.

Diffuse hepatocellular disease (e.g., viral or drug-induced hepatitis, cirrhosis)

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby was brought with irritability, vomiting, and seizures. The mother reports that he was breastfed for 6 months and cereals and fruit juices were recently introduced into the diet. On examination, icterus and hepatomegaly were noted. Investigations revealed hypoglycemia and Benedict's test of the urine showed the finding as given below.  Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in him?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, the child becomes symptomatic after ingesting fruit juice that contains fructose, and Benedict's test showing positive results for reducing sugars points towards a diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI). This condition is caused due to the deficiency of aldolase B.

Aldolase B converts fructose-1-phosphate to glyceraldehyde. The deficiency of aldolase B results in the accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate. This decreases the levels of inorganic phosphate and ATPs. ATP is required for gluconeogenesis and protein synthesis. Therefore, the patient presents with hypoglycemia and acidosis. 

Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). They present with profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after ingestion of fructose-containing foods. If the condition is not treated it might lead to the impairment of liver functioning.

Diagnosis is made by detecting reducing sugars in the urine, enzyme assay, or DNA testing for the mutations in the ALDOB gene. Once the diagnosis of HFI is made, the source of fructose must be removed from the diet.

Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Patients with a deficiency of this enzyme are usually asymptomatic as the accumulated fructose is eliminated from urine. This condition is called essential fructosuria.

Options C and D: Deficiency of galactose 1-phosphate uridyl transferase and galactokinase can result in similar symptoms. But it starts as soon as breastfeeding is initiated as the patient cannot metabolise galactose present in the breastmilk. The affected children might also have cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is diagnosed to have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. He struggles to hear and understand speech despite appropriately fit hearing aids. The ENT specialist decided that a cochlear implant would be the best treatment for this patient. What is the site in which the electrode is placed?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. In cochlear implant surgery, the electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve and the higher auditory pathway a prerequisites for cochlear implant surgery.

It is indicated in severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and in those who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

Note:

The auditory brainstem implant is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 20-year-old man twists his right knee while playing in a football game a few days back. He immediately felt the knee swell. At presentation, he reports that the knee catches and locks intermittently. On examination, there is tenderness along the affected joint line. An MRI revealed a meniscal tear and he underwent meniscal tear repair. Which of the following zones of the meniscus is likely to heal last?
questions.solution:
The white zone heals last in case of a meniscal tear due to its poor blood supply. On the other hand, the red zone heals best due to its rich blood supply.

The menisci are supplied by perimeniscal blood vessels from superior and inferior branches of medial and lateral genicular vessels. Following birth, the menisci become increasingly avascular. By adulthood, only the peripheral 10% to 25% of the tissue is perfused. This gives rise to 3 distinct regions of the menisci:

  • The peripheral relatively vascularised region is called the red-red zone (Zone 1)
  • A zone of transition between the 2 zones, is called the red-white zone (Zone 2)
  • The completely avascular inner zone is known as the white-white zone (Zone 3)

There is a direct relationship between vascularization and the capacity of the tissue to heal, predisposing the white-white zone to permanent post-traumatic and degenerative lesions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but is breathing rapidly. SpO2 is measured to be 86%. He is administered oxygen via a face mask with a reservoir bag with a flow rate of 10 L/min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy. 

When respiratory distress and/or hypoxemia of the patient cannot be alleviated after receiving standard oxygen therapy, high–flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNO), or non–invasive ventilation can be considered. Compared to standard oxygen therapy, HFNO reduces the need for intubation.

Patients on HFNO should be closely monitored, and endotracheal intubation should be done if the patient acutely deteriorates or does not improve after a short trial (about 1 hr).

Patients with hypercapnia (exacerbation of COPD), hemodynamic instability, multi-organ failure, or abnormal mental status should not receive HFNO.

Note: If a high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) or simple nasal cannula is used to administer O2, an N95 mask should be applied over it.

Some of the benefits of HFNC are

  • It can deliver oxygen at 40L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.
  • It also reduces the work of breathing, improves gas exchange by nasopharyngeal dead-space washout, and decreases energy required to humidify and heat respiratory gases.

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (no. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with complaints of hip pain for the past few days. She has been taking alendronic acid 10 mg for the treatment of osteoporosis since 6 years. She also takes calcium and vitamin D supplements regularly. What is the next investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
A patient who has been administered bisphosphonates for many years coming with complaints of hip pain arouses suspicion of atypical femur fracture due to long-term bisphosphonate therapy. The next investigation to be done for diagnosis is a plain radiograph.

The first-line medication for reduction of fracture risk in postmenopausal women is oral bisphosphonates therapy with the availability of intravenous formulations as well. Bisphosphonates reduce osteoclastic bone resorption and the general rate of bone turnover. They have been shown to prevent bone loss and to reduce the risk of vertebral and hip fractures.

Prolonged use of bisphosphonates is associated with two potential side effects:

  • Osteonecrosis of the jaw - usually follows a dental procedure.
  • Atypical femur fracture - occurs in the subtrochanteric femoral region or along the shaft distal to the lesser trochanter.

Atypical fractures are those which don't occur at sites typically seen in osteoporosis such as spine, femur (femoral neck and the inter-trochanteric region) or wrist. They instead occur in regions that have increased bone density like the femoral shaft or the subtrochanteric regions. The mechanism of fracture is also atypical wherein it is either atraumatic/low-trauma.

These fractures are thought to occur due to long-term suppression of bone turnover which lowers new bone formation and remodelling. Consequent accumulation of hypermineralized bone which are of poor quality with microcracks are highly susceptible to fractures.

Operative treatment is required for femoral neck and other long bone fractures.

Other options:

Biochemical tests are usually normal in osteoporosis. However, tests like serum calcium, phosphorus, vitamin D, protein, creatinine, alkaline phosphatase, cortisol and parathyroid hormone levels are important in the initial evaluation to rule out differentials and secondary causes of osteoporosis.

The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is DEXA - dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry. A T-score <–2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought by his parents when they noticed that he was passing blood in the urine. He has been complaining of abdominal pain for a few months. On examination, he was found to have a unilateral abdominal mass and ambiguous genitalia. His blood pressure was high. The boy also has intellectual disability. On examination, the following finding was found in his eyes. Which of the following can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows absence of iris (aniridia) and the given scenario indicates WAGR syndrome which is caused due to deletion of WT1 and PAX 6 regions of chromosome 11.

The WAGR syndrome is characterized by

  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genitourinary anomalies
  • Mental retardation

The findings of hematuria, hypertension and abdominal mass which are suggestive of renal tumor which along with aniridia, abnormal genitalia and mental retardation suggest the diagnosis of WAGR syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- C-met proto-oncogene- It codes for c MET tyrosine kinase which binds with hepatocyte growth factor and activates a wide range of cellular signalling pathways. It is implicated in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option B- Mutation of WT1- Willm's tumour related 1 gene regulates the transcription of several other genes. It is implicated in Wilms’ tumor, renal abnormalities and gonadal tumors (WAGR, Denys-Drash and Frasier’s syndromes).

Option C- Mutation of WT2 is implicated in the increased incidence of Wilms tumor in patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS), characterized by enlargement of body organs (organomegaly), macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and adrenal cytomegaly. 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.
